questions.text: Match the following procedures with their correct clinical indication or description:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

  • Paul Miculicz procedure (1-d) Resection of sigmoid with double-barrel stoma: Resection of sigmoid with double-barrel stoma, commonly performed in strangulated sigmoid volvulus with contamination risk.
  • Bishop-Koop procedure (2-c) Procedure for meconium ileus: Used in meconium ileus, creating a proximal stoma with distal chimney to decompress bowel.
  • Hartmann procedure (3-b) End colostomy with rectal stump left inside: Performed for complicated sigmoid disease, involving resection and end colostomy while leaving rectal stump inside.
  • Anterior resection (4-a) Performed for rectal cancers: Standard operation for rectal cancers where the anal sphincter is preserved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paul Miculicz = double-barrel stoma, Bishop-Koop = meconium ileus, Hartmann = rectal stump with colostomy, and anterior resection = rectal cancers.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man with advanced HIV infection has recently been started on combination antiretroviral therapy. Two weeks later, he returns with complaints of vivid dreams, dizziness, impaired concentration, and episodes of confusion. His partner also reports noticeable changes in his mental status and mood swings. Which antiretroviral medication is most likely responsible for these neurological toxicities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Efavirenz

 

  • Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).
  • It is well known to cause neurological toxicity, including altered mental status, insomnia, impaired concentration, vivid dreams, dizziness, and depression.
  • These neuropsychiatric side effects are particularly problematic early in therapy but may persist in some patients.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Zidovudine: A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI); major side effects include bone marrow suppression (anemia, neutropenia) and myopathy, not neurotoxicity.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: Another NRTI; associated with renal toxicity (Fanconi syndrome, tubular dysfunction) and bone mineral loss, not altered mental status.

 

Option D. Atazanavir: A protease inhibitor; adverse effects include indirect hyperbilirubinemia and nephrolithiasis, not neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efavirenz, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), is associated with neurological toxicity, including vivid dreams, confusion, dizziness, and altered mental status.

questions.text: Match the following antimicrobial resistance mechanisms (Column A) with their respective bacterial examples (Column B):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

  • Efflux pumps → Escherichia coli (1–c): E. coli commonly resists tetracycline via efflux pumps (e.g., tetA and tetB genes), which actively transport the drug out of the cell, reducing intracellular antibiotic concentration.
  • Enzymatic inactivation → Pseudomonas aeruginosa (2–d): Pseudomonas is notorious for producing metallo beta-lactamases, aminoglycoside-modifying enzymes, and other drug-degrading enzymes that inactivate antibiotics before they reach their targets.
  • Target site modification → Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) (3–b): MRSA develops resistance by altering the target penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) encoded by the mecA gene, making beta-lactams ineffective.
  • Reduced cell wall permeability → Mycobacterium tuberculosis (4–a): M. tuberculosis has a waxy, lipid-rich cell wall, reducing drug penetration. This intrinsic barrier contributes to resistance against many antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each bacterium often employs a specific resistance strategy:

 

  • E. coli → Efflux pump for tetracycline resistance
  • Pseudomonas → Enzyme-mediated inactivation
  • MRSA → Target site modification (PBP2a)
  • M. tuberculosis → Reduced permeability due to its unique cell wall

choices.text: Pretomanid is metabolized in part by CYP3A4, and hence contraindicated in patients receiving strong or moderate enzyme inducers.
Pretomanid belongs to the bicyclic nitroimidazole class and acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.
Pretomanid is combined with Bedaquiline and Linezolid and is FDA approved for treatment of pre-XDR-TB.
Pretomanid is ineffective in cases of MDR-TB that are resistant to rifampicin or fluoroquinolones.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Pretomanid is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pretomanid is ineffective in cases of MDR-TB that are resistant to rifampicin or fluoroquinolones

 

Pretomanid is effective in MDR-TB, particularly in cases resistant to rifampicin and fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretomanid is metabolized in part by CYP3A4, and hence contraindicated in patients receiving strong or moderate enzyme inducers: Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, and co-administration with enzyme inducers (e.g., rifampicin) reduces its efficacy. Thus, it is contraindicated with enzyme-inducer drugs.

 

Option B. Pretomanid belongs to the bicyclic nitroimidazole class and acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria: Pretomanid is a bicyclic nitroimidazole that targets mycolic acid synthesis, a critical component of mycobacterial cell wall formation.

 

Option C. Pretomanid is combined with Bedaquiline and Linezolid and is FDA approved for treatment of pre-XDR-TB: Pretomanid, in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid, was FDA-approved in 2019 for XDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pretomanid is a bicyclic nitroimidazole, metabolized by CYP3A4, contraindicated with enzyme-inducer drugs, and FDA-approved with bedaquiline + linezolid for Pre-XDR/XDR-TB.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of severe burning itch on both hands. Examination reveals multiple clear vesicles as shown in the figure. He also has erythema, fissuring, and maceration between the 4th and 5th toes of the left foot, along with bilateral but asymmetrical vesiculopustular lesions on the insteps. He has a history of atopy. There is no history of contact with irritant chemicals in the recent past. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dyshidrotic eczema

 

  • Dyshidrotic eczema (pompholyx) is characterized by symmetric, pruritic vesicles on the palms and soles that may coalesce into bullae. 
  • A history of atopy is often present, and triggers include stress. 
  • The clinical picture of diffuse vesicles with severe itching strongly supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis: Allergic or irritant contact dermatitis usually produces localized erythema, scaling, and vesiculation at the site of allergen exposure. This patient denies exposure to irritants, and the symmetrical involvement of both palms is atypical.

 

Option C. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex: This is a genetic blistering disorder where blisters develop at sites of friction, often in childhood. In contrast, the current case shows acute onset vesicles with atopic history, favoring dyshidrotic eczema rather than a hereditary blistering condition.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex: Herpetic whitlow presents with painful grouped vesicles, usually on one finger or hand, not with diffuse bilateral palm involvement. The absence of a prodromal viral history also makes herpes simplex unlikely here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dyshidrotic eczema (pompholyx) presents with recurrent, symmetric pruritic vesicles on the palms and soles, often linked to atopy and triggered by stress or fungal infections, distinguishing it from contact dermatitis, genetic blistering disorders, and viral infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active man presents with growths over the shaft and glans of his penis. On examination, the lesions are as shown below. Which strains of human papillomavirus (HPV) are most commonly responsible for these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV 6 and 11

 

  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata, are most commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11. 
  • These strains have low oncogenic potential but are highly contagious and spread through sexual contact. 
  • The lesions are soft, fleshy, and verrucous, and histology often shows koilocytosis (cells with perinuclear halo).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV 1, 2, and 3: These HPV strains are associated with cutaneous warts (verruca vulgaris and plantar warts) rather than genital warts. They typically appear on hands and feet, not in the genital region.

 

Option B. HPV 3 and 5: These are linked with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare inherited condition with widespread flat warts and a predisposition to skin cancers, not genital lesions.

 

Option D. HPV 16 and 18: These are high-risk oncogenic strains associated with cervical, anal, and penile intraepithelial neoplasia and cancers. While they can cause flat lesions, they are not the most common cause of exophytic genital warts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital warts (condyloma acuminata) are most commonly caused by HPV 6 and 11, which have low malignant potential, whereas high-risk HPV strains (16, 18, 31, 33) are linked to cervical and anogenital cancers.

choices.text: Total protein of 252 mg in a 24-hour urine collection

questions.text: A multiparous patient who did not attend any antenatal visit and came to the emergency room with a complaint of bleeding. On examination, uterine tone was increased with BP >150/90 mmHg. Which of the following tests supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Creatinine 1.24 mg/dl

 

  • Preeclampsia is diagnosed by the presence of elevated blood pressure after 20 weeks of gestation (≥140/90 mmHg) and either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction. 
  • One of the markers of end-organ dysfunction in preeclampsia is renal impairment, which can be indicated by an elevated serum creatinine level.
  • A serum creatinine level of >0.9 mg/dL is considered abnormal in pregnancy and supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia. 
  • The value of 1.24 mg/dL in this patient is above the normal threshold, indicating renal involvement and supporting the diagnosis of preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet counts 164,000/microL: Normal count. Thrombocytopenia in preeclampsia is defined as <100,000/microL.

 

Option C. Alkaline phosphatase 142 IU/L: Alkaline phosphatase levels typically rise during pregnancy due to placental production, so this is not a specific indicator of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Total protein of 252 mg in a 24-hour urine collection: While proteinuria is a key feature of preeclampsia, the threshold for diagnosis is ≥300 mg/24 hours. A level of 252 mg is below this threshold and does not meet the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL is an indicator of renal involvement in preeclampsia and supports the diagnosis in patients with elevated blood pressure after 20 weeks of gestation. 
  • Other indicators, such as thrombocytopenia or proteinuria, may indicate severity but are not always present early in the disease course.

choices.text: Prophylactic methylergometrine administration with delivery of the anterior shoulder
Shortening of the second stage of labor

questions.text: Which of the following measures is not recommended in the intrapartum management of a woman with preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prophylactic methylergometrine administration with delivery of the anterior shoulder

 

  • In women with preeclampsia, intrapartum management focuses on controlling blood pressure, preventing seizures, and avoiding complications such as pulmonary edema and intracranial hemorrhage.
  • Methylergometrine is contraindicated because it causes potent vasoconstriction and can lead to sudden severe hypertension, stroke, or myocardial ischemia in preeclamptic women.
  • Instead, oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for prevention of postpartum hemorrhage in these patients.
  • Fluid restriction helps avoid pulmonary edema, as preeclamptic patients have increased vascular permeability and reduced oncotic pressure.
  • Shortening the second stage of labor (e.g., with assisted delivery) reduces maternal stress, helps prevent BP surges, and minimizes the risk of complications.
  • Thus, the incorrect and unsafe measure is prophylactic methylergometrine at delivery of the anterior shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin 10 units intramuscularly after delivery: Correct practice. Safe in preeclampsia for postpartum hemorrhage prevention without the hypertensive risks associated with ergot derivatives.

 

Option C. Restriction of intravenous fluids:  Correct practice. Reduces the risk of pulmonary edema in preeclamptic patients, who are prone to fluid overload due to increased capillary permeability.

 

Option D. Shortening of the second stage of labor: Correct practice. Minimizes prolonged maternal effort, reduces risk of BP spikes, and lowers the chance of cerebrovascular complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In preeclampsia, methylergometrine is avoided during labor and delivery because of its potent vasoconstrictive effect, which can precipitate severe hypertension and life-threatening complications. 
  • Oxytocin is preferred for uterine contraction after delivery.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is taken to the operating room for incision and drainage of a perianal abscess under general anesthesia. He is breathing spontaneously throughout the procedure. The anesthesiologist must choose the most efficient breathing circuit for spontaneous ventilation with minimal fresh gas flow requirements. Which of the following is the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

 

  • The Mapleson A (Magill circuit) is the circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation because it requires the lowest fresh gas flow—approximately equal to the patient’s minute ventilation (around 5 L/min). 
  • Its efficiency in minimizing rebreathing under spontaneous breathing makes it ideal for such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mapleson B: This circuit is rarely used in clinical practice. It is inefficient for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation, as it requires high fresh gas flows to prevent rebreathing.

 

Option C. Mapleson C: The Mapleson C (Waters circuit) is a compact version of the Mapleson B and is commonly used in postoperative recovery rooms because of its portability. However, it is not the best for spontaneous breathing intraoperatively since it requires higher flows compared to Mapleson A.

 

Option D. Mapleson D: The Mapleson D (Bain circuit) system, particularly in its coaxial Bain modification, is highly efficient for controlled ventilation, not for spontaneous breathing. It requires higher gas flows for spontaneous ventilation and is therefore not the first choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mapleson A (Magill) circuit is the most efficient breathing system for spontaneous ventilation, while Mapleson D (Bain circuit) is the preferred choice for controlled ventilation.

choices.text: Excess TSH secretion due to pituitary adenoma
Autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells
Excess production of thyroglobulin by thyroid follicular cells

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and constipation. On examination, she has dry skin, coarse hair, and a diffusely enlarged, non-tender thyroid gland. Laboratory studies reveal elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and decreased free thyroxine (T4). Fine-needle aspiration biopsy demonstrates lymphocytic infiltration with Hurthle cell changes. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells

 

  • This 39-year-old woman has classical features of hypothyroidism: fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, dry skin, coarse hair, and a diffuse non-tender goiter. 
  • Laboratory data show increased TSH and low T4, confirming primary hypothyroidism.
  • The key histological findings — lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cell changes — are characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. 
  • The pathogenesis involves autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells, mediated by cytotoxic T lymphocytes and associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excess TSH secretion due to pituitary adenoma: This would cause secondary hyperthyroidism with high TSH and high T4, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations. This is the opposite of the patient’s presentation, which is hypothyroidism.

 

Option C. Defective synthesis of thyroglobulin: Rare congenital defects in thyroglobulin synthesis can lead to hypothyroidism, but they present in infancy with congenital hypothyroidism features, not in a 45-year-old woman with autoimmune histology (lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells).

 

Option D. Excess production of thyroglobulin by thyroid follicular cells: Increased thyroglobulin alone does not lead to hypothyroidism. It may occur in certain thyroid neoplasms, but it is not associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis or lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas, is due to autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells and is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cell changes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with Graves’ hyperthyroidism presents with gritty eyes, double vision, and eyelid swelling for 3 months. He has uncontrolled hyperthyroidism on carbimazole and is a smoker. Examination reveals proptosis, conjunctival injection, and restricted extraocular movements, with preserved vision. Orbital CT shows thickened extraocular muscles, confirming severe thyroid eye disease (TED). All of the following can be used in his treatment except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenium supplementation

 

  • The patient’s symptoms (gritty eyes, double vision, eyelid swelling), signs (proptosis, conjunctival injection, restricted extraocular movements), and CT findings (thickened extraocular muscles) indicate moderate-to-severe thyroid eye disease (TED) associated with Graves’ hyperthyroidism. Smoking and uncontrolled hyperthyroidism exacerbate TED; preserved vision excludes optic neuropathy.
  • Selenium supplementation is primarily used for mild TED to reduce inflammation, especially in selenium-deficient areas. 
  • In moderate-to-severe TED with significant proptosis and diplopia, as in this patient, selenium lacks efficacy as a primary treatment. 
  • First-line options include IV glucocorticoids or teprotumumab, with radiation as a second-line choice.
  • Treatment involves achieving euthyroidism (e.g., optimizing carbimazole), smoking cessation, local measures (lubricating drops, dark glasses), and specific therapies like glucocorticoids or teprotumumab, with external beam radiation for refractory cases, based on clinical severity. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous methylprednisolone: Can be used. IV glucocorticoids (e.g., methylprednisolone, 0.5–1 g/week) are a first-line treatment for moderate-to-severe TED, effectively reducing inflammation, proptosis, and diplopia, suitable for this patient’s active disease.

 

Option B. Teprotumumab infusions: Can be used. Teprotumumab is a first-line therapy for moderate-to-severe TED, targeting IGF-1 receptors to improve proptosis and diplopia, ideal for this patient, though access in India may be limited.

 

Option D. External beam radiation therapy: Can be used. As a second-line option, external beam radiation is appropriate for moderate-to-severe TED with persistent inflammation or failure of first-line therapies, reducing orbital inflammation when combined with glucocorticoids, despite potential access constraints in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intravenous methylprednisolone controls inflammation in moderate-to-severe TED with conjunctival injection and diplopia.
  • Teprotumumab infusions improve proptosis and extraocular movement restriction in moderate-to-severe TED.
  • External beam radiation is a second-line option for persistent moderate-to-severe TED.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a sudden severe headache, palpitations, sweating, and markedly elevated blood pressure (220/120 mmHg). His wife reports that earlier in the evening he had attended a party where he consumed aged cheese, red wine, and smoked meats. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder that has been poorly controlled with multiple medications, and he is currently taking phenelzine. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for managing this patient’s current hypertensive crisis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tolazoline

 

  • This patient has a hypertensive crisis triggered by ingestion of tyramine-containing foods (aged cheese, wine, smoked meats) while on a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) such as phenelzine or tranylcypromine.
  • Tyramine displaces norepinephrine from presynaptic vesicles, causing a massive adrenergic surge and severe hypertension (“cheese reaction”).
  • Tolazoline, a non-selective alpha-adrenergic antagonist, is the drug of choice (DOC) for such hypertensive crises. By blocking alpha-adrenergic receptors, it counteracts the excessive catecholamine effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydralazine: Direct arteriolar vasodilator, but not the specific DOC for catecholamine-driven crises.

 

Option C. Nitroglycerin: Primarily a venodilator used for angina, not effective for this mechanism.

 

Option D. Propranolol: Non-selective beta-blocker; contraindicated in catecholamine crisis due to risk of unopposed alpha stimulation, which can worsen hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolazoline is the drug of choice for hypertensive crisis precipitated by tyramine ingestion (“cheese reaction”) in patients taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer has been receiving chemotherapy for the past 2 months. She now reports progressive burning pain and tingling in her palms and soles. On examination, there is erythema, swelling, and peeling of the skin on both hands, along with tender, thickened patches and ulceration on the soles. The symptoms worsen when she grips objects or walks long distances. Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents is most strongly associated with this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-Fluorouracil

 

  • This patient presents with painful erythema, swelling, and desquamation of the palms and soles, consistent with hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia), a dose-limiting toxicity of some chemotherapeutic drugs.
  • Capecitabine and 5-fluorouracil have the highest incidence of causing this syndrome. 
  • The prolonged exposure leads to accumulation of toxic metabolites in the capillaries of palms and soles, producing characteristic changes.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Doxorubicin: Anthracycline associated with cardiotoxicity (dilated cardiomyopathy), myelosuppression, and alopecia, but not hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: It is associated with hepatotoxicity, megaloblastic anemia, bone marrow suppression and pulmonary fibrosis but not hand and foot syndrome.

 

Option D. Paclitaxel: Microtubule inhibitor; dose-limiting toxicities include peripheral neuropathy, myelosuppression, and alopecia, not hand-foot syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine, an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil, carries the maximum risk of hand-foot syndrome, characterized by painful erythema, swelling, and desquamation of the palms and soles.

choices.text: 3′ to 5′ polymerase activity of DNA polymerase δ
3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase γ
5′ to 3′ polymerase activity of DNA polymerase III
3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase δ

questions.text: Which of the following proofreading activities is critical for ensuring the accuracy of nuclear DNA replication in eukaryotic cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase δ

 

  • In eukaryotic nuclear DNA replication, DNA polymerase δ (lagging strand) and DNA polymerase ε (leading strand) are responsible for the bulk of synthesis. 
  • Both possess 3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity, which serves as the proofreading function.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • During synthesis, if an incorrect nucleotide is incorporated, the polymerase pauses.
  • The 3′ to 5′ exonuclease removes the mispaired nucleotide from the 3′ end.
  • DNA synthesis then resumes in the correct sequence, maintaining high fidelity.
  • Key point: Accuracy in nuclear DNA replication depends on proofreading by nuclear DNA polymerases (δ & ε), not mitochondrial enzymes or prokaryotic polymerases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3′ to 5′ polymerase activity of DNA polymerase δ: Incorrect. No DNA polymerase synthesizes in the 3′ to 5′ direction; polymerases work 5′ to 3′ only.

 

Option B. 3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase γ: Incorrect. While this activity exists, DNA polymerase γ functions in mitochondrial DNA replication, not nuclear DNA replication.

 

Option C. 5′ to 3′ polymerase activity of DNA polymerase III: Incorrect. DNA polymerase III is a prokaryotic enzyme and not involved in eukaryotic nuclear DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 3′ to 5′ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase δ is the primary proofreading mechanism ensuring the accuracy of nuclear DNA replication in eukaryotes.

 

Prokaryotic DNA Polymerase

 

 

Note: DNA Polymerase I, II, III have proofreading ability.

 

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerase

questions.text: During a surgical procedure for endolymphatic sac decompression, it is crucial to identify a specific anatomical landmark to guide the surgery. Which structure, based on the provided diagram, is the appropriate surgical landmark?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  • The correct surgical landmark for endolymphatic sac decompression is C.
  • This is due to Donaldson's line, which passes through the horizontal semicircular canal and bisects the posterior semicircular canal. 
  • The endolymphatic sac lies anterior and inferior to this line, making it an essential reference point during surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In endolymphatic sac decompression, Donaldson’s line is used as a landmark to locate the endolymphatic sac, as it passes through the horizontal and posterior semicircular canals

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with acute left flank pain radiating to the groin. After giving him NSAIDs for the pain, an X-ray KUB is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plain CT KUB

 

  • Non-contrast CT KUB (kidneys, ureters, bladder) is the gold standard for diagnosing urolithiasis, as it provides precise information on stone size, location, density, and associated obstruction. 
  • It guides the choice of definitive management (ESWL, URS, PCNL, or conservative). 
  • Hence, it is the most appropriate next step before intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is a treatment modality for stones less than 2 cm in the kidney or upper ureter. However, it is not the immediate next step before confirming stone size and location on CT KUB.

 

Option B. Uretero-renoscopic removal (URS): Ureteroscopy is a treatment option for ureteric stones, particularly in the mid and lower ureter. As with ESWL, the choice of URS requires prior imaging confirmation with CT KUB for stone location and suitability.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Observation is appropriate for small stones (<5 mm) that have a high chance of spontaneous passage. However, in this case, further imaging with CT KUB is required first to confirm stone size and position before adopting a conservative approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-contrast CT KUB is the investigation of choice in suspected renal/ureteric calculi, as it defines stone size, location, and density, thereby guiding the decision between conservative management and intervention.

questions.text: A 38-year-old multiparous woman presents with progressive dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding. Pelvic exam reveals a uniformly enlarged, tender, boggy uterus consistent with adenomyosis. She does not desire future fertility and requests medical therapy to control symptoms. Which of the following is not an appropriate medical treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Copper intrauterine device

 

  • The copper intrauterine device lacks progestin; it commonly increases menstrual bleeding and cramping, which can worsen adenomyosis symptoms rather than treat them. 
  • Therefore, the copper intrauterine device is not an appropriate medical therapy for adenomyosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Appropriate. NSAIDs reduce prostaglandin synthesis, thereby improving dysmenorrhea and contributing to decreased menstrual blood loss. They are a standard medical first-line option for adenomyosis symptoms.

 

Option B. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS): Appropriate. The LNG-IUS delivers local progestin, causing endometrial decidualization/atrophy, significantly reducing heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea in adenomyosis; it is among the most effective medical therapies.

 

Option D. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs): Appropriate. COCs regulate cycles, reduce menorrhagia, and alleviate dysmenorrhea through endometrial suppression—well-accepted medical therapy for adenomyosis when fertility is not desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adenomyosis, evidence-based medical treatments include NSAIDs, COCs, and especially LNG-IUS; the copper intrauterine device (non-hormonal) is not appropriate because it can increase bleeding and cramping, potentially worsening symptoms.

questions.text: What is the indication for the following maneuvers being done in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body aspiration

 

  • The maneuvers illustrated are back blows and chest thrusts, which are specifically recommended for infants <1 year old with complete airway obstruction due to foreign body aspiration. 
  • Abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) are avoided in infants because of the risk of visceral injury, so chest thrusts are the safer alternative. 
  • These steps aim to generate high intrathoracic pressure to expel the obstructing object.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest management in infants requires high-quality CPR with chest compressions and ventilation, not back blows or chest thrusts. These maneuvers are ineffective in restoring circulation during arrest and are not part of resuscitation algorithms for cardiac arrest.

 

Option C. Ventricular tachycardia: Infant ventricular tachycardia is managed depending on stability: unstable VT requires synchronized cardioversion, while stable VT may be treated with antiarrhythmics. Mechanical maneuvers like chest thrusts or back blows have no therapeutic role in arrhythmia management.

 

Option D. Hypothermia: Hypothermia in infants requires warming measures such as warm blankets, radiant warmers, and heated oxygen delivery. Physical thrust maneuvers do not address hypothermia and could worsen the infant’s instability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Back blows and chest thrusts are the first-line interventions for relieving complete airway obstruction due to foreign body aspiration in infants under one year of age.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with morbid obesity undergoes bariatric surgery. Which of the following best describes the procedure performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roux-en-Y gastric bypass

 

  • This surgery involves creating a small gastric pouch and connecting it to a Roux limb of the jejunum, bypassing the majority of the stomach and duodenum. 
  • It is one of the most effective bariatric procedures, leading to significant weight loss by restricting intake and inducing malabsorption.

 

Option A. Duodenal switch: This procedure combines sleeve gastrectomy with a long intestinal bypass, preserving the pylorus and duodenum. It's more complex and has a higher risk of nutritional deficiencies than Roux-en-Y.

 

 

Option C. Sleeve gastrectomy: This procedure reduces the stomach volume by removing its greater curvature, leaving behind a narrow tubular gastric conduit. It is restrictive but does not involve intestinal bypass, unlike the Roux-en-Y.

 

 

Option D. Minigastric bypass:  Mini-gastric bypass (MGB) is a bariatric surgery in which a long, narrow gastric pouch is created and connected to the small intestine about 150–200 cm distal to the ligament of Treitz. It combines restrictive and malabsorptive mechanisms, leading to significant weight loss and improvement in obesity-related comorbidities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is a bariatric surgery that creates a small gastric pouch and diverts food into the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum and part of the small bowel, combining restriction with malabsorption for weight reduction.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with an ultrasound report confirming an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her β-hCG level is 600 IU/L. The scan shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Expectant management

 

  • In this scenario, expectant management is the most appropriate option. Expectant management involves close observation without active intervention. 
  • It is indicated in cases where the following criteria are met:
    • The β-hCG level is low (typically <1,000 IU/L, and in this case, it is 600 IU/L).
    • The patient is hemodynamically stable with no symptoms.
    • The gestational sac size is less than 3.5 cm.
    • There is no yolk sac or cardiac activity seen on the scan.
  • Since this patient has all the criteria for expectant management, close follow-up with serial weekly β-hCG measurements would be appropriate.
  • The β-hCG levels should steadily decrease over time, and if they fall as expected, no further treatment is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Single-dose inj Methotrexate: Methotrexate is typically used for medical management in cases where the β-hCG level is between 1,000 and 5,000 IU/L. In this case, with a very low β-hCG level of 600 IU/L, expectant management is more appropriate. Methotrexate may be considered if the β-hCG levels were higher (e.g., >1,000 but <5,000 IU/L).

 

Option C. Laparoscopic salpingostomy: Surgical management, such as salpingostomy, is reserved for cases where the β-hCG level is >5,000 IU/L, the patient is symptomatic, or the ectopic pregnancy is larger than 3.5 cm. In this stable, asymptomatic patient, surgery is unnecessary.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic salpingotomy: Similar to salpingostomy, salpingotomy is indicated in cases where the pregnancy is more advanced, the patient is unstable, or medical management is contraindicated or has failed. This is not required in this case due to the stable condition and low β-hCG level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with an unruptured, asymptomatic ectopic pregnancy and low β-hCG levels (<1,000 IU/L), expectant management is an appropriate option.
  • Regular follow-up with serial β-hCG measurements is necessary to confirm that the pregnancy is resolving spontaneously.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/ are correct regarding the highlighted structure (in red) shown below?

 

 

  1. Its superior border is the inguinal ligament.
  2. Its lateral border is formed by the sartorius muscle.
  3. Its medial border is formed by the adductor magnus muscle.
  4. The femoral artery and vein pass through this structure.
  5. The saphenous nerve passes through this structure.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, and 5 only

 

  • The femoral triangle is an important anatomical region located in the upper anterior thigh.
  •  Its boundaries are:
    • Statement 1. Its superior border is the inguinal ligament: This ligament stretches from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the pubic tubercle, forming the upper border of the triangle.
    • Statement 2. Its lateral border is formed by the sartorius muscle: This long, thin muscle runs diagonally across the thigh and serves as the lateral boundary.
    • Statement 4. The femoral artery and vein pass through this structure: The contents of the femoral triangle, arranged from lateral to medial, are:
      1. Femoral nerve
      2. Femoral artery (Statement 4 – Correct)
      3. Femoral vein (Statement 4 – Correct)
      4. Lymphatics
    • Statement 5. The saphenous nerve passes through this structure: Additionally, the saphenous nerve (a sensory branch of the femoral nerve) passes through the femoral triangle before entering the adductor canal.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Its medial border is formed by the adductor magnus muscle: Adductor longus muscle, not adductor magnus. The adductor magnus lies deeper and more posterior, so it does not form the medial border of the femoral triangle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The femoral triangle is bounded superiorly by the inguinal ligament, laterally by the sartorius muscle, and medially by the adductor longus muscle. 
  • Its contents include the femoral nerve, artery, vein, lymphatics, and the saphenous nerve. 
  • The adductor magnus is not part of its borders.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with acute onset of eye pain, blurred vision, headache, and halos around lights. Examination reveals a mid-dilated pupil, corneal edema, and markedly raised intraocular pressure. She is diagnosed with primary angle closure glaucoma. Arrange the following events in the order in which they occur in the pathogenesis of primary angle closure glaucoma:

 

  1. Peripheral anterior synechiae
  2. Iris bombe
  3. Optic nerve and visual field changes
  4. Relative pupillary block
  5. Irido-trabeculo-corneal contact
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4, 2, 5, 1, 3

 

  • Primary angle closure glaucoma occurs due to a mechanical obstruction of aqueous humor flow, leading to a sequence of events:
  • Relative pupillary block (4): Resistance to aqueous flow from posterior to anterior chamber occurs at the mid-dilated pupil, leading to pressure buildup behind the iris.
  • Iris bombe (2): The posterior chamber pressure bows the peripheral iris forward.
  • Irido-trabeculo-corneal contact (5): The bowed iris blocks the trabecular meshwork, impeding aqueous outflow and raising IOP.
  • Peripheral anterior synechiae (1): Prolonged iridocorneal contact results in adhesions (synechiae), permanently closing the angle.
  • Optic nerve and visual field changes (3): Sustained elevated IOP damages the optic nerve, resulting in visual field loss and glaucomatous optic neuropathy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary angle closure glaucoma begins with a relative pupillary block, leading to iris bombe, angle closure, formation of peripheral anterior synechiae, and finally optic nerve damage with visual field defects.
  • PACG sequence:
    • Relative pupillary block → Iris bombe → Angle contact → Peripheral anterior synechiae → Optic nerve damage
    • Early recognition of this sequence is critical to prevent irreversible vision loss.

choices.text: Inheritance of the ε4 allele at the ApoE gene
Inheritance of a mutant prion gene
Expansion of CAG repeats on chromosome 4p16

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with an 8-year history of progressive cognitive decline and dementia dies of bronchopneumonia. At autopsy, the brain is shown below. Microscopic evaluation reveals numerous neuritic plaques in the hippocampus, amygdala, and neocortex, and Congo red staining demonstrates amyloid deposition within cerebral arteries. Which of the following genetic factors is most likely associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inheritance of the ε4 allele at the ApoE gene

 

  • This 70-year-old woman had a long course of progressive dementia and died of a common terminal complication (bronchopneumonia). 
  • Autopsy revealed cerebral atrophy. 
  • The cerebral atrophy seen here mainly in the frontal and parietal regions is characterized by narrowed gyri along with widened sulci, and histology showed numerous neuritic plaques in the hippocampus, amygdala, and neocortex. 
  • Congo red staining demonstrated amyloid deposition in cerebral arteries.
  • These findings are diagnostic of Alzheimer disease, the most common cause of dementia in elderly individuals. 
  • A major genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer disease is inheritance of the ε4 allele of the ApoE gene, which increases deposition of β-amyloid derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP).
  • Thus, the most likely genetic factor involved is ApoE ε4.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA-DR3/DR4: These HLA types are associated with Rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes mellitus, not Alzheimer disease. They are unrelated to amyloid deposition or neuritic plaques.

 

Option C. Inheritance of a mutant prion gene: Mutations in the prion protein gene cause Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a rapidly progressive dementia characterized by spongiform encephalopathy and death within months. This patient’s 8-year dementia history with neuritic plaques and amyloid angiopathy is not consistent with prion disease.

 

Option D. Expansion of CAG repeats on chromosome 4p16: This trinucleotide repeat expansion is the cause of Huntington disease, which presents with chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and progressive dementia beginning in mid-adulthood. It is not associated with amyloid plaques or Congo red–positive vascular deposits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer disease is characterized by progressive dementia, neuritic plaques, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and cerebral atrophy. Inheritance of the ε4 allele of the ApoE gene is a major genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true regarding national anemia and deworming programs, except:

 

  1. Pregnant women receive 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid weekly.
  2. Adolescents are given blue tablets weekly under IFA prophylaxis.
  3. Albendazole is given only to children aged 12–59 months.
  4. Deworming in women of reproductive age is carried out biannually.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. Pregnant women receive 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid weekly: False. Pregnant and lactating women are given daily supplementation, not weekly.

 

Statement 3. Albendazole is given only to children aged 12–59 months: False. Deworming is provided to children (1–19 years), WRA, and pregnant women. So Albendazole is not limited to 12–59 months.

 

True Statements:

 

Statement 2. Adolescents are given blue tablets weekly under IFA prophylaxis: True. Adolescents (10–19 years) are provided 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly in the blue tablet form.

 

Statement 4. Deworming in women of reproductive age is carried out biannually: True. WRA (20–49 years) receive 400 mg Albendazole twice a year, under the National Deworming Day program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • National IFA and Deworming Supplementation
  • Iron-Folic Acid Supplementation

 

 

  • NPNL = Non-pregnant, Non-lactating
  • Pregnancy: From 4th month POG onwards for 180 days
  • Albendazole Deworming (400 mg Tablet)

choices.text: Arrange for cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if PCV < 30%
Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver

questions.text: A 25-year-old G3P2 presented to the OPD at 29 weeks. Her blood group is B negative and her husband's blood group is B positive. An ICT (indirect Coombs test) revealed high titers of 1 in 32, and an MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler shows an increased peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM). Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrange for cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if PCV < 30%

 

  • The patient has Rh alloimmunization with an increased risk of fetal anemia, as evidenced by high titers of antibodies (1:32) and elevated MCA peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM), which indicates fetal anemia. 
  • The next appropriate step in management is to arrange for cordocentesis (also known as percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)) to confirm the diagnosis and assess the fetal hemoglobin level. 
  • If the fetal PCV is <30%, the fetus may require an intrauterine transfusion to treat anemia.
  • The MCA peak systolic velocity is used as a non-invasive way to detect fetal anemia. An MCA PSV >1.5 MoM is a reliable indicator of moderate to severe fetal anemia.
  • Cordocentesis allows direct measurement of fetal hemoglobin and blood gases, guiding the decision on whether to perform an intrauterine transfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis for amniotic fluid spectrophotometry: This method was traditionally used to assess fetal anemia (based on amniotic fluid bilirubin levels) but has largely been replaced by the more reliable and non-invasive MCA Doppler for assessing fetal anemia.

 

Option C. Give Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity and deliver: While Betamethasone may be given to promote fetal lung maturity if early delivery is necessary, it is too early to consider delivery at 29 weeks based solely on anemia. First, the fetal anemia should be confirmed and managed with intrauterine transfusion.

 

Option D. Repeat MCA PSV after 1 week: With a significantly elevated MCA PSV (>1.5 MoM), the situation likely indicates moderate to severe fetal anemia. Immediate action, such as cordocentesis and intrauterine transfusion, is needed rather than waiting to repeat the MCA Doppler after a week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of Rh alloimmunization with elevated MCA peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM), the next step is cordocentesis to confirm fetal anemia. 
  • If fetal hemoglobin levels are low (PCV <30%), intrauterine transfusion is indicated to treat the anemia and improve fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Immediate corticosteroid therapy for fetal lung maturity
Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman presents at 29 weeks gestation with headache and a blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg. Investigations reveal 2+ proteinuria on dipstick, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and a platelet count of 80,000/mm³. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor

 

  • This 30-year-old primigravida at 29 weeks gestation presents with severe hypertension (BP 160/110 mmHg), proteinuria (2+ on dipstick), elevated liver enzymes (SGOT, SGPT), and thrombocytopenia (platelet count 80,000/mm³).
  • These findings indicate severe preeclampsia with HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets).
  • The definitive management for severe preeclampsia or HELLP after viability is delivery, regardless of gestational age, to prevent maternal and fetal complications (such as eclampsia, placental abruption, DIC, fetal demise).
  • Magnesium sulphate therapy is initiated to prevent seizures (eclampsia prophylaxis).
  • Induction of labor is preferred over expectant management in severe disease with end-organ involvement.
  • Thus, Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labor is the correct, guideline-supported approach for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antihypertensive therapy: Incorrect. While antihypertensives are important for blood pressure control, they do not address the underlying severe preeclampsia or HELLP. Definitive management requires delivery, and delaying for sole BP control risks maternal and fetal morbidity.

 

Option B. Immediate corticosteroid therapy for fetal lung maturity: Incorrect. Antenatal corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) can be considered if delivery is anticipated before 34 weeks, but in this patient with severe features and thrombocytopenia, immediate delivery is indicated after maternal stabilization, not delay for 48 hours solely to complete steroid dosing.

 

Option D. Expectant management with close monitoring: Incorrect. Expectant management may be considered in mild preeclampsia without severe features before 37 weeks, but is contraindicated in HELLP or severe disease due to high maternal and fetal risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome, Magnesium sulphate is given for seizure prophylaxis, and delivery is the definitive treatment, regardless of gestational age, after maternal stabilization.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical locations normally contains this type of tissue, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intervertebral disc

 

  • Fibrocartilage is a specialized connective tissue composed of type I collagen fibers arranged in thick bundles, providing high tensile strength. 
  • It contains chondrocytes in lacunae but lacks a perichondrium. This tissue is ideally suited for areas under both compressive and tensile forces. 
  • Intervertebral discs, particularly in the annulus fibrosus, are composed of fibrocartilage. 
  • The tissue shown in the histology image demonstrates elongated collagen fibers with interspersed chondrocytes—characteristic of fibrocartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pubic symphysis: Also made of fibrocartilage, but in this context, the correct answer is the intervertebral disc because of the direct clinical and histological correlation described.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: Contains elastic cartilage, rich in type II collagen and elastic fibers, giving flexibility. Found in the epiglottis, external ear, and Eustachian tube.

 

Option D. Articular cartilage: Composed of hyaline cartilage, which has type II collagen and a smooth, glassy appearance, specialized for reducing friction in synovial joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrocartilage, composed primarily of type I collagen and lacking a perichondrium, is found in the intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and tendon-bone junctions, providing resistance to both compressive and tensile forces.

questions.text:
A public health program adopts a service-based approach, aiming to deliver health services directly to the community. However, this strategy is later evaluated for long-term effectiveness and community engagement. All of the following statements are limitations of the service approach, except?

 

  1. It often ignores the felt needs of the community.
  2. Long-term sustainability is a concern due to lack of ownership.
  3. It enhances local leadership involvement and participatory decision-making.
  4. It may lead to passive dependence on external healthcare providers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 only

 

  • Statement 3. It enhances local leadership involvement and participatory decision-making: Is not a limitation – Rather, encouragement of local leadership and participation is a strength of approaches like primary healthcare or health education, not the service approach.
  • Service approach is typically top-down, with services provided irrespective of community participation.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. It often ignores the felt needs of the community: True. Service approach often provides what is deemed important by health authorities, not necessarily what the community needs or asks for.

 

Statement 2. Long-term sustainability is a concern due to lack of ownership: True. Without community involvement, such programs tend to fade over time due to lack of ownership.

 

Statement 4. It may lead to passive dependence on external healthcare providers: True. This model may result in passive dependency, rather than empowering people to take control of their own health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The service approach delivers care without empowering the community, often leading to unsustainable health gains. 
  • Participatory strategies remain key for long-term behavior change and self-reliance in public health.

questions.text: The following patients are victims of a mass casualty. Assign appropriate triage codes to them:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

  • In mass casualty incidents, triage is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their injuries and their potential for survival with immediate treatment. 
  • A four-tier system is commonly used:
  • Red: Immediate care needed; life-threatening injuries with a good chance of survival if treated promptly.
    • Hemothorax requires immediate drainage to prevent death = Red (1–C)
  • Yellow: Delayed care; serious injuries but not immediately life-threatening and the patient can wait for a short period without loss of life or limb.
    • Compound tibial fracture is serious but stable = Yellow (2–A)
  • Green: Minor injuries; the patient can wait for longer periods for care without significant risk.
    • Arm laceration without significant bleeding = Green (3–D)
  • Black: Expectant; injuries are so severe that survival is unlikely even with treatment.
    • 90% fourth-degree burns have extremely poor prognosis even with care = Black (4–B)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about epistaxis are correct? 

 

  1. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the source of bleeding in 90% of cases
  2. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be given if anterior nasal packing is left for more than 48 hours
  3. Anterior nasal packing is easier to insert and less traumatic than balloon tamponade
  4. Trotter’s method is used as a first aid measure in epistaxis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 1. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the source of bleeding in 90% of cases: Correct. Kiesselbach’s plexus (Little’s area) is indeed the most common source (90%) of anterior epistaxis.

 

Statement 3. Anterior nasal packing is easier to insert and less traumatic than balloon tamponade: Correct. Anterior nasal packing is simpler and less traumatic compared to balloon tamponade, which is reserved for special situations.

 

Statement 4. Trotter’s method is used as a first aid measure in epistaxis: Correct. Trotter’s method (sitting upright, leaning forward, mouth open) is the standard first-aid for epistaxis.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be given if anterior nasal packing is left for more than 48 hours: Incorrect. Antibiotics are needed if packing is left for more than 24 hours, not 48 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epistaxis is most often from Kiesselbach’s plexus, managed initially with Trotter’s method and anterior nasal packing; prophylactic antibiotics are required if packing exceeds 24 hours.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has had a persistent lesion on her face for the past 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed, and the histology is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

 

  • Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus (MCV, most commonly type 1) and is frequent in children. 
  • Histopathology shows a characteristic cup-shaped epidermal hyperplasia with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Henderson–Paterson bodies) in keratinocytes. 
  • Clinically, lesions are dome-shaped, pearly white, umbilicated papules, often on the face in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: SCC is a malignant neoplasm of keratinocytes, usually presenting as a hyperkeratotic nodule or ulcer. Histology shows atypical keratinocytes with keratin pearls and dysplasia—not the cup-shaped crater with inclusion bodies seen here.

 

Option B. Squamous papilloma with central crater: Squamous papilloma typically shows papillomatous projections with fibrovascular cores and hyperkeratosis. The absence of viral inclusion bodies differentiates it from molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Herpes zoster: Herpes zoster (shingles) presents with grouped vesicular lesions along a dermatomal distribution. Histology shows multinucleated giant cells and ballooning degeneration, not large intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by molluscum contagiosum virus, showing umbilicated papules clinically and cup-shaped epidermal invagination with Henderson–Paterson bodies histologically, distinguishing it from SCC, papillomas, and herpesvirus infections.

choices.text: Decreased sensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to hypoxia
Increased respiratory drive due to metabolic acidosis
Delayed detection of changes in blood CO₂ by central chemoreceptors
Increased lung stiffness leading to decreased tidal volume

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of advanced dilated cardiomyopathy is brought by her daughter because of episodes of abnormal breathing during the night. She is noted to have alternating cycles of deep, rapid breathing followed by complete pauses in respiration. On examination, she has bilateral basal lung crackles and elevated jugular venous pressure. Which of the following best explains the mechanism underlying this patient’s breathing pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delayed detection of changes in blood CO₂ by central chemoreceptors

 

  • This patient demonstrates Cheyne–Stokes respiration, characterized by cyclical hyperventilation followed by apnea. 
  • In chronic heart failure, reduced cardiac output delays blood flow from the lungs to the brain. 
  • This leads to a lag in CO₂ detection by the central chemoreceptors. 
  • The delayed feedback results in overcorrection: hyperventilation when CO₂ rises, followed by apnea when CO₂ falls too low, producing the waxing and waning breathing pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased sensitivity of the peripheral chemoreceptors to hypoxia: Incorrect. Peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to hypoxia, but they are not the primary cause of the cyclical breathing in Cheyne–Stokes respiration. The key defect lies in delayed CO₂ feedback, not hypoxic sensitivity.

 

Option B. Increased respiratory drive due to metabolic acidosis: Incorrect. Metabolic acidosis produces rapid and deep breathing (Kussmaul respiration), not the cyclic waxing and waning seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Increased lung stiffness leading to decreased tidal volume: Incorrect. Lung fibrosis or stiffness causes shallow, rapid breathing. It does not produce the alternating hyperventilation and apnea characteristic of Cheyne–Stokes respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cheyne–Stokes breathing is defined by alternating cycles of hyperventilation and apnea, most often seen in heart failure, and is caused by delayed detection of CO₂ changes by central chemoreceptors.

questions.text: A 2-day-old preterm infant develops generalized tonic–clonic seizures in the NICU. The neonate is unstable, and the treating team decides to perform an imaging study that can be done to identify the underlying pathology. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcranial ultrasound

 

  • Cranial ultrasonography is the investigation of choice in premature neonates with seizures.
  • It can be performed at the bedside, is non-invasive, and allows visualization of intraventricular hemorrhage, ischemia, hydrocephalus, and evolving lesions. 
  • This makes it ideal for unstable neonates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: Plain radiographs have no diagnostic value in neonatal seizures, as they cannot assess brain parenchyma, hemorrhage, or infarction.

 

Option B. CT Head: CT is useful in detecting hemorrhage or infarction but requires shifting the neonate to a scanner, which can be risky. Radiation exposure is another drawback, so it is considered adjunctive, not first-line.

 

Option C. MRI Brain: MRI provides superior structural detail and is excellent for diagnosing cortical malformations and subtle ischemic changes. However, it is impractical as an initial bedside tool in unstable neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred initial investigation for neonatal seizures, particularly in preterm infants, due to its bedside availability, safety, and effectiveness in detecting hemorrhagic and ischemic lesions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with breast cancer undergoes imaging that demonstrates metastasis to the internal mammary lymph nodes, without axillary spread. No distant metastasis is noted on staging workup. According to the TNM classification system, what is the N stage of her breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) N2b

 

N2b is spread to internal mammary LN alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N2a: Is ipsilateral fixed axillary LN spread.

 

Option C. N2c: Is not a part of the N stage in breast cancer.

 

Option D. N3a: Is spread to ipsilateral infra-clavicular LN.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Involvement of the internal mammary lymph nodes in breast cancer is classified as N2b and corresponds to stage IIIA/B of the TNM classification.

 

N staging of breast cancer

questions.text:
Which of the following are recognized early clinical features of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)?

 

  1. Sudden, painless vision loss
  2. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD)
  3. Photophobia and eye pain
  4. History of amaurosis fugax
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

  • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is an ophthalmic emergency characterized by sudden, profound, painless monocular vision loss. 

 

 

  • The key early clinical features include:

 

Statement 1. Sudden, painless vision loss: The hallmark presentation due to retinal ischemia.

 

Statement 2. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD): Common in CRAO due to profound loss of retinal function.

 

Statement 4. History of amaurosis fugax: Transient vision loss episodes caused by retinal emboli often precede a full-blown CRAO.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Photophobia and eye pain: Are not typical of CRAO; these are more indicative of anterior segment pathology like uveitis or acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CRAO presents with sudden, painless monocular vision loss, RAPD, and may be preceded by transient ischemic episodes (amaurosis fugax). 
  • Photophobia and pain are not features of retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

 

Statement 1: Lithium is excreted primarily by the kidneys and requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.

 

Statement 2: Thiazide diuretics increase serum lithium levels and may precipitate toxicity.

 

Statement 3: Lithium should be avoided during pregnancy, preferably, due to the risk of Ebstein’s anomaly.

 

Statement 4: Lithium reduces suicidality in patients with mood disorders.

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

  • Statement 1. Lithium is excreted primarily by the kidneys and requires dose adjustment in renal impairment: Correct. Lithium is renally excreted and must be used cautiously in patients with renal dysfunction.
  • Statement 2. Thiazide diuretics increase serum lithium levels and may precipitate toxicity: Correct. Thiazides causes hypo natremia. Thiazides reduce sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule, leading to increased lithium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, raising the risk of toxicity.
  • Statement 3. Lithium should be avoided during pregnancy, preferably, due to the risk of Ebstein’s anomaly: Correct. Lithium is teratogenic, especially in the first trimester, with a known association with Ebstein’s anomaly (tricuspid valve malformation).
  • Statement 4. Lithium reduces suicidality in patients with mood disorders: Correct. Lithium is the only mood stabilizer with anti-suicidal properties, especially in bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder with suicidality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium is a first-line mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder and treatment-resistant depression.
  • Renally excreted – avoid in renal failure; monitor serum levels regularly (target: 0.6–1.2 mEq/L).
  • Common adverse effects: Tremor, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and weight gain.
  • Narrow therapeutic index; toxicity >1.5 mEq/L (features: ataxia, confusion, seizures).
  • Teratogenic: causes Ebstein’s anomaly – avoid in 1st trimester of pregnancy.
  • Interacts with thiazides, NSAIDs, and ACE inhibitors – can raise lithium levels dangerously.
  • Unique property: Anti-suicidal effect among mood stabilizers.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking is diagnosed with metastatic colorectal cancer. Despite surgical resection of the primary tumor and multiple cycles of standard chemotherapy, repeat imaging shows progressive hepatic and pulmonary metastases. His oncologist recommends adding a monoclonal antibody therapy that works by binding vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A), thereby preventing new blood vessel formation and restricting tumor growth through inhibition of angiogenesis. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies best fits this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bevacizumab

 

  • This patient with metastatic colorectal cancer is being considered for therapy targeting angiogenesis.
  • Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF-A, a growth factor that stimulates angiogenesis. 
  • By neutralizing VEGF-A, bevacizumab reduces tumor vascular supply, slows metastatic progression, and enhances chemotherapy efficacy.
  • It is used in several metastatic cancers, including colorectal carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, and non-small cell lung cancer, as well as in wet age-related macular degeneration.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Trastuzumab: Targets the HER2/neu receptor (a tyrosine kinase). Used in HER2-positive breast cancer and HER2-positive gastric adenocarcinoma. It does not target VEGF-A.

 

Option C. Alemtuzumab: Targets CD52, leading to destruction of mature lymphocytes. Used in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and multiple sclerosis. Not an anti-angiogenic agent.

 

Option D. Daratumumab: Targets CD38 on plasma cells, inducing apoptosis. Used in multiple myeloma, not metastatic solid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds VEGF-A, inhibiting angiogenesis and reducing tumor vascularization in metastatic cancers such as colorectal carcinoma. 
  • Other monoclonal antibodies target different molecules (HER2, CD52, CD38) and are used in other malignancies.

questions.text: Match the following growth ratings with their Population Doubling Times:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a–2, b–3, c–4, d–1

 

  • a–2. Rapid growth corresponds to an Annual Growth Rate (AGR) of 1.0–1.5%, which leads to a population doubling time of 70–47 years.
  • b–3. Explosive growth (AGR 3.5–4%) is the fastest and results in the shortest doubling time of 20–18 years.
  • c–4. Stationary population indicates no growth, and thus, there is no doubling time — population size remains constant.
  • d–1. Slow growth (AGR <0.5%) has a population doubling time greater than 139 years, indicating minimal increase over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annual Growth Rate directly influences the population doubling time.

 

  • Higher AGR → shorter doubling time.
  • Stationary populations have no doubling time.
  • Explosive growth (AGR >3.5%) can double population in less than 20 years.

 

Relation between Annual Growth Rate (AGR) and Population Doubling Time

 

 

*India

questions.text:
Match the following immunodeficiency disorders in newborns and young infants (0–6 months) with their characteristic features: 

 

Column A – Diagnosis

 

  1. DiGeorge anomaly
  2. Leukocyte adhesion defect
  3. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)
  4. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  5. Hyper IgM syndrome

 

Column B – Features

 

  1. Delayed umbilical cord detachment, leukocytosis, recurrent infections
  2. Diarrhea, pneumonia, thrush, failure to thrive
  3. Hypocalcemia, heart disease, unusual facies
  4. Bloody stools, draining ears, eczema
  5. Mouth ulcers, neutropenia, recurrent infections
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1–c, 2–a, 3–b, 4–d, 5–e

 

1. DiGeorge anomaly → c. Hypocalcemia, heart disease, unusual facies: This disorder results from a 22q11.2 deletion causing thymic aplasia. Features include hypocalcemia (due to hypoparathyroidism), congenital heart disease, recurrent viral/fungal infections, and dysmorphic facies.

 

2. Leukocyte adhesion defect → a. Delayed umbilical cord detachment, leukocytosis, recurrent infections: Defective CD18 integrins impair leukocyte adhesion and migration. Hallmark features include delayed separation of the umbilical cord (>30 days), neutrophilia, and recurrent bacterial infections without pus formation.

 

3. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) → b. Diarrhea, pneumonia, thrush, failure to thrive: SCID is characterized by defective T- and B-cell function. Infants present with persistent infections, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, pneumonia, and growth failure, often requiring bone marrow transplantation.

 

4. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome → d. Bloody stools, draining ears, eczema: This X-linked disorder presents with the classic triad of thrombocytopenia (bloody diarrhea, petechiae), recurrent infections, and eczema.

 

5. Hyper IgM syndrome → e. Mouth ulcers, neutropenia, recurrent infections: Caused by defective CD40–CD40L signaling, preventing class switching. Children present with recurrent infections, mouth ulcers, and neutropenia, while IgM levels remain elevated with low IgG/IgA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary immunodeficiencies in infants present with distinctive clinical patterns—DiGeorge with hypocalcemia and heart defects, LAD with delayed cord separation, SCID with severe infections and failure to thrive, Wiskott–Aldrich with bleeding and eczema, and Hyper IgM with mouth ulcers and recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with chronic schizophrenia is brought to the psychiatry emergency by her sister. The patient is refusing all treatment, including food and medication, and is unable to make decisions regarding her care. The psychiatrist determines that she currently lacks mental capacity. According to the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA), 2017, who is legally empowered to make decisions on behalf of the patient regarding admission and treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nominated representative

 

  • Under the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA), 2017, when a person with mental illness (PMI) is found to lack mental capacity to make informed decisions regarding their care, the law permits a legally designated person—known as a Nominated Representative (NR)—to take decisions on behalf of the patient, including decisions regarding treatment and admission.
  • In the current scenario, the 42-year-old woman with chronic schizophrenia is refusing all forms of treatment, including food and medication, and has been assessed by the psychiatrist as incapable of making decisions—fulfilling the MHCA criteria for lack of capacity.
  • Therefore, the psychiatrist must involve the NR to act in the patient's best interest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treating psychiatrist: While the psychiatrist assesses capacity and provides clinical recommendations, they cannot take legal decisions on behalf of a patient who lacks capacity. The psychiatrist must seek consent from the NR.

 

Option B. Judicial magistrate: The magistrate may be involved in supported admissions under certain sections (e.g., 102), but not in routine decisions about treatment for a patient who already has an NR under the MHCA framework.

 

Option D. Medical superintendent of the hospital: The MS may oversee administrative operations but is not authorized to act as the NR or make personal healthcare decisions for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Involves ecological disruption and demands international aid
Causes more than 10 deaths in a localized setting
Requires a response that exceeds the capacity of the affected community
Must involve more than 30 people needing hospital treatment simultaneously

questions.text: According to WHO, what key criterion distinguishes a disaster from a routine public health emergency, especially in settings like the current floods in Himachal Pradesh?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Requires a response that exceeds the capacity of the affected community

 

  • According to the WHO, a disaster is defined as: “Any occurrence that causes damage, ecological disruption, loss of human life or deterioration of health and health services on a scale sufficient to warrant an extraordinary response from outside the affected community or area.”
  • The need for external support is the key feature distinguishing disasters from smaller-scale emergencies manageable with local resources.
  • This is particularly relevant in natural disasters like floods, where local health infrastructure is often overwhelmed and higher authorities or aid agencies must intervene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Involves ecological disruption and demands international aid: While ecological disruption can be a feature, international aid is not required for the definition. The emphasis is on external help, which can be local or national.

 

Option B. Causes more than 10 deaths in a localized setting: There's no specific death count threshold in the WHO definition. Even fewer deaths can be considered a disaster if it overwhelms local capacity.

 

Option D. Must involve more than 30 people needing hospital treatment simultaneously: This definition is derived from Colin Grant’s criteria, not WHO. While relevant, it is not the WHO-standard definition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“A situation is classified as a disaster by WHO when it overwhelms the local community’s ability to respond effectively and requires support from outside the affected area.”

questions.text: A 72-year-old man has had abdominal pain for the past year. Imaging with abdominal CT reveals a large 10-cm mass involving the pancreas. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma and shows inactivation of the SMAD4 gene. Which of the following regulatory pathways is most likely disrupted in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TGF-β

 

  • This 72-year-old man has a pancreatic adenocarcinoma with SMAD4 gene inactivation. SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a protein acting in the TGF-β (transforming growth factor-beta) signaling pathway.
  • Normally, TGF-β signaling via SMAD proteins inhibits cell proliferation by inducing cell cycle arrest. 
  • Loss or inactivation of SMAD4 disrupts this pathway, leading to uncontrolled cellular proliferation and progression of pancreatic cancer.
  • Thus, the regulatory pathway most likely altered in this patient is the TGF-β pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. β-catenin: β-catenin is a key effector in the Wnt signaling pathway, which plays a role in colorectal cancer via APC gene mutations. While important in colon carcinogenesis, it is not the mechanism described here, since the biopsy highlights SMAD4 loss in pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. MYC: MYC is a proto-oncogene that functions as a transcription factor promoting cell growth and proliferation. Mutations or amplification of MYC are implicated in cancers such as Burkitt lymphoma. It is not related to SMAD4 or pancreatic adenocarcinoma in this scenario.

 

Option D. BCL2: BCL2 is an anti-apoptotic gene, commonly overexpressed in follicular lymphoma due to the t(14;18) translocation. It prevents programmed cell death but is not linked to SMAD4 inactivation or pancreatic carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SMAD4 is a tumor suppressor gene that functions in the TGF-β signaling pathway. 
  • Inactivation of SMAD4 is a hallmark of pancreatic adenocarcinoma and leads to loss of growth inhibition and uncontrolled proliferation.

questions.text:
Risk factor(s) for Legg-calve-Perthe’s disease is/are: 

 

  1. Accelerated skeletal growth
  2. Growth hormone abnormalities
  3. Positive family history
  4. Female sex
  5. Passive smoking
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3, 5 

 

  • Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is a rare childhood condition that occurs when the blood supply to the femoral head is temporarily disrupted, causing the bone to die and collapse (avascular necrosis). 
  • The exact cause is unknown, but several risk factors are associated with it.
  • Statement 3. Positive family history: There is a genetic predisposition, with a positive family history increasing the risk.
  • Statement 5. Passive smoking: Studies have shown a strong association between passive smoking and the development of Perthes disease, likely due to its effect on blood vessels and coagulation.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Accelerated skeletal growth: Perthes disease is more common in children with delayed skeletal maturation and a lower height-for-age.

 

Statement 2. Growth hormone abnormalities: Growth hormone deficiencies and abnormalities have been linked to the disease, but the primary link is to delayed growth, not an excess.

 

Statement 4. Female sex: Perthes disease is much more common in males (approximately a 4:1 ratio).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The prognosis for Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is generally good, especially with early diagnosis and proper management. 
  • Most children recover completely, but the long-term outcome largely depends on several key factors.

choices.text: ABOi kidney transplant is not possible.
In a comprehensive database analysis, three-year graft survival was better for ABOi transplant.
ABOi kidney transplant is a new development in transplantation, and we do not have much information on outcomes.
Risk of infections and hemorrhagic complications is significantly higher in ABOi transplant.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ESRD due to diabetes, on hemodialysis for five years, is evaluated for a kidney transplant. His wife, willing to donate, is ABO-incompatible (patient: O positive, wife: A). They seek information on ABOi kidney transplant outcomes. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Risk of infections and hemorrhagic complications is significantly higher in ABOi transplant.

 

  • The patient’s blood group (O positive) and his wife’s (A) indicate ABO incompatibility, as O can only receive from O, while A can donate to A or AB. ABOi transplantation is feasible with desensitization protocols (e.g., plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab) to remove anti-A/B antibodies, a practice increasingly utilized since the 2000s.
