  • Data from the US Renal Data System and Medicare (2000–2007) on 119 ABOi transplant recipients show significantly higher risks compared to ABO-compatible recipients: 2.2-fold higher risk of pneumonia, 3.6-fold higher risk of wound infections, 56% higher risk of pyelonephritis, and nearly 2-fold higher risk of hemorrhage. These complications arise due to immunosuppression and desensitization-related immune activation, making this statement accurate.
  • Supporting Evidence: The increased infectious and hemorrhagic risks are attributed to intensified immunosuppression and antibody-mediated injury, a well-documented challenge in ABOi transplants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ABOi kidney transplant is not possible: False. ABOi kidney transplantation is possible and has been successfully performed since the early 2000s with desensitization protocols. It is an established option for incompatible donor-recipient pairs, contradicting this statement.

 

Option B. In a comprehensive database analysis, three-year graft survival was better for ABOi transplant: False. Comprehensive data (e.g., 1420 ABOi vs. ABO-matched living donor transplants from 2005–2012) show that three-year graft survival is identical, not better, for ABOi transplants compared to ABO-compatible ones, refuting this claim.

 

Option C. ABOi kidney transplant is a new development in transplantation, and we do not have much information on outcomes: False. ABOi transplantation has been practiced since the mid-2000s, with extensive data from 101 centers (1420 ABOi transplants) showing comparable graft and patient survival to ABO-matched transplants, indicating robust outcome information is available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ABOi kidney transplant carries a significantly higher risk of infections (pneumonia, wound infections, pyelonephritis) and hemorrhagic complications due to immunosuppression.
  • Three-year graft survival in ABOi transplants is equivalent to ABO-compatible transplants, not superior.
  • ABOi transplantation is an established procedure with extensive outcome data, feasible via desensitization since the 2000s.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and bilateral leg edema for 3 months. You are suspecting heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Which of the following is not a component of the H2FPEF score for diagnosing HFpEF?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ejection fraction

 

  • The patient’s presentation (dyspnea, fatigue, leg edema, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, LVEF 55%, diastolic dysfunction) is consistent with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), a condition characterized by heart failure symptoms with normal or near-normal LVEF (≥50%) and evidence of diastolic dysfunction. 
  • The H2FPEF score is a diagnostic tool to estimate the probability of HFpEF in patients with unexplained dyspnea, incorporating six weighted components: Heavy (BMI >30 kg/m², 2 points), Hypertension (≥2 antihypertensive medications, 1 point), Fibrillation (paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation, 3 points), Pulmonary hypertension (echocardiographic pulmonary artery systolic pressure >35 mmHg, 1 point), Elderly (age >60 years, 1 point), and Filling pressure (elevated E/e’ ratio >9 on echocardiography, 1 point). 
  • A score ≥6 indicates high probability of HFpEF.
  • Ejection fraction is not part of the H2FPEF score. While LVEF ≥50% is a diagnostic criterion for HFpEF itself, the H2FPEF score focuses on clinical and echocardiographic variables that predict HFpEF likelihood in ambiguous cases, not LVEF, which is already assumed to be preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Old age: Included. Age >60 years is a component of the H2FPEF score (1 point), as elderly patients are at higher risk for HFpEF due to age-related diastolic dysfunction. This patient, at 62 years, meets this criterion.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Included. Use of ≥2 antihypertensive medications is a component of the H2FPEF score (1 point), reflecting the strong association between chronic hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy/diastolic dysfunction in HFpEF. This patient’s history of hypertension likely contributes to her score.

 

Option C. Atrial fibrillation: Included. Paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation is a major component of the H2FPEF score (3 points), as it exacerbates diastolic dysfunction and contributes to heart failure symptoms. This patient’s atrial fibrillation is a key scoring factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Old age (>60 years) contributes 1 point to the H2FPEF score for HFpEF diagnosis.
  • Hypertension (≥2 antihypertensive medications) and atrial fibrillation (paroxysmal/persistent) are weighted components of the H2FPEF score.
  • Ejection fraction is not part of the H2FPEF score, though LVEF ≥50% defines HFpEF.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reversibly binds the site labelled as B in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ticagrelor

 

  • The figure shows a platelet activation and aggregation pathway involving the COX-1 enzyme, thromboxane, ADP, the P2Y12 receptor, and the GPIIb/IIIa receptor. 
  • The site labelled "B" is the P2Y12 receptor, which is targeted by antiplatelet drugs.
  • Ticagrelor is unique because it reversibly binds to the P2Y12 receptor.
  • Thus, the drug that reversibly binds the site labelled "B" (P2Y12 receptor) is ticagrelor.
  • Site A: The site labelled "A" in the figure corresponds to the COX-1 enzyme. COX-1 is responsible for the production of thromboxane A2, a potent promoter of platelet aggregation. The primary drug that targets this site is aspirin, which irreversibly inhibits COX-1, leading to a decrease in thromboxane A2 production and thus reduced platelet aggregation.
  • Site C: The site labelled "C" in the figure corresponds to the GPIIb/IIIa receptor. This receptor is crucial for platelet aggregation because it binds fibrinogen, which links platelets together. Drugs that target this receptor, known as GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors, include abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban. These drugs prevent fibrinogen binding to the GPIIb/IIIa receptor, thereby inhibiting platelet aggregation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B and D. Clopidogrel, Prasugrel, and Ticlopidine: Irreversibly bind to the P2Y12 receptor to inhibit ADP-induced platelet aggregation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the mechanisms of action of antiplatelet drugs is crucial for their effective use in preventing thrombotic events. 
  • Ticagrelor is a reversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist, which distinguishes it from other P2Y12 inhibitors like clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticlopidine, which bind irreversibly. 
  • Aspirin targets the COX-1 enzyme, reducing thromboxane A2 production, while GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors prevent platelet aggregation by blocking fibrinogen binding.

choices.text: The sympathetic nervous system is overactive.
This illness generally occurs only with advanced chronic kidney disease.
In going from supine to standing, heart rate will remain unchanged.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease currently on hemodialysis presents to your office for a follow-up visit. He reports a history of impotence, dyspepsia, and dizziness. Which of the following is true about his illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The sympathetic nervous system is overactive.

 

  • The patient’s ESRD, managed with hemodialysis, and symptoms (impotence, dyspepsia, dizziness) suggest complications of chronic kidney disease (CKD), potentially including uremic autonomic neuropathy. 
  • This condition affects the autonomic nervous system due to uremic toxins and is common in ESRD patients.
  • In uremic autonomic neuropathy, the sympathetic nervous system is overactive, while the parasympathetic nervous system is hypoactive. 
  • This imbalance contributes to symptoms like hypertension, dizziness (due to orthostatic instability), and autonomic dysfunction, aligning with the patient’s presentation.
  • Overactivity of the sympathetic nervous system is a well-documented feature in CKD, driven by uremic toxin accumulation and renal ischemia, exacerbating cardiovascular and autonomic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This illness generally occurs only with advanced chronic kidney disease: False. Uremic autonomic neuropathy can manifest early in the course of chronic renal failure, contrasting with uremic encephalopathy and uremic neuropathy, which typically occur with advanced disease (e.g., glomerular filtration rate <10 mL/min). The patient’s ESRD (advanced stage) supports this condition, but it is not exclusive to this stage.

 

Option C. In going from supine to standing, heart rate will remain unchanged: False. Patients with uremic autonomic neuropathy typically show a normal increase in heart rate when transitioning from supine to standing, as the sympathetic overactivity can still elicit a compensatory response, unlike in severe autonomic failure where the response is blunted.

 

Option D. Baroreceptor sensitivity remains normal: False. Uremic autonomic neuropathy is associated with impaired baroreceptor sensitivity, leading to poor regulation of blood pressure and contributing to dizziness and orthostatic hypotension, consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sympathetic nervous system overactivity characterizes uremic autonomic neuropathy in ESRD, contributing to symptoms like dizziness and impotence.
  • Uremic autonomic neuropathy can occur early in CKD, unlike uremic encephalopathy/neuropathy, which require advanced disease.
  • Impaired baroreceptor sensitivity and a normal heart rate increase on standing are typical findings in this condition

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with severe hypoxemic respiratory failure due to viral pneumonia is admitted to the ICU. Despite low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg IBW), FiO₂ 0.8, and PEEP 12 cm H₂O, his PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio remains <100 mmHg. The ICU team decides to change his position, as shown in the image, to optimize oxygenation while continuing invasive mechanical ventilation. This ventilation strategy is primarily indicated in the management of which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ARDS

 

  • The image shows a patient in prone positioning while receiving invasive mechanical ventilation. 
  • Prone ventilation is not a mode of ventilation but a supportive strategy used in severe ARDS to improve oxygenation when lung-protective ventilation fails. 
  • It improves gas exchange by reducing dorsal lung compression, redistributing perfusion, and reducing ventral-dorsal transpulmonary pressure differences. 
  • Clinical trials (e.g., PROSEVA) have shown a survival benefit in severe ARDS with prolonged prone ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. COPD: Patients with COPD usually benefit from noninvasive ventilation, controlled oxygen delivery, and permissive hypercapnia. Prone positioning is not standard management in COPD exacerbations, as their hypoxemia is not due to diffuse alveolar collapse as in ARDS.

 

Option C. Circulatory shock: Management of shock focuses on fluids, vasopressors, and treating the underlying cause. Prone positioning does not play a therapeutic role and may worsen hemodynamics due to increased intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Lung atelectasis: While body positioning can help in postoperative atelectasis, prone positioning is not the standard approach. Techniques like incentive spirometry, CPAP, and physiotherapy are more relevant. Prone ventilation is reserved for diffuse severe lung injury, not isolated atelectasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prone ventilation is a supportive strategy in severe ARDS to improve oxygenation when conventional lung-protective ventilation fails, by enhancing alveolar recruitment, reducing dorsal lung compression, and improving ventilation–perfusion matching.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought for evaluation due to delayed milestones, ataxic gait, seizures, and a happy demeanor characterized by frequent laughter. The child also has severe developmental delay and absence of speech. On examination, there is microcephaly and a prominent chin. Genetic testing demonstrates a deletion on chromosome 15q11–q13. Which of the following is the most likely genetic cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deletion of the maternal chromosome 15

 

  • This 3-year-old child presents with a triad of delayed milestones, ataxic gait, and seizures, together with a happy demeanor with frequent laughter.
  • Additional findings include severe developmental delay, absence of speech, microcephaly, and a prominent chin.
  • The key clue is the genetic testing revealing a deletion on chromosome 15q11–q13. 
  • When this deletion occurs on the maternal chromosome, the result is Angelman syndrome. 
  • Hallmark features include:
    • Severe intellectual disability and developmental delay
    • Seizures
    • Ataxia
    • A happy/excitable disposition, often described as frequent inappropriate laughter (“happy puppet” phenotype)
    • Microcephaly and craniofacial findings (e.g., prominent chin)
  • By contrast, a paternal deletion in the same region results in Prader–Willi syndrome (characterized by hypotonia, obesity, and hypogonadism). 
  • Thus, the most likely genetic cause of the observed features is deletion of the maternal chromosome 15.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy of chromosome 21: Presents with hypotonia in infancy, intellectual disability, characteristic facies (upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds), single palmar crease, congenital heart disease (AV canal), and increased risk of leukemia/Alzheimer disease—not the happy demeanor with laughter, ataxia, and seizures classically tied to maternal 15q11–q13 deletion.

 

Option B. Mutation in the FMR1 gene: This mutation causes Fragile X syndrome, the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. Clinical findings include macroorchidism, long face, large ears, and developmental delay. However, ataxia, frequent laughter, and maternal chromosome 15q11–q13 deletion are not features of Fragile X.

 

Option D. Deletion of the paternal chromosome 15: A paternal deletion in chromosome 15q11–q13 causes Prader–Willi syndrome, presenting with neonatal hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, short stature, and hypogonadism. The described features (frequent laughter, ataxia, seizures, microcephaly) fit Angelman syndrome, which arises from the maternal deletion, not the paternal one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angelman syndrome results from a maternal deletion on chromosome 15q11–q13 and presents with developmental delay, seizures, ataxia, microcephaly, and a happy disposition with frequent laughter.

questions.text: From the given pressure–volume loop of the left ventricle, calculate the ejection fraction (EF):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 66%

 

  • To calculate ejection fraction (EF), use the formula:

 

 

  • From the PV loop:
    • EDV (End-Diastolic Volume) = ~150 mL (point 1 on the loop — when the ventricle is full)
    • ESV (End-Systolic Volume) = ~50 mL (point 2 on the loop — after contraction) 
  • Now, stroke volume is to be calculated by:

 

 

  • Interpretation of Loop Points:
    • Point 1 → 2: Isovolumetric contraction
    • Point 2 → 3: Ejection phase
    • Point 3 → 4: Isovolumetric relaxation
    • Point 4 → 1: Filling phase

This value is within the normal range (55–70%) and shows effective ventricular contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ejection fraction is calculated as stroke volume divided by end-diastolic volume. 
  • From the loop (EDV = 150 mL, ESV = 50 mL), EF = 66%.

choices.text: Ulnar nerve injury at the cubital tunnel
Ulnar nerve injury at the arcade of Struthers
Ulnar nerve injury at Guyon’s canal

questions.text: A 52-year-old person with long-standing diabetes develops progressive weakness of hand grip. Exam shows clawing of the ring and little fingers and hollowing of the hypothenar eminence. Wrist flexion strength is normal, and sensation over the dorsal ulnar hand is preserved. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve injury at Guyon’s canal 

 

  • The presentation localizes to a distal ulnar nerve lesion at Guyon’s canal:
    • Clawing of digits 4–5 with hypothenar wasting → intrinsic hand muscle denervation.
    • Normal wrist flexion → flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) intact.
    • Preserved DIP flexion of digits 4–5 → ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus intact.
    • No dorsal sensory loss → dorsal cutaneous branch of ulnar nerve spared (branches proximal to canal).
  • These findings indicate the lesion is distal to FCU/FDP branches but proximal to palmar sensory branches, i.e., at Guyon’s canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve injury at the cubital tunnel: Proximal lesion that weakens FCU and ulnar FDP, leading to impaired wrist/DIP flexion and dorsal sensory loss. The patient's intact wrist flexion and preserved dorsal sensation rule this out.

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve injury at the arcade of Struthers: A proximal compression site above the medial epicondyle; would cause weakness of FCU/FDP and dorsal sensory loss, which are not present here.

 

Option D. C8 radiculopathy: Would affect multiple nerve distributions (including median-innervated muscles) and cause sensory changes along the medial forearm and hand, not isolated ulnar motor deficits with preserved dorsal sensation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guyon’s canal syndrome presents with ulnar claw and hypothenar wasting while sparing FCU, ulnar FDP, and dorsal ulnar hand sensation because the lesion occurs distal to motor/sensory branches supplying those areas.

questions.text: Russell-Silver syndrome is a rare growth disorder characterized by severe intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal short stature, and characteristic dysmorphic features. Which of the following genetic mechanisms is most commonly associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uniparental disomy

 

  • Russell-Silver syndrome is strongly associated with maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 7. 
  • This means both copies of chromosome 7 come from the mother, leading to disrupted genomic imprinting and abnormal growth regulation. 
  • Other imprinting disorders include Prader-Willi, Angelman, and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal inheritance: The syndrome is not transmitted via a straightforward autosomal dominant or recessive pattern. Familial cases are extremely rare.

 

Option B. X-linked inheritance: There is no X-linked basis for Russell-Silver syndrome; both genders are affected equally.

 

Option C. Sporadic gene mutation: Although some epigenetic alterations and rare chromosomal abnormalities have been reported, sporadic single-gene mutations are not the main mechanism in Russell-Silver syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Russell-Silver syndrome is an imprinting disorder most often caused by maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 7, highlighting the role of genomic imprinting in growth regulation.

choices.text: The swelling should be operated on after the child turns two years of age with mesh
The swelling lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle
It develops due to a patent processus vaginalis
It contains the intestine inside the sac

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with a swelling in the right groin that becomes prominent while crying. On gentle reduction of the swelling, a characteristic gurgling sound is heard. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The swelling should be operated on after the child turns two years of age with mesh

 

  • Inguinal hernias should be operated promptly due to risk of strangulation. Waiting till 2 years of age is not recommended. 
  • Mesh repair is not required and herniotomy is sufficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The swelling lies above and medial to pubic tubercle: This is correct. An indirect inguinal hernia always lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle, following the path of the inguinal canal. This anatomical relationship helps distinguish it from femoral hernias, which lie below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

 

Option C. It develops due to a patent processus vaginalis: This is correct. In children, indirect inguinal hernia occurs due to failure of closure of the processus vaginalis, allowing abdominal contents to protrude into the inguinal canal or scrotum. This embryological defect is the hallmark of pediatric inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. It contains the intestine inside the sac: This is correct because the gurgling sound on reduction strongly indicates that the hernia sac contains bowel loops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In children, an indirect inguinal hernia results from a patent processus vaginalis, lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle, and often contains bowel that produces a gurgling sound on reduction. 
  • Inguinal hernias should be operated promptly due to risk of strangulation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with low back pain radiating down her left leg to the foot. She has numbness in the dorsum of her foot and weakness in Extensor Hallucis Longus. What nerve root is most likely compressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L5

 

  • The L5 nerve root controls EHL muscle and is responsible for sensation on the dorsum of the foot. 
  • The radiating pain that follows the path of this nerve is often called sciatica. 
  • All these symptoms are present in the patient's case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. S1: An S1 nerve root compression would typically cause a loss of sensation on the lateral side of the foot and weakness in plantar flexion, which is tested by asking the patient to walk on their tiptoes.

 

Option C. L4: L4 nerve root compression can cause pain and numbness along the medial side of the leg and foot. It can also cause weakness in ankle dorsiflexion and the quadriceps muscle, which may be apparent when squatting. 

 

Option D. L3: L3 nerve root compression affects the sensation in the anterior thigh and medial knee and can cause weakness in the hip flexors and knee extensors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognized by low back pain radiating down the leg, numbness in the top of the foot, and weakness in ankle dorsiflexion, all pointing to compression of the L5 nerve root.

questions.text: A mother brings her child for a routine developmental checkup. On observation, the child is able to copy a circle on paper and builds a tower of seven cubes without assistance. Based on these developmental milestones, what is the most likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 years

 

  • At 3 years, a child is expected to copy a circle and build a tower of 9 cubes (7–9 cubes is within range). 
  • Other fine motor milestones at this age include dressing with help and improved hand–eye coordination. 
  • Gross motor milestones include riding a tricycle and climbing stairs with alternate feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: By 12 months, a child achieves a mature pincer grasp, stands without support, and says 1–2 meaningful words. They cannot yet copy shapes or build tall block towers—only small towers (2–3 blocks by 15–18 months).

 

Option B. 2 years: At 2 years, children can build a tower of 6 cubes and make vertical and circular scribbles. They can also undress themselves and walk up stairs with two feet per step. However, they are still too young to copy a circle correctly.

 

Option C. 2 ½ years: Around 2½ years, a child may build slightly taller block structures (6–7 blocks), but the ability to accurately copy a circle is not seen until about 3 years. At this age, language development is still at the stage of short 2–3 word sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copying a circle and building a tower of 7–9 cubes are developmental milestones achieved at approximately 3 years of age.

 

DEVELOPMENTAL MILESTONES:

 

Gross Motor

 

 

Fine Motor

 

 

Social and Adaptive

 

 

Language

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is being planned in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post-placental intra-uterine device insertion

 

  • The kit in the image shows the long placental (Kelly/ring) forceps used to grasp and guide a Copper-T to the fundus within 10 minutes of placental delivery—the defining steps of post-placental intra-uterine device insertion. 
  • This immediate postpartum technique does not use the standard plastic inserter, uterine sound, or tenaculum; instead, the IUCD is placed from the vaginal side with the long forceps to achieve high fundal placement and reduce expulsion.
  • The question stem’s clues—vaginal birth, immediate timing, long forceps, device advanced to fundus—match post-placental intra-uterine device insertion, not interval, intra-cesarean, or post-abortal settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interval intra-uterine device insertion: Incorrect. “Interval” placement is performed weeks after delivery (typically ≥4–6 weeks) in a clinic setting using the standard IUCD inserter, cervical stabilization with a tenaculum, and uterine sounding—not a long placental/ring forceps as shown.

 

Option C. Intra-cesarean intra-uterine device insertion. Incorrect. In intra-cesarean intra-uterine device insertion, the IUCD is placed through the uterine incision during cesarean delivery, often by hand or with forceps from the abdominal side; the bedside vaginal kit in the image does not correspond to this technique.

 

Option D. Post-abortal intra-uterine device insertion: Incorrect. Post-abortal insertion (after suction evacuation) typically uses the standard IUCD inserter once the uterus is empty and is not characterized by the immediate postpartum placental setting or the use of long placental forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-placental IUCD insertion is identified by immediate postpartum timing and use of long placental/ring forceps to place the device at the uterine fundus through the vagina within minutes after placental delivery.

questions.text:
Regarding the branches of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3):

 

  1. The auriculotemporal nerve (ATN) arises from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.
  2. The buccal nerve is derived from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve.
  3. The medial pterygoid muscle is supplied directly by a branch from the main trunk of the mandibular nerve.
  4. The posterior division of the mandibular nerve contains only sensory branches.
  5. The anterior division of the mandibular nerve is primarily motor, except for the buccal nerve which is sensory.

 

Which of the above statements are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4

 

Statement 1. The auriculotemporal nerve (ATN) arises from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve (ATN) is indeed a branch of the posterior division, not the anterior. Hence this statement is false. (Wait we must check correctness carefully)

 

 

Statement 2. The buccal nerve is derived from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve: Incorrect. The buccal nerve is from the anterior division (sensory), not posterior.

 

Statement 4. The posterior division of the mandibular nerve contains only sensory branches: Incorrect. The posterior division is mainly sensory (auriculotemporal, lingual, inferior alveolar) but does have a motor branch (nerve to mylohyoid). Hence not exclusively sensory.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 3. The medial pterygoid muscle is supplied directly by a branch from the main trunk of the mandibular nerve: Correct. The medial pterygoid muscle receives its nerve directly from the main trunk before the mandibular nerve divides.

 

Statement 5. The anterior division of the mandibular nerve is primarily motor, except for the buccal nerve which is sensory: Correct. The anterior division is largely motor to muscles of mastication, except the buccal nerve, which is sensory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The buccal nerve arises from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve (sensory), the medial pterygoid is innervated from the main trunk, and the posterior division is predominantly—but not exclusively—sensory (nerve to mylohyoid is motor).

choices.text: Presence of mecC gene encoding PBP2c with sequence divergence
Hyperproduction of β-lactamase causing false resistance
Modification of mecA gene by IS1272 insertion element
Expression of mecB gene from Macrococcus species

questions.text: A clinical microbiology laboratory receives a S. aureus isolate showing oxacillin resistance but tests negative for mecA gene by PCR. The isolate shows positive results with PBP2a latex agglutination test. What is the most likely explanation for this discrepancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of mecC gene encoding PBP2c with sequence divergence 

 

  • Oxacillin resistance is β lactam resistance  
  • mecC gene (formerly mecALGA251) was discovered in 2011 and shows only 70% nucleotide sequence identity with mecA, causing false-negative results with mecA-specific PCR primers. 
  • However, mecC encodes a PBP2a variant (sometimes called PBP2c) that cross-reacts with anti-PBP2a antibodies in latex agglutination tests, giving positive results. 
  • mecC-MRSA strains are found in <1% of human MRSA isolates but are more common in livestock-associated MRSA. 
  • These strains typically carry SCCmec type XI and are often missed by routine mecA PCR. 
  • Laboratories should use primers detecting both mecA and mecC or perform phenotypic testing for comprehensive MRSA detection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperproduction of β-lactamase causing false resistance: β-lactamase hyperproduction causes borderline resistance but wouldn't give positive PBP2a latex test

 

Option C. Modification of mecA gene by IS1272 insertion element: IS1272 insertion might affect mecA expression but wouldn't cause PCR negativity with intact primers

 

Option D. Expression of mecB gene from Macrococcus species: mecB is found in Macrococcus but doesn't naturally occur in S. aureus

 

Educational Objective: 

 

mecC gene encodes PBP2c causing methicillin resistance with negative mecA PCR but positive PBP2a latex agglutination due to cross-reactivity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is started on a medication that alters the activity of key metabolic enzymes in his liver by adding or removing phosphate groups. These changes in enzyme activity occur rapidly without altering the amount of enzyme present. Which of the following mechanisms best describes this form of regulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Covalent modification

 

  • The enzyme regulation via phosphorylation (addition of phosphate) or dephosphorylation (removal of phosphate). 
  • This is a form of covalent modification, where a functional group is added to or removed from an enzyme through a covalent bond, resulting in a reversible change in enzyme activity.
  • Phosphorylation is carried out by kinases, while dephosphorylation is mediated by phosphatases.
  • This process does not change the concentration of the enzyme; it changes its activity.
  • Covalent modification is a rapid and reversible regulatory mechanism, critical in pathways like glycogen metabolism, gluconeogenesis, and signal transduction.
  • Depending on the enzyme, phosphorylation may activate (e.g., glycogen phosphorylase) or inhibit (e.g., glycogen synthase) its activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allosteric inhibition: Incorrect. In allosteric inhibition, a molecule binds to a site other than the active site, causing a conformational change in the enzyme. It does not involve the formation or breaking of covalent bonds (e.g., phosphate linkage) and is independent of phosphorylation/dephosphorylation.

 

Option B. Repression: Incorrect. Repression is a genetic regulation process in which the synthesis of an enzyme is decreased at the transcriptional level. It changes enzyme amount, not immediate activity, and does not involve phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Competitive inhibition: Incorrect. Competitive inhibitors bind reversibly to the active site of an enzyme, competing with the substrate. This is a non-covalent process and does not involve phosphate group addition or removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphorylation and dephosphorylation regulate enzyme activity through covalent modification, a rapid, reversible process that alters enzyme activity without changing enzyme concentration.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, bone pain, and recurrent infections. Laboratory studies show elevated serum calcium, anemia, and renal impairment. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike, and bone marrow biopsy demonstrates >10% clonal plasma cells. He is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a chemotherapeutic regimen that includes a first-generation proteasome inhibitor administered by intravenous infusion. Which of the following drugs was most likely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bortezomib

 

  • Bortezomib is a first-generation proteasome inhibitor, administered intravenously (or subcutaneously).
  • It works by inhibiting the 26S proteasome, leading to accumulation of misfolded proteins and apoptosis of malignant plasma cells.
  • It is a cornerstone in multiple myeloma therapy, often combined with lenalidomide or dexamethasone.
  • Side effects include peripheral neuropathy and myelosuppression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Melphalan: It is an alkylating agent, also used in multiple myeloma, but not a proteasome inhibitor as described in the question.

 

Option B. Imatinib: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting BCR-ABL, used in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Lenalidomide: An immunomodulatory drug (IMiD) used in multiple myeloma, but not a proteasome inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bortezomib is a first-generation proteasome inhibitor given by intravenous infusion, used primarily in the treatment of multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma.

choices.text: By promoting calcium absorption in the intestines
By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion
By enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism. Laboratory analysis shows elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). The accompanying graph shows changes in plasma calcium and phosphate levels after administration of PTH. Which of the following mechanisms explains how PTH increases plasma calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion 

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a key regulator of calcium and phosphate levels in the blood.
  • When PTH is released, it works through several mechanisms to increase plasma calcium levels. 
  • The following processes are involved:
    1. Bone resorption: PTH stimulates osteoclasts (cells responsible for breaking down bone) and inhibits osteoblasts (cells responsible for bone formation). This increases the release of calcium from bones into the bloodstream.
    2. Kidney function: PTH increases calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, reducing the amount of calcium excreted in the urine. Simultaneously, PTH increases phosphate excretion in the urine (to help maintain a balance in the blood).
    3. Intestinal absorption: PTH indirectly increases calcium absorption from the intestine by enhancing the activation of vitamin D in the kidneys, which then boosts calcium absorption in the intestines.
  • PTH directly increases osteoclastic activity (bone resorption) and reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys.
  • These actions are the primary mechanisms through which PTH raises plasma calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By stimulating osteoblastic activity: This is incorrect because PTH actually inhibits osteoblastic (bone-forming) activity and stimulates osteoclastic (bone-resorbing) activity to release calcium from bones.

 

Option B. By promoting calcium absorption in the intestines: Although PTH indirectly increases intestinal calcium absorption via vitamin D activation, this is not the primary mechanism. The primary effect of PTH is on bone resorption and kidney calcium reabsorption.

 

Option D. By enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine: This is incorrect because PTH decreases phosphate levels in the blood by promoting its excretion in the urine, not by enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTH's main action to increase plasma calcium levels is through increasing osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is admitted to the ICU following a road traffic accident and requires prolonged ventilatory support. The surgical team places a tracheostomy tube. Which of the following is the correct name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube

 

  • This device is designed like a regular cuffed tracheostomy tube but incorporates a suction port above the cuff. 
  • Its purpose is to aspirate pharyngeal secretions that collect above the cuff, thereby preventing aspiration into the trachea during cuff deflation. 
  • It is especially valuable in patients at high risk of aspiration, such as those on long-term ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fuller’s tracheostomy tube: Fuller’s tube is a metal double-cannula tracheostomy tube, often used in earlier practice. It lacks a cuff and suction mechanism, making it unsuitable for preventing aspiration in ventilated patients.

 

 

Option B. Jackson’s tracheostomy tube: Jackson’s tube is another metal tracheostomy tube, often uncuffed, mainly used for maintaining an airway but not for mechanical ventilation. It cannot provide aspiration protection since it lacks a cuff and suction channel.

 

 

Option C. Cuffed tracheostomy tube: A cuffed tracheostomy tube provides airway protection by sealing the trachea and preventing aspiration during ventilation. However, it does not have an additional suction channel to clear secretions above the cuff, which is the distinguishing feature of the suction-aid design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube combines the airway-sealing function of a cuff with an extra suction channel above it, reducing the risk of aspiration by allowing clearance of pooled secretions before cuff deflation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with mild hemorrhage following a road traffic accident. To assess the hemodynamic changes, his cardiac function is analyzed using the Frank–Starling curve, which plots cardiac output against central venous pressure. At baseline, his heart is functioning at point X. Considering the reduction in preload caused by blood loss and the compensatory increase in sympathetic activity, to which point is the stroke volume most likely to shift?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Point A

 

  • Mild hemorrhage leads to reduced preload due to decreased venous return. 
  • The body responds by activating the sympathetic nervous system, which increases contractility and heart rate. 
  • This compensation shifts the Frank–Starling curve upward, maintaining cardiac output despite reduced preload. The new equilibrium is represented by Point A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Point B: Incorrect. Point B reflects an increase in preload, which is the opposite of what occurs in hemorrhage. Since blood volume is reduced, preload cannot increase in this scenario.

 

Option C. Point C: Incorrect. Point C represents an excessive increase in contractility beyond what is typically expected in mild hemorrhage. It overestimates the physiological response.

 

Option D. Point E: Incorrect. Point E indicates decreased contractility, which contradicts the expected sympathetic response. Hemorrhage stimulates increased contractility, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mild hemorrhage reduces preload, but sympathetic compensation increases contractility, shifting the stroke volume to Point A on the Frank–Starling curve.

choices.text: Commissural fusion and scarring due to prior group A streptococcal infection
Large, friable vegetations that frequently embolize and destroy valves
Vegetations composed of immune complexes that may occur on either side of the valve leaflets
Small sterile vegetations limited to the lines of valve closure in hypercoagulable states

questions.text: A patient with a known history of systemic lupus erythematosus is found at autopsy to have sterile valvular involvement consistent with Libman-Sacks endocarditis. Which of the following best characterizes this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vegetations composed of immune complexes that may occur on either side of the valve leaflets

 

  • The patient had a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and was found at autopsy to have sterile valvular involvement, which is consistent with Libman-Sacks endocarditis. 
  • This condition is characterized by:
    • Sterile vegetations made up of immune complexes, fibrin, and inflammatory cells
    • They can form on either side of valve leaflets, chordae tendineae, or endocardial surfaces
    • Most often involve the mitral and aortic valves
    • Typically do not embolize and are usually clinically silent
    • Occur in about 4% of patients with SLE
  • Thus, the correct answer is that these vegetations are immune complex–mediated and may appear on either side of the valve leaflets.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commissural fusion and scarring due to prior group A streptococcal infection: This describes rheumatic heart disease, which causes chronic valvular deformity, fusion of commissures, and shortened chordae. While the patient’s background shows old rheumatic changes, the valve vegetations in SLE are specifically Libman-Sacks endocarditis, not rheumatic disease.

 

Option B. Large, friable vegetations that frequently embolize and destroy valves: This is typical of infective endocarditis, caused by bacterial or fungal infection. Unlike Libman-Sacks, these vegetations are infectious, destructive, and embolic.

 

Option D. Small sterile vegetations limited to the lines of valve closure in hypercoagulable states: This describes Marantic endocarditis or nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), often linked to malignancy or chronic wasting disease. In contrast, Libman-Sacks vegetations occur in SLE, and are not confined to the lines of closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Libman-Sacks endocarditis occurs in systemic lupus erythematosus and is characterized by sterile vegetations composed of immune complexes that may occur on either side of valve leaflets or endocardial surfaces.

choices.text: Frequent involvement of mesenteric and Waldeyer’s ring lymph nodes
Localized nodal disease, often without mediastinal involvement
Extranodal involvement with early dissemination to the spleen

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a painless enlarged cervical lymph node. An excisional biopsy of the node is shown below. Which of the following best describes the pattern of lymph node involvement in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Localized nodal disease, often without mediastinal involvement

 

  • The patient is a 42-year-old woman with a painless enlarged cervical lymph node. The biopsy image provided demonstrates histological findings consistent with Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL).
  • NLPHL is characterized by LP (“popcorn”) cells surrounded by a nodular background of small lymphocytes, and an immunophenotype of CD20+, CD30−, CD15−, and BCL6+. 
  • This immunoprofile distinguishes NLPHL from classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • The pattern of lymph node involvement in NLPHL is typically localized disease, most often affecting cervical or axillary lymph nodes, with minimal or absent mediastinal involvement. 
  • Compared with classical Hodgkin lymphoma, which spreads contiguously through lymphatic chains, NLPHL tends to remain localized and follow an indolent course.
  • Therefore, the best description of the lymph node involvement is localized nodal disease, often without mediastinal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frequent involvement of mesenteric and Waldeyer’s ring lymph nodes: This pattern is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphomas, particularly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma or other extranodal variants. NLPHL typically involves peripheral nodes (cervical/axillary) and not mesenteric nodes or Waldeyer’s ring.

 

Option C. Extranodal involvement with early dissemination to the spleen: Extranodal spread with early dissemination is also a hallmark of non-Hodgkin lymphomas, not NLPHL. In NLPHL, disease is usually nodal and localized at presentation, with a slow progression.

 

Option D. Contiguous spread through lymphatic chains: This describes the classical spread of classical Hodgkin lymphoma, which characteristically progresses from one lymph node group to the next adjacent group. NLPHL does not follow this stepwise contiguous pattern and more commonly shows isolated localized nodal disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) is distinguished by LP (“popcorn”) cells with CD20+, CD30−, CD15−, and BCL6+ phenotype, and typically presents with localized nodal disease, often without mediastinal involvement.

choices.text: Increase tidal volume to improve ventilation
Decrease tidal volume to improve ventilation
Switch to high-frequency oscillatory ventilation immediately
Increase plateau pressure goal above 40 cm H₂O for better oxygenation

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with severe community-acquired pneumonia is admitted to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. He is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His height is 175 cm (69 inches) and weight is 95 kg. The intensivist plans to use a lung-protective ventilation strategy. After calculating his predicted body weight, the team sets an initial tidal volume of 10 mL/kg IBW. Thirty minutes later, his plateau pressure is measured at 32 cm H₂O. Which of the following is the next best step according to ARDSnet lung-protective ventilation protocol?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease tidal volume to improve ventilation

 

  • ARDSnet recommends lung-protective ventilation using low tidal volumes (4–8 mL/kg predicted body weight) and keeping plateau pressure ≤30 cm H₂O. 
  • Since this patient’s plateau pressure is >30 cm H₂O, the tidal volume should be reduced to 4–8 mL/kg IBW, even if permissive hypercapnia occurs, to minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase tidal volume to improve ventilation: Increasing tidal volume would raise plateau pressure further, worsening volutrauma and barotrauma. Although ventilation might improve transiently, this contradicts lung-protective strategy and increases mortality risk.

 

Option C. Switch to high-frequency oscillatory ventilation immediately: HFOV is not first-line and has not shown mortality benefit in large ARDS trials. It is only considered in refractory hypoxemia unresponsive to optimized lung-protective ventilation and adjuncts such as prone positioning.

 

Option D. Increase plateau pressure goal above 40 cm H₂O for better oxygenation: Permitting higher plateau pressures worsens barotrauma risk and is contraindicated. The recommended plateau pressure threshold is ≤30 cm H₂O; higher pressures are only cautiously considered in very obese or stiff chest wall cases, not as the first step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ARDSnet protocol advocates tidal volumes of 4–8 mL/kg predicted body weight and plateau pressures ≤30 cm H₂O; when plateau pressure exceeds 30, tidal volume must be reduced to 4–6 mL/kg IBW to minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Amphetamines can cause hypertension and tachycardia due to peripheral sympathetic stimulation.


Reason (R): They directly stimulate beta-2 adrenergic receptors in vascular smooth muscle.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false.

 

  • Assertion (A) is true: Amphetamines are central and peripheral sympathomimetic agents. They increase the release of norepinephrine and dopamine, leading to alpha-1–mediated vasoconstriction and beta-1–mediated tachycardia, thus causing hypertension and tachycardia.
  • Reason (R) is false: Beta-2 adrenergic receptors, when stimulated, cause vasodilation in vascular smooth muscle—not vasoconstriction. Therefore, stimulation of beta-2 receptors would actually reduce blood pressure, not raise it. Thus, the reason does not support the assertion and is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amphetamine-induced hypertension is due to alpha-1 vasoconstriction, not beta-2 activity.
  • Beta-2 receptors promote vasodilation, not increased blood pressure.
  • Clinical signs of amphetamine overdose include tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, and mydriasis.

choices.text: The serum ammonia level correlates with the severity of hepatic encephalopathy.
The diagnosis is made by electroencephalograph.
Precipitants for this condition are present in over 80% of patients.
TIPS placement is a second-line treatment.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with cirrhosis associated with hepatitis C infection is evaluated for confusion. Examination reveals asterixis, ascites, and a sweet odor to his breath. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precipitants for this condition are present in over 80% of patients.

 

  • The patient’s cirrhosis (from hepatitis C), confusion, asterixis (flapping tremor), ascites, and fetor hepaticus (sweet breath odor due to dimethyl sulfide) are classic features of hepatic encephalopathy (HE), a brain dysfunction caused by liver insufficiency and portosystemic shunting. HE is graded by the West Haven criteria (I–IV), with this presentation suggesting at least grade II.
  • Precipitants (e.g., infection, gastrointestinal bleeding, electrolyte imbalances, constipation, medications like benzodiazepines, or portosystemic shunt) are identified in over 80% of HE cases. 
  • Identifying and treating these (e.g., antibiotics for infection, lactulose for ammonia reduction) is the mainstay of management, supporting this statement.
  • The high prevalence of precipitants underscores the multifactorial nature of HE, making their detection and correction critical for effective treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The serum ammonia level correlates with the severity of hepatic encephalopathy: False. Serum ammonia levels are elevated in HE but do not reliably correlate with disease severity, as clinical symptoms and West Haven grades are better indicators. Ammonia reduction (e.g., with lactulose) is therapeutic, but levels alone are not diagnostic or prognostic.

 

Option B. The diagnosis is made by electroencephalograph: False. HE is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on history (cirrhosis) and findings (confusion, asterixis, fetor hepaticus). Electroencephalography (EEG) shows nonspecific slowing (e.g., theta/delta waves) in advanced stages but is not diagnostic; it may support severity assessment.

 

Option D. TIPS placement is a second-line treatment: False. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is not a treatment for HE; it is used for variceal bleeding or refractory ascites. TIPS can worsen HE by increasing portosystemic shunting, and in refractory cases, shunt reduction/occlusion may be considered, contradicting this statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Precipitants are identified in over 80% of hepatic encephalopathy cases, guiding primary treatment with lactulose and precipitant correction.
  • Serum ammonia levels do not correlate with HE severity; diagnosis relies on clinical findings, not EEG.
  • TIPS placement can exacerbate HE and is not a therapeutic option for this condition.

choices.text: It uses retrospective data only without follow-up
Cohort is selected after disease develops
Only cases and controls are assessed for expensive testing
Baseline interviews are conducted after diagnosis

questions.text: All of the following statements about the structure of a Nested Case-Control study are incorrect, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only cases and controls are assessed for expensive testing

 

  • Nested Case-Control Study, a hybrid design that combines the strengths of cohort and case-control methodologies. 
  • It is especially useful in situations where biological or genetic tests are expensive.
  • In this design, baseline data is collected at the start of the cohort study, and subjects are followed over time.
  • When cases of the disease develop, they are matched with controls from the same cohort, and only these individuals undergo further expensive testing (e.g., genetic, biomarker, etc.).
  • Thus, option C is correct (i.e., the only statement that is NOT incorrect).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses retrospective data only without follow-up: Is incorrect. Nested case-control studies are not purely retrospective. They involve prospective follow-up from baseline to the occurrence of disease.

 

Option B. Cohort is selected after disease develops: Is incorrect: The cohort is defined before the disease develops; the whole idea is to follow exposure-to-outcome.

 

Option D. Baseline interviews are conducted after diagnosis: Is incorrect: Data collection (including interviews and biological samples) is done at baseline, i.e., before the disease develops, reducing recall bias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nested Case-Control studies are efficient, cost-effective designs conducted within a cohort, where only cases and matched controls undergo expensive diagnostic testing, and baseline data is already available — minimizing recall bias and maintaining temporal validity.

choices.text: Patients have the right to request deletion of their digital medical records under specific conditions
Health records collected for one scheme can be automatically reused for another without fresh consent
Public hospitals must notify authorities and affected individuals in case of a health data breach
The scope of the law includes telemedicine platforms used in public health interventions

questions.text: A government hospital participating in the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM) initiates digital record-keeping for patients enrolled under a maternal health scheme. Later, the hospital administrator plans to use this data for a non-communicable disease screening program. As per the Digital Personal Data Protection (DPDP) Act, 2023, all of the following statements about such practices are consistent with the law, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health records collected for one scheme can be automatically reused for another without fresh consent

 

  • Under the DPDP Act 2023, data collected for a specific purpose (e.g., maternal health program) cannot be reused for a different purpose (e.g., NCD screening) without obtaining fresh, informed, and explicit consent.
  • This aligns with the principle of purpose limitation, which ensures that personal health data is used only for the reason it was collected.
  • The reuse of digital health data across programs without consent violates the autonomy and rights of individuals and increases the risk of misuse or privacy breaches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients have the right to request deletion of their digital medical records under specific conditions: True. The DPDP Act provides the right to erasure when data is no longer necessary, or consent is withdrawn, provided it does not conflict with legal or public health obligations (e.g., mandatory disease reporting).

 

Option C. Public hospitals must notify authorities and affected individuals in case of a health data breach: True. The law mandates timely breach notification to the Data Protection Board of India and to the affected individuals if there’s a risk of harm, such as identity theft or unauthorized disclosure.

 

Option D. The scope of the law includes telemedicine platforms used in public health interventions: True. The DPDP Act explicitly includes digital health platforms, mobile health apps, and telemedicine systems under its purview. These entities must implement security, consent, and privacy protections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under the Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP) 2023, health data collected for one purpose cannot be reused for another without fresh informed consent. 
  • The Act upholds principles like purpose limitation, user rights, and data breach accountability, making it vital for all public health digital systems in India.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to OPD due to frequent respiratory and skin infections, easy bruising, and increased sensitivity to light. On examination, he has pale skin, light-colored hair, and involuntary rapid eye movements. Laboratory studies demonstrate prolonged bleeding time and peripheral smear reveals large coarse cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes. Genetic analysis identifies a mutation in the LYST gene. Which of the following normal cellular processes is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phagosome-lysosome fusion

 

  • This boy has recurrent infections, easy bruising, light sensitivity, fair skin, light-colored hair, nystagmus, prolonged bleeding time, and large coarse cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes, together with a mutation in the LYST gene. 
  • These findings are classic for Chediak–Higashi syndrome (CHL).
  • The LYST gene encodes a lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. Mutation causes failure of phagosome-lysosome fusion, leading to defective microbial killing by neutrophils and macrophages. 
  • This defect also explains the large abnormal granules seen in leukocytes and the increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Thus, the impaired cellular process is phagosome-lysosome fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracellular trafficking: While trafficking of vesicles is indeed influenced by LYST, the extracellular trafficking is not affected. 

 

Option C. Oxidative burst activity: Oxidative burst is impaired in chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) due to NADPH oxidase deficiency, not in CHL. Patients with CGD cannot generate reactive oxygen species to kill pathogens, whereas in CHL the problem is fusion, not ROS generation.

 

Option D. Chemotaxis: Defective chemotaxis is seen in leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD), due to impaired integrin function. CHL patients can recruit neutrophils, but those neutrophils fail to kill effectively due to defective lysosomal fusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chediak–Higashi syndrome is due to LYST gene mutation, leading to impaired phagosome-lysosome fusion, giant cytoplasmic granules in leukocytes, recurrent infections, bleeding tendency, and light sensitivity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought by his parents with bowing of the legs noted over the past year. The deformity is painless, and developmental milestones are otherwise normal. X-ray of both knees is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

  • The radiograph shows cupping, fraying, and splaying of the metaphysis, along with widening of the growth plate. 
  • In a growing child, these findings with painless genu varum strongly suggest nutritional rickets due to defective mineralization of bone. 
  • Clinical features like craniotabes, frontal bossing, delayed dentition, and genu varum/valgum further support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy, caused by vitamin C deficiency, presents with painful pseudoparalysis, bleeding gums, and subperiosteal hemorrhages. Radiology shows the white line of Frankel, Pelkan spurs, and corner sign, not metaphyseal cupping and splaying as seen here.

 

Option C. Congenital anomaly: Congenital anomalies such as Blount disease or skeletal dysplasias can present with bowing, but they usually have characteristic asymmetric involvement or dysplastic changes, not the classical rachitic changes seen here.

 

Option D. Trauma to epiphysis causing degeneration: Trauma involving the epiphysis (e.g., Salter-Harris fractures) results in localized growth plate damage, irregularity, or premature closure, not the diffuse metaphyseal changes with splaying and cupping that are hallmarks of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painless genu varum with X-ray features of metaphyseal cupping and splaying is diagnostic of rickets, a disease of defective bone mineralization in children.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Acute Pancreatitis are true?

 

  1. Necrosis can occur in severe acute pancreatitis
  2. Conservative management is the mainstay of treatment
  3. The most common cause is biliary calculi
  4. BISAP scoring system is used for severity assessment
  5. Pseudocyst occurs within 4 weeks of acute pancreatitis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Necrosis can occur in severe acute pancreatitis: True. Necrosis does occur in severe acute pancreatitis due to autodigestion of pancreatic tissue by enzymes.

 

Statement 2. Conservative management is the mainstay of treatment: True. Most patients are treated conservatively with fluids, analgesia, and supportive care.

 

Statement 3. The most common cause is biliary calculi: True. Gallstones are the most common cause of acute pancreatitis worldwide.

 

Statement 4. BISAP scoring system is used for severity assessment: True. BISAP (Bedside index of severity in acute pancreatitis) is a well-known scoring system used to assess severity.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 5. Pseudocyst occurs within 4 weeks of acute pancreatitis: False. Pseudocyst is a late complication, occurs due to persistence of acute peripancreatic fluid collection for more than 4 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute pancreatitis is most often caused by gallstones, managed conservatively, may lead to necrosis, and severity is graded by BISAP score.

choices.text: There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer
MRI is useful in diagnosing accreta in posterior placentas
During cesarean, a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation
Upper segment cesarean is usually performed to deliver the baby

questions.text: All are true regarding morbidly adherent placenta except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) During cesarean, a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation

 

  • In cases of morbidly adherent placenta (placenta accreta, increta, or percreta), attempting to manually deliver the placenta can lead to catastrophic hemorrhage and should not be attempted. 
  • Instead, if a placenta accreta is suspected, the recommended approach is to leave the placenta in situ and proceed with further interventions such as a hysterectomy if necessary. 
  • Trying to remove the placenta forcibly could result in severe blood loss due to the abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer: This is correct. The absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer is characteristic of placenta accreta, allowing the placenta to abnormally adhere to the myometrium.

 

Option B. MRI is useful in diagnosing accreta in posterior placentas: This is correct. MRI is especially useful in diagnosing placenta accreta when the placenta is located in the posterior aspect, as ultrasound imaging may be inadequate due to interference from maternal bony structures.

 

Option D. Upper segment cesarean is usually performed to deliver the baby: This is incorrect. In most cases of morbidly adherent placenta, a lower segment cesarean section is preferred. A classical cesarean (upper segment) may be considered in specific cases, but it is generally avoided due to the risk of complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with morbidly adherent placenta, it is crucial not to attempt manual removal of the placenta during cesarean delivery. 
  • Instead, the placenta is often left in situ, and further interventions like hysterectomy are planned to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mismatched pair between the study type and its corresponding reporting guideline?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quality Improvement Studies – STROBE

 

  • STROBE (Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) is specifically designed for observational studies, such as cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies.
  • It is not the appropriate guideline for Quality Improvement (QI) studies.
  • The correct guideline for Quality Improvement Studies is SQUIRE (Standards for QUality Improvement Reporting Excellence)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic studies – STARD: Correct pairing. STARD (Standards for Reporting Diagnostic Accuracy Studies) is the correct guideline for reporting diagnostic and prognostic accuracy.

 

Option B. Case Reports – CARE: Correct. CARE (CAse REport) guidelines are used for writing and reporting case reports.

 

Option C. Qualitative Research – SRQR: Correct. SRQR (Standards for Reporting Qualitative Research) applies to qualitative research methodologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specific reporting guidelines tailored to the study type:

 

  • STROBE – Observational studies
  • SQUIRE – Quality improvement
  • PRISMA – Systematic reviews/meta-analyses
  • CONSORT – Randomized controlled trials
  • STARD – Diagnostic accuracy
  • CARE – Case reports
  • SRQR – Qualitative research
  • MOOSE - Meta-analysis 
  • SPIRIT – Intervention trials (Standard Protocols)

questions.text: Which of the following represents a Phase I metabolic transformation that typically introduces a polar functional group into a drug molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxylation

 

  • Drug metabolism consists of two stages:
    • Phase I (functionalization reactions): These reactions involve oxidation, reduction, or hydrolysis and are mainly mediated by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver. They introduce or expose a polar functional group (such as hydroxyl, amino, or sulfhydryl groups). Hydroxylation is the classic Phase I reaction.
    • Phase II (conjugation reactions): These reactions involve methylation, glucuronidation, sulfation, and glutathione conjugation, which couple drugs with endogenous substrates to increase water solubility and enhance renal or biliary excretion.
  • Thus, hydroxylation is the only Phase I reaction listed here.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Methylation: A Phase II conjugation reaction that transfers a methyl group (–CH3). It does not introduce polarity but may inactivate drugs.

 

Option C. Glucuronidation: A Phase II reaction mediated by UDP-glucuronyl transferase, essential in metabolism of bilirubin and drugs like morphine.

 

Option D. Glutathione conjugation: Another Phase II reaction where glutathione binds to toxic electrophiles, important in detoxifying drugs like acetaminophen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydroxylation is a Phase I metabolic transformation (via cytochrome P450 enzymes) that introduces polar functional groups. 
  • In contrast, Phase II reactions such as methylation, glucuronidation, and glutathione conjugation are conjugation processes that enhance solubility for elimination.

choices.text: HALE is equivalent to crude life expectancy
YPLL emphasizes deaths occurring at younger ages

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) YPLL emphasizes deaths occurring at younger ages

 

  • YPLL (Years of Potential Life Lost) is a measure that quantifies premature mortality by emphasizing deaths that occur before a predetermined age threshold (e.g., 70 years).
  • It assigns more weight to deaths at younger ages, hence highlighting conditions and injuries affecting children and young adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DALE has replaced HALE: Incorrect. HALE (Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy) is currently the accepted term used by WHO. DALE (Disability-Adjusted Life Expectancy) was an older term previously used but was replaced by HALE.

 

Option B. HALE is equivalent to crude life expectancy: Incorrect. HALE adjusts life expectancy by accounting for years lived in less than full health due to disease or disability. Crude life expectancy does not consider the quality of life.

 

Option D. Socio-economic indicators exclude dependency ratio: Incorrect. Dependency ratio is a key socio-economic indicator, used to assess the burden of non-working (dependent) population on the working-age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

YPLL focuses on premature mortality, especially deaths occurring at younger ages, making it crucial for identifying preventable causes of death and targeting public health interventions.

 

Note - Socio-economic Indicators [Mnemonic: He FLAGGED]

 

  • Housing
  • Family size
  • Literacy rate
  • Availability per capita calorie
  • GNP per capita
  • Growth rate
  • UnEmployment level
  • Dependency ratio

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about atrial septal defect (ASD) are true? 

 

  1. Ostium primum is the most common type of ASD
  2. Surgery is usually done before 3 years of age
  3. The second heart sound is wide and fixed in splitting
  4. A soft mid-diastolic rumble may be heard at the lower left sternal border
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 2. Surgery is usually done before 3 years of age: Elective surgical or device closure is ideally performed in early childhood, typically between 2–5 years, to prevent long-term complications such as arrhythmias, pulmonary hypertension, and right heart failure. Repair in adulthood carries higher risks.

 

Statement 3. The second heart sound is wide and fixed in splitting: Auscultation in ASD characteristically reveals a widely split and fixed second heart sound (S2) that does not vary with respiration. This is a hallmark clinical finding of ASD.

 

Statement 4. A soft mid-diastolic rumble at the lower left sternal border: A short, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur may be heard due to increased tricuspid valve flow from left-to-right shunting across the atrial septum.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 1. Ostium primum is the most common type of ASD): False. The most common type is ostium secundum ASD (about 70%), located at the region of the fossa ovalis. Ostium primum is less common and associated with AV valve abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ostium secundum is the most common type of ASD; the classic signs include a fixed wide split of S2 and a mid-diastolic murmur at the left sternal border, with surgical correction recommended in early childhood.

questions.text: Match the following reflexes with their correct explanation:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

  • 1-c. Bezold–Jarisch reflex- Triggered by myocardial ischemia, causes bradycardia and hypotension: Caused by stimulation of ventricular receptors (especially during ischemia), leading to bradycardia and hypotension.
  • 2-d. Hering–Breuer reflex- Triggered by lung inflation, regulates depth and frequency of breathing: Triggered by lung inflation; regulates depth and frequency of respiration, preventing overinflation.
  • 3-b. Bainbridge reflex- Triggered by increased venous return, causes increased heart rate to accommodate blood volume: Triggered by increased venous return; increases heart rate to handle the extra blood volume.

  • 4-a. Cushing’s reflex- Triggered by increased intracranial pressure, produces hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration: Triggered by raised intracranial pressure; produces the classic triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bezold–Jarisch → MI-induced vagal bradycardia.
  • Hering–Breuer → Lung stretch regulates breathing.
  • Bainbridge → Increased venous return raises heart rate.
  • Cushing’s → ICP ↑ leads to HTN, bradycardia, abnormal breathing.

questions.text: What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculin syringe

 

  • The syringe shown is a 1 mL tuberculin syringe, calibrated in 0.01 mL increments. 
  • It is specifically designed for intradermal administration of tuberculin for the Mantoux test and is also used for BCG vaccination, both of which utilize tuberculin. 
  • Its precision makes it ideal for very small-volume injections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mantoux syringe: The Mantoux test is performed using a tuberculin syringe, but the term "Mantoux syringe" is not correct terminology. The syringe itself is universally called a tuberculin syringe.

 

Option B. BCG syringe: Although BCG vaccine is administered intradermally with a tuberculin syringe, there is no separate entity called a "BCG syringe." The same tuberculin syringe is used for both BCG vaccination and Mantoux testing.

 

Option D. DOT syringe: This option is a distractor. "DOT" refers to Directly Observed Treatment for tuberculosis, which does not require a specific syringe type. Standard disposable syringes are used for injectable drugs, not tuberculin syringes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tuberculin syringe is a 1 mL syringe marked in 0.01 mL increments, used for precise intradermal injections such as Mantoux testing and BCG vaccination.

questions.text:
Which of the following commonly used methods for evaluating protein quality are based on nitrogen balance or retention principles? 

 

  1. Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER)
  2. Biological Value (BV)
  3. Net Protein Utilization (NPU)
  4. Amino Acid Score (AAS)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, and 3

 

Statement 1. Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER): Although PER is a growth-based method, it depends on the weight gain per unit protein intake, which indirectly reflects nitrogen retention.

 

Statement 2. Biological Value (BV): Measures how much nitrogen absorbed from protein is retained in the body, thus directly related to nitrogen metabolism.

 

Statement 3. Net Protein Utilization (NPU): Calculates the percentage of nitrogen ingested that is retained for tissue formation. It is a direct nitrogen-based measure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Amino Acid Score (AAS): This is a chemical method, based on comparing amino acid composition with a reference protein. No nitrogen-based calculation is involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protein Quality Assessment:

 

  • DIAAS: FAO-recommended; measures digestible essential amino acids. Most accurate.
  • PDCAAS: AAS + digestibility; now outdated.
  • AAS: Based on most limiting essential amino acid.
  • PER: Weight gain per gram protein; not ideal for adults.
  • BV: Nitrogen retained vs. absorbed.
  • NPU: Nitrogen used for tissue vs. digested.

choices.text: It indicates epithelial rejection, best treated with surface steroids
This sign is pathognomonic of subepithelial immune infiltration
It represents a leading edge of endothelial rejection requiring urgent systemic immunosuppression
It confirms active endothelial rejection and requires intensive topical corticosteroids

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most accurate about the finding shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It confirms active endothelial rejection and requires intensive topical corticosteroids

 

  • The image shows a classic Khodadoust line, a linear aggregation of inflammatory cells at the endothelial level of a corneal graft. 
  • It is a hallmark of acute endothelial graft rejection.
  • The line typically starts from the graft-host junction and progresses centrally.

 

Progression → “MOVE”

 

  • M – Moving centrally (line advances toward visual axis)
  • O – Opacity increases (stromal/epithelial edema worsens)
  • V – Vision worsens (increasing blur/haloes)

  • E – Exudates rise (more KPs + AC cells/flare)

     

     

Regression → “CLEAR”

 

  • C – Clearing starts (edema reduces from periphery)
  • L – Line halts (no further central movement)
  • E – Edema subsides (corneal clarity improves)
  • A – AC reaction decreases (fewer cells/flare)
  • R – Recovery of vision (subjective improvement)

 

So

 

“Progression is identified if the Khodadoust line moves centrally with increasing edema and worsening vision; regression is noted when the line halts and the cornea begins to clear from the periphery inward.”

 

 

  • Prompt treatment is crucial to prevent permanent endothelial loss and graft failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Hourly topical corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone acetate 1%)
    • Consider systemic steroids only in recurrent or resistant cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It indicates epithelial rejection, best treated with surface steroids: Epithelial rejection shows Krachmer spots (subepithelial infiltrates), not this endothelial pattern.

 

 

Option B. This sign is pathognomonic of subepithelial immune infiltration: Subepithelial infiltration appears as diffuse hazy patches, not a linear band.

 

Option C. It represents a leading edge of endothelial rejection requiring urgent systemic immunosuppression: Systemic immunosuppression is not first-line; topical therapy is effective in most cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Khodadoust line is the classic slit-lamp finding in corneal endothelial graft rejection.
  • It requires urgent intensive topical corticosteroids to preserve graft clarity and function.

questions.text: In a clinical trial comparing blood pressure measurements, two nurses independently record systolic pressures for the same patients. The values differ systematically between observers. Which of the following statistical tools best quantifies the degree of agreement in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bland-Altman plot

 

  • The Bland-Altman plot is the gold standard for assessing agreement between two quantitative measurement methods or raters. 
  • It plots the difference between the two measurements against their mean, allowing visualization of:
    • Systematic bias (e.g., one nurse consistently reading higher)
    • Random variation (scatter of differences)
    • Limits of agreement (typically mean ± 2 SD of the difference)
  • In this case, where the difference is consistent and numeric, Bland-Altman is preferred over correlation-based methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cronbach’s alpha: Measures internal consistency of items within a scale (e.g., questionnaire reliability), not inter-observer agreement for continuous variables.

 

Option B. Pearson correlation coefficient: Assesses linear correlation, not agreement. Two observers could have a high Pearson’s r but poor agreement (i.e., one always reads 10 mmHg higher).

 

Option C. Kappa statistic: Used to assess inter-rater agreement for categorical variables, not continuous numeric data like systolic BP.

 

Educational Objective:
