The Bland-Altman plot is used to evaluate agreement between two quantitative measurement methods or observers, detecting both systematic bias and variability.

choices.text: Injection of adrenaline into the lesion

questions.text: A 49-year-old man, with a history of long-standing abdominal distension presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is hemodynamically stabilized with IV fluids and blood products. Upper GI endoscopy shows the following. What is the next immediate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Variceal banding

 

  • Endoscopic variceal ligation (banding) is the first-line treatment for actively bleeding esophageal varices once the patient is stabilized. 
  • It directly controls bleeding by mechanically strangulating varices, is safer than sclerotherapy, and has fewer complications. 
  • It is considered the immediate step in management after initial resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Injection of adrenaline into the lesion: This is performed for a bleeding peptic ulcer as a part of dual endotherapy

 

Option C. Argon plasma coagulation: This is performed so vascular lesions like GAVE.

 

Option D. Balloon tamponade: Balloon tamponade (e.g., using a Sengstaken–Blakemore tube) is a temporary measure for uncontrolled variceal bleeding when endoscopic therapy is not available. It has a high risk of aspiration, ulceration, and esophageal rupture, so it is only used as a bridge until definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic variceal ligation (banding) is the immediate next step in the management of actively bleeding esophageal varices after stabilization, while TIPSS, devascularization, and balloon tamponade are reserved for refractory or rescue situations.

questions.text: A dental sample from an unidentified dead infant is examined under microscopy. A neonatal line is detected, and 30 cross striations are counted between the neonatal line and the surface. What is the most likely age of the infant at the time of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days postnatal

 

  • This is based on Boyde’s method of age estimation, which relies on the microscopic counting of daily cross striations (incremental growth lines) in the enamel of developing teeth:
    • The neonatal line marks the boundary between prenatal and postnatal enamel, and forms within 1–3 days after birth.
    • Each cross striation represents one day of enamel formation.
    • Therefore, 30 striations beyond the neonatal line indicate that the child lived for approximately 30 days after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boyde’s method is a microscopic forensic technique that estimates the postnatal age of infants by counting cross striations in the enamel beyond the neonatal line, with each striation representing one day of life after birth.

choices.text: IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen
Drug-induced antibody formation against RBC membrane antigens

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman with a known history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with progressive fatigue and jaundice. Laboratory findings show:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 7.9 g/dL
  • Reticulocyte count: elevated
  • Bilirubin: indirect hyperbilirubinemia
  • LDH: elevated
  • Direct Coombs test: positive

 

Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen

 

  • This patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with anemia, jaundice, and laboratory evidence of hemolysis:
    • Low hemoglobin (8.2 g/dL)
    • Elevated reticulocyte count (compensatory marrow response)
    • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia (from heme breakdown)
    • Elevated LDH (released from lysed red cells)
    • Positive direct Coombs test (confirming autoimmune hemolysis)
  • These findings point toward warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (warm AIHA), which is strongly associated with CLL. In warm AIHA, IgG antibodies bind RBCs at body temperature. 
  • The IgG-coated RBCs are then recognized by splenic macrophages through Fc receptors, leading to extravascular hemolysis in the spleen.
  • Thus, the most likely mechanism is IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement-mediated lysis: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is caused by PIGA gene mutation, leading to deficient GPI-anchored proteins (CD55/CD59) that normally protect RBCs from complement. This results in chronic intravascular hemolysis, not a Coombs-positive hemolytic anemia, and it is not directly associated with CLL in this case.

 

Option C. Drug-induced antibody formation against RBC membrane antigens: Certain drugs (e.g., penicillin, methyldopa) can trigger drug-induced immune hemolytic anemia, leading to Coombs positivity. However, in this case, the patient’s history of CLL and absence of drug exposure history strongly favor warm autoimmune hemolysis due to IgG rather than drug-induced hemolysis.

 

Option D. Membrane attack complex (MAC)-mediated intravascular hemolysis: Complement-mediated MAC lysis results in intravascular hemolysis, as seen in conditions like cold agglutinin disease (IgM-mediated) or PNH. However, this patient’s findings (warm setting, IgG-mediated opsonization, splenic hemolysis) indicate warm AIHA, not complement-driven MAC destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, often associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, is caused by IgG autoantibodies that opsonize red blood cells, leading to splenic sequestration and extravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old competitive sprinter begins a 100-meter dash. Within seconds of the first powerful muscle contractions, intracellular signals trigger rapid glycogen phosphorylase activation in skeletal muscle to meet acute ATP demand. Which of the following molecules most directly activates glycogen phosphorylase during this contraction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcium

 

  • During sudden, intense skeletal muscle contraction, calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. 
  • Cytosolic calcium binds calmodulin on phosphorylase kinase, activating it even in the absence of hormonal input. 
  • Activated phosphorylase kinase converts glycogen phosphorylase b → glycogen phosphorylase a, thereby activating glycogen phosphorylase and accelerating glycogenolysis to supply glucose-1-phosphate for rapid ATP production. 
  • Thus, calcium directly couples excitation–contraction to activation of glycogen phosphorylase in muscle.

 

Key phrases covered:

 

  • Activates / activation: Calcium-triggered activation via calmodulin–phosphorylase kinase turns glycogen phosphorylase into its active “a” form.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase: The enzyme that cleaves α-1,4 glycosidic bonds during glycogenolysis in contracting muscle.
  • Calcium: The correct molecule linking contraction to metabolic response.
  • Glucose 6-phosphate, insulin, glucose: Addressed below as incorrect alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin promotes the dephosphorylation (via protein phosphatase-1) and inactivation of glycogen phosphorylase, while favoring glycogen synthesis (activates glycogen synthase). Therefore, insulin does not activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Glucose 6-phosphate: Incorrect. Glucose 6-phosphate is an allosteric inhibitor of hepatic glycogen phosphorylase and an activator of glycogen synthase; it does not activate glycogen phosphorylase. Thus, glucose 6-phosphate does not serve as the activating signal described.

 

Option D. Glucose: Incorrect. Glucose (especially in liver) allosterically favors the inactive state of glycogen phosphorylase a by promoting its dephosphorylation; it does not activate glycogen phosphorylase. In the contracting muscle setting, glucose is not the direct activator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium released during muscle contraction binds calmodulin to activate phosphorylase kinase, which activates glycogen phosphorylase and drives glycogenolysis.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is undergoing cataract surgery with primary intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Biometry reveals an ideal IOL power of 24 diopters (D) based on axial length and keratometry. To account for future ocular growth and the expected myopic shift, the surgeon plans to under-correct the IOL. What power of IOL should ideally be implanted?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 19.0D

 

  • In paediatric cataract surgery, the implanted IOL power is intentionally under-corrected to account for the myopic shift that occurs as the child’s eye grows. 
  • Unlike adults, children’s eyes increase in axial length significantly in the first few years of life, causing a natural shift toward myopia.
  • A commonly used rule is to reduce IOL power by a percentage based on age. 
  • 20% under-correction at age 1 year is typically recommended.
  • For a calculated power of 24D:
    • 20% of 24D = 4.8D
    • 24D – 4.8D = 19.2D, so closest power is 19.0 D
  • This approach minimizes the risk of postoperative high myopia in later childhood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In infants undergoing IOL implantation for congenital cataract, IOL power must be under-corrected to compensate for future axial eye growth and the resulting myopic shift. 
  • A 20% reduction from calculated power is commonly used at 1 year of age.

choices.text: Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Sciatic nerve; Posterior compartment: Obturator nerve
Anterior compartment: Sciatic nerve; Medial compartment: Femoral nerve; Posterior compartment: Obturator nerve
Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Obturator nerve; Posterior compartment: Sciatic nerve
Anterior compartment: Obturator nerve; Medial compartment: Sciatic nerve; Posterior compartment: Femoral nerve

questions.text: Based on the anatomy of thigh compartments and their nerve supply, which of the following correctly matches the three main compartments of the thigh with their respective primary innervating nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior compartment: Femoral nerve; Medial compartment: Obturator nerve; Posterior compartment: Sciatic nerve

 

  • The thigh is divided into three compartments, each with its own primary nerve supply:
    • Anterior compartment: Innervated by the femoral nerve, responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. Key muscles include quadriceps femoris, sartorius, and pectineus (partially by obturator nerve).
    • Medial compartment: Innervated mainly by the obturator nerve, responsible for thigh adduction. Muscles include adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus (adductor part), and gracilis.
    • Posterior compartment: Innervated primarily by the sciatic nerve (tibial division for most muscles, common fibular division for short head of biceps femoris), responsible for hip extension and knee flexion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh compartment, the obturator nerve supplies the medial compartment, and the sciatic nerve supplies the posterior compartment. 
  • This organization is essential for understanding motor deficits following nerve injuries in the thigh.

choices.text: Twin concordance is more with ulcerative colitis than Crohn’s disease.
Very early onset IBD has a strong family history and is resistant to therapy.
Reduced biodiversity of intestinal microbiota is common.
Breastfeeding confers protection against the development of IBD.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy and biopsy confirm Crohn’s disease. He has a family history of ulcerative colitis in his mother. Regarding the risk factors for IBD, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Twin concordance is more with ulcerative colitis than Crohn’s disease.

 

  • Twin concordance rates reflect the genetic contribution to a disease. Studies consistently show that Crohn’s disease (CD) has a higher twin concordance rate than ulcerative colitis (UC), indicating a stronger genetic predisposition in CD. 
  • For monozygotic twins, concordance for CD is approximately 40-60%, while for UC, it is around 14–19%.  
  • Dizygotic twin concordance is lower for both (4–7% for CD, 0–2% for UC), but the gap is more pronounced in CD, suggesting a greater genetic influence.
  • Therefore, stating that twin concordance is higher in UC than CD is false.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Very early onset IBD has a strong family history and is resistant to therapy: Correct. VEO-IBD (onset <6 years) is often linked to genetic mutations (e.g., IL10RA, NOD2), leading to a strong family history. Its aggressive course and monogenic etiology make it resistant to standard therapies like aminosalicylates, often requiring biologics or surgical intervention.

 

Option C. Reduced biodiversity of intestinal microbiota is common: Correct. Dysbiosis, characterized by reduced microbial diversity, is well-documented in IBD. Loss of beneficial bacteria (e.g., Faecalibacterium prausnitzii) and overgrowth of pro-inflammatory species contribute to chronic inflammation in CD and UC.

 

Option D. Breastfeeding confers protection against the development of IBD: Correct. Breastfeeding is protective against IBD, with studies showing a reduced risk of both CD and UC in breastfed individuals, likely due to early microbial colonization and immune modulation from breast milk components.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crohn’s disease has higher twin concordance (50–58%) than ulcerative colitis (14–19%), reflecting a stronger genetic predisposition.
  • Very early onset IBD is associated with strong family history and therapy resistance due to genetic factors.
  • Breastfeeding reduces IBD risk by fostering a protective gut microbiome, while reduced microbial biodiversity is a common feature of IBD.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man undergoes routine occupational health screening. Urinalysis detects a reducing substance. His fasting blood glucose level is normal, and he denies any history of diabetes mellitus. He mentions that his father had a similar finding on testing but remained healthy throughout life. Which of the following sugars is most likely to be present in his urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L-xylulose  

 

  • This presentation is characteristic of essential pentosuria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder of pentose metabolism caused by L-xylulose reductase deficiency.
  • Biochemical basis: L-xylulose is an intermediate in the uronic acid pathway. A deficiency of L-xylulose reductase leads to its accumulation and subsequent urinary excretion.
  • Clinical clues in the stem:
    • Reducing substance in urine: Detected by Benedict’s or Fehling’s test.
    • Normal glucose: Excludes diabetes mellitus and renal glycosuria.
    • Positive family history: Suggests inherited enzyme deficiency.
    • Pentose metabolism defect: Directs focus away from common disaccharides or hexoses.
  • Course: Benign, with no systemic manifestations. Recognition prevents unnecessary workup for glycosuria causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. D-ribulose:

 

  • A ketopentose in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Not involved in essential pentosuria.
  • No benign familial disorder exists with isolated urinary excretion of D-ribulose.

 

Option C. D-lactose:

 

  • A disaccharide of glucose and galactose, present in milk.
  • Urinary excretion is not seen in pentose metabolism defects; occurs only in rare renal or metabolic disorders unrelated to L-xylulose reductase deficiency.

 

Option D. D-ribose:

 

  • An aldopentose critical for nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Excretion is linked to certain nucleoside metabolism defects, not essential pentosuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Essential pentosuria is a benign, autosomal recessive disorder due to L-xylulose reductase deficiency, leading to persistent urinary excretion of L-xylulose despite normal blood glucose levels.

choices.text: Only Patient A's organism exhibits cyst formation in tissues
Only Patient B's organism has a flagellated form
Patient A's organism is associated with neutrophilic CSF, while Patient B's with lymphocytic CSF
Patient B's disease has a more acute, rapidly fatal course than Patient A's

questions.text: You are reviewing CSF wet mounts of two patients: Patient A’s sample is shown in Image A and Patient B’s sample is shown in Image B. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates these organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient A's organism is associated with neutrophilic CSF, while Patient B's with lymphocytic CSF

 

  • Patient A's image is consistent with Naegleria fowleri trophozoite: Trophozoites are typically 10-25 µm in diameter, broadly rounded, and move using lobopodia (broad, finger-like projections).  It has single nucleus with central karyosome, consistent with Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM). The CSF response is neutrophilic.
  • Patient B's image shows Acanthamoeba trophozoite with spiny acanthopodia—seen in Granulomatous Amoebic Encephalitis (GAE), which elicits a lymphocytic CSF response due to its chronic course.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Only Patient A's organism exhibits cyst formation in tissues: Incorrect. Naegleria fowleri does not form cysts in tissues or CSF. Acanthamoeba does form cysts.

 

Option B. Only Patient B's organism has a flagellated form: Incorrect. Naegleria fowleri has a flagellated form; Acanthamoeba does not.

 

Option D. Patient B's disease has a more acute, rapidly fatal course than Patient A's: Incorrect. Naegleria causes a rapidly fatal course (acute), while Acanthamoeba is slowly progressive (subacute to chronic).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naegleria fowleri causes acute, rapidly progressive meningoencephalitis with neutrophilic CSF, while Acanthamoeba causes chronic granulomatous encephalitis with lymphocytic CSF.

questions.text: Which of these suture materials is known as the “Work horse” suture in general surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polyglactin 910 (Vicryl)

 

  • Polyglactin 910 (Vicryl) is a synthetic, absorbable, braided suture.
  • It offers excellent handling, secure knotting, and predictable absorption (~60 days).
  • Used widely for soft tissue approximation, bowel anastomosis, fascia closure, and subcutaneous suturing.
  • Its versatility across multiple tissue types and surgical scenarios makes it the go-to or “workhorse” suture in general surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with severe pain on the left side of his face, describing each attack as a sharp "stab" lasting seconds, occurring above his left eye at a frequency of 5–6 times per minute. Attacks are sometimes triggered by neck movement, with redness and tearing of the left eye during episodes. He has been on carbamazepine, titrated to a high dose, without relief, and seeks a second opinion. Which of the following is a potential next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamotrigine

 

  • The patient’s symptoms - short-lasting (seconds) unilateral facial pain with conjunctival injection (redness) and tearing, triggered by neck movement, and occurring frequently (5-6/min) - are characteristic of SUNCT, a rare trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC). 
  • Carbamazepine, a first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, has failed, indicating refractoriness, a known feature of SUNCT.
  • Lamotrigine is a potential next step. 
  • It is one of the most commonly used treatments for SUNCT, alongside gabapentin and topiramate, due to its efficacy in stabilizing neuronal hyperexcitability. 
  • Dosing typically starts at 25–50 mg/day, titrated to 100–400 mg/day based on response and tolerance, making it a reasonable option after carbamazepine failure.
  • The patient’s clinical profile and lack of response to carbamazepine support trialing lamotrigine, as SUNCT is notoriously refractory, and alternative anticonvulsants are guideline-supported next-line therapies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indomethacin: Incorrect. Indomethacin is highly effective for paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua (other TACs), but SUNCT and cluster headache do not respond to it. The patient’s profile (SUNCT) makes this inappropriate.

 

Option C. Neurosurgical consultation: Incorrect. While neuroimaging is recommended to rule out structural causes (e.g., tumors, vascular anomalies), neurosurgical intervention (e.g., microvascular decompression) is not the next step unless a correctable lesion is identified or medical therapy fails after multiple trials. Current evidence supports further medical management first.

 

Option D. Melatonin: Incorrect. Melatonin has no established efficacy for SUNCT or other TACs. It is sometimes explored for cluster headache prophylaxis, but there is no data supporting its use in SUNCT, making it unsuitable here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lamotrigine (25–400 mg/day) is a first-line alternative for SUNCT after carbamazepine failure, targeting neuronal hyperexcitability.
  • Indomethacin is ineffective for SUNCT, reserved for paroxysmal hemicrania/hemicrania continua.
  • Neurosurgical consultation is premature unless structural causes are confirmed or medical options exhaust.

questions.text: A 27-year-old parous woman (P1L1) is being treated with warfarin for a recent deep-vein thrombosis (DVT). She asks for contraception. Which method should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NuvaRing (combined ethinyl-estradiol/etonogestrel vaginal ring)

 

  • In a patient with DVT who is currently on warfarin, estrogen-containing contraception is contraindicated due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). 
  • Per CDC/WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), combined hormonal contraception (CHC)—which includes the NuvaRing (ethinyl-estradiol + etonogestrel)—is Category 4 (unacceptable health risk) in women with current DVT/PE, even when receiving therapeutic anticoagulation.
  • Therefore, the method to avoid is the NuvaRing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD): Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD is progestin-only and MEC Category 2 in women with current DVT on anticoagulation. It also reduces menstrual blood loss, which can be beneficial for patients on warfarin who may otherwise experience heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Etonogestrel implant (Implanon): The implant is progestin-only and is Category 2 for DVT on treatment. It does not contain estrogen and is acceptable in this setting.

 

Option D. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA/Depot Provera): Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate is progestin-only. For women with current DVT/PE on anticoagulation, it is Category 2. Although some studies discuss small VTE signals with DMPA, guidelines still allow its use when estrogen must be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In women with current or recent DVT/PE—including those on warfarin—avoid estrogen-containing methods (CHC: pills, patch, ring). 
  • Progestin-only options (LNG-IUD, implant, DMPA) are generally acceptable (MEC Category 2) and the LNG-IUD can help mitigate anticoagulation-related bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old unmarried man from a rural background presents to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of fatigue, weakness, anxiety, and sleep disturbance. He attributes his symptoms to frequent loss of semen in urine and during masturbation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dhat syndrome

 

  • The patient presents with somatic symptoms like fatigue, weakness, anxiety, and sleep disturbance, which he attributes to semen loss through urine or masturbation. 
  • This presentation is characteristic of Dhat syndrome, a culture-bound syndrome seen primarily in South Asian countries, especially India. 
  • It involves the belief that semen is a vital fluid, and its loss leads to physical and psychological symptoms.
  • Dhat syndrome is often seen in young, unmarried men from rural or conservative backgrounds, reflecting cultural beliefs about masculinity, virility, and sexuality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatization disorder: Involves multiple, medically unexplained somatic complaints across various systems over a longer period, without a specific cultural attribution to semen loss.

 

Option B. Hypochondriasis: Involves preoccupation with having a serious illness, despite medical reassurance. This patient attributes his symptoms specifically to semen loss, not disease fear.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder: While anxiety is present, GAD is not characterized by fixed cultural beliefs about bodily fluids. The focus on semen loss points away from GAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dhat syndrome is a culture-bound syndrome commonly seen in Indian subcontinent. Patients believe that they are losing ‘dhat’ or semen in urine or stools, and attribute multiple physical (such as weakness, fatigue and sexual symptoms) and psychological symptoms (anxiety, depressive symptoms) to this ‘semen loss’.

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and blood pressure
Increased activity of the vasomotor center

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is undergoing carotid endarterectomy for severe carotid artery stenosis. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally places a clamp just below the carotid sinus. Which of the following physiological responses is most likely to occur in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased activity of the vasomotor center

 

  • Clamping below the carotid sinus reduces perfusion pressure sensed by baroreceptors. 
  • The reduced stretch causes decreased baroreceptor firing, which the brainstem interprets as hypotension. 
  • This leads to increased sympathetic output from the vasomotor center, causing vasoconstriction, increased heart rate, and elevated blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased heart rate and blood pressure: Incorrect. A fall in baroreceptor firing increases sympathetic outflow. Thus, heart rate and blood pressure rise, not fall.

 

Option B. Increased parasympathetic discharge: Incorrect. The response is sympathetic activation with reduced parasympathetic activity, so this is opposite of the actual effect.

 

Option C. Decreased baroreceptor sensitivity: Incorrect. The sensitivity of the receptors is unchanged. The decreased afferent firing is due to reduced stretch from lower pressure, not a change in receptor sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clamping below the carotid sinus decreases baroreceptor firing, leading to increased vasomotor center activity, sympathetic outflow, and a compensatory rise in blood pressure and heart rate.

choices.text: May lead to deep transverse arrest

questions.text: A 24-year-old in the second stage of labor has the fetal head at the perineum, and the examiner notes the skull has reached the pelvic floor with the sagittal suture in an anteroposterior diameter. Which statement is most accurate in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outlet forceps can be applied 

 

  • When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, the delivery is at the outlet. 
  • Classical criteria for outlet forceps include: 
    1. Fetal skull at the pelvic floor
    2. Head at or on the perineum
    3. Sagittal suture in the AP diameter or slight obliquity, and 
    4. Scalp visible at the introitus (often without manually separating the labia). 
  • This clinical picture satisfies those outlet criteria; therefore, outlet forceps can be applied.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best time to give episiotomy: Incorrect as stated. Although an episiotomy, when indicated, is typically performed late (when the perineum is thinned and just prior to delivery), modern guidance avoids routine episiotomy. The phrase “best time” suggests a blanket recommendation, which is not appropriate; episiotomy is performed selectively, not automatically, even when the head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor.

 

Option C. Called as crowning: Incorrect in this vignette. Crowning is when the fetal head remains visible between contractions as it distends the perineum. Here, the stem explicitly states the scalp is not visible between contractions, so this is not crowning, despite the head being at the perineum and the skull on the pelvic floor.

 

Option D. May lead to deep transverse arrest: Incorrect. Deep transverse arrest is a malrotation problem occurring earlier at the mid-pelvis/ischial spines when the head is deeply engaged but fails to rotate anteriorly. Once the skull has reached the pelvic floor and the head is at the perineum, the scenario is past the stage at which deep transverse arrest typically occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When the head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor with appropriate rotation, the delivery is an outlet presentation, and outlet forceps can be applied if indicated. 
  • Crowning requires the head to remain visible between contractions, and routine episiotomy is not recommended.

choices.text: Skip the missed dose and proceed to Day 14 dose
Administer the missed dose as soon as possible and continue the remaining doses as per original schedule
Convert to intradermal Thai Red Cross regimen

questions.text: A 35-year-old veterinary worker is bitten by a monkey. He is promptly administered human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) and started on the Essen regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis. However, due to unforeseen circumstances, he misses his Day 7 dose. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer the missed dose as soon as possible and continue the remaining doses as per original schedule

 

  • The Essen regimen is a 5-dose intramuscular schedule administered on Days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 on deltoid
  • If any dose is missed, the recommendation is to administer the missed dose as soon as possible and then continue the remaining doses as originally scheduled, without restarting the entire course.
  • This approach is backed by WHO and NCDC guidelines, which emphasize maintaining immunity continuity while ensuring patient adherence and practicality, especially in post-exposure scenarios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skip the missed dose and proceed to Day 14 dose: Skipping any dose compromises immunity and increases risk of incomplete prophylaxis, especially for high-risk exposures.

 

Option B. Restart the entire Essen regimen: Restarting is not necessary; this leads to unnecessary vaccine doses and costs without added benefit.

 

Option D. Convert to intradermal Thai Red Cross regimen: Switching regimens mid-course is not advised and lacks validation for effective seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Essen regimen (1-1-1-1-1), missed doses should be given as soon as possible, and subsequent doses should continue as originally scheduled. Restarting or switching regimens is not necessary unless a significant lapse occurs.

choices.text: Bacterial flagellin activates B-cells monoclonally, while tetanus toxoid activates them polyclonally.
Bacterial flagellin does not require antigen processing, whereas tetanus toxoid does.
Bacterial flagellin induces affinity maturation and class switching, whereas tetanus toxoid does not.
Bacterial flagellin generates immunological memory, while tetanus toxoid does not.

questions.text: A research study is conducted to investigate the antibody response to two different antigens: bacterial flagellin and tetanus toxoid. Which of the following best describes the difference between these antigens?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacterial flagellin does not require antigen processing, whereas tetanus toxoid does.

 

  • Bacterial flagellin is a T-independent antigen that directly stimulates B-cells without requiring antigen processing or presentation by APCs. 
  • In contrast, tetanus toxoid is a T-dependent antigen, which requires antigen processing, presentation on MHC-II molecules, and T-cell help to stimulate B-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial flagellin activates B-cells monoclonally, while tetanus toxoid activates them polyclonally: Incorrect. Bacterial flagellin activates B-cells polyclonally, not monoclonally. Tetanus toxoid activates B-cells monoclonally.

 

Option C. Bacterial flagellin induces affinity maturation and class switching, whereas tetanus toxoid does not: Incorrect. Tetanus toxoid, as a T-dependent antigen, induces affinity maturation and class switching, while flagellin does not.

 

Option D. Bacterial flagellin generates immunological memory, while tetanus toxoid does not: Incorrect. Immunological memory is generated by T-dependent antigens like tetanus toxoid but not by T-independent antigens like flagellin.

 

Educational Objective:


T-independent antigens, such as bacterial flagellin, do not require antigen processing and presentation, whereas T-dependent antigens like tetanus toxoid require T-cell help for activation.

 

T-Independent Antigen vs. T-Dependent Antigen:

choices.text: Directed cervical biopsy from acetowhite areas

questions.text: A 47-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with postcoital bleeding. On pelvic examination, the cervix appears grossly normal. A Pap smear reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). Colposcopic evaluation demonstrates dense acetowhite epithelium with abnormal vascular patterns. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Directed cervical biopsy from acetowhite areas

 

  • In a postmenopausal woman with HSIL on cytology and colposcopy showing dense acetowhite lesions with abnormal vascularity, the next best step is to obtain a directed biopsy from the abnormal colposcopic areas.
  • HSIL warrants histopathologic confirmation before initiating definitive excisional treatment, especially in postmenopausal women where atrophy, chronic inflammation, or even invasive disease may alter management.
  • The dense acetowhite changes and abnormal vascular patterns on colposcopy are suspicious for high-grade CIN or invasive carcinoma, so targeted biopsies ensure accurate diagnosis and staging before treatment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocervical curettage: Incorrect. While ECC is performed when the transformation zone is not fully visible or when lesions extend into the canal, in this case the abnormal acetowhite lesions are visible and can be biopsied directly.

 

Option B. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP): Incorrect as the first step here. LEEP is an excisional treatment for confirmed CIN 2/3 or when colposcopic assessment is inadequate. Since the patient has a visible lesion with abnormal vascularity, histologic confirmation by biopsy is essential before proceeding to excision, especially in postmenopausal women where invasive carcinoma risk is higher.

 

Option C. Cold knife conization: Incorrect at this stage. Cold knife conization is indicated when there is suspicion of adenocarcinoma in situ, discordance between cytology and colposcopy, or inadequate colposcopic assessment. Here, colposcopy is adequate, so directed biopsy is preferred first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In women with HSIL on Pap smear and visible colposcopic lesions, the next step is directed biopsy from the abnormal areas to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment. 
  • This is especially critical in postmenopausal women, where histology guides the choice between ablative, excisional, or radical procedures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a short neck, limited range of neck movement, and a low posterior hairline. She has no recent trauma or systemic illness. A sagittal CT scan of the cervical spine is shown below. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klippel-Feil syndrome

 

  • The CT image shows congenital fusion of cervical vertebrae, typically seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome (KFS). 
  • The hallmark radiologic finding is the failure of segmentation of cervical somites, leading to fused vertebral bodies, most often involving C2–C3. This matches the patient’s clinical triad:
    • Short neck
    • Limited cervical mobility
    • Low posterior hairline
  • These features, in conjunction with imaging, make KFS the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sprengel deformity: This refers to a congenital elevation of the scapula, often associated with KFS, but not diagnosed by cervical spine CT alone.

 

Option C. Atlantoaxial dislocation: Involves abnormal motion or alignment between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2), usually seen in trauma, Down syndrome, or rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with instability, not fusion.

 

Option D. Arnold-Chiari malformation: Involves herniation of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, best seen on MRI brain/spine, not CT cervical spine. Associated symptoms include ataxia and headache—not limited neck motion or vertebral fusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Klippel-Feil syndrome is diagnosed radiologically by congenital fusion of cervical vertebrae, often presenting with a short, stiff neck and low posterior hairline. 
  • It arises from failure of segmentation of cervical somites and may be associated with scoliosis, Sprengel deformity, renal anomalies, or hearing loss.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being found lethargic in the morning. His parents report that he has frequent episodes of low blood sugar, especially after missing meals, and his abdomen has been progressively enlarging over the past year. Physical examination confirms hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals hypoglycemia. A liver biopsy shows glycogen deposits with abnormally short outer chains. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cori’s disease

 

  • This child presents with hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and abnormal glycogen accumulation seen on liver biopsy, specifically described as glycogen with short outer chains. 
  • This is diagnostic of Cori’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease type III), caused by debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) deficiency.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Debranching enzyme deficiency results in incomplete glycogen degradation.
  • The abnormal glycogen has short outer branches because α-1,6 linkages cannot be fully cleaved.
  • Hypoglycemia occurs due to limited glycogenolysis, but is less severe than in Von Gierke’s disease because gluconeogenesis remains intact.
  • Glycogen accumulates in liver, skeletal muscle, and sometimes heart, causing hepatomegaly, muscle weakness, and growth delay.

 

Key points from question included here:

 

  • Child – Pediatric onset is common.
  • Hypoglycemia – Fasting intolerance due to impaired glycogen breakdown.
  • Hepatomegaly – From glycogen accumulation in liver.
  • Accumulation of abnormal glycogen – Hallmark feature.
  • Liver biopsy – Confirms short-branched glycogen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Gierke’s disease (GSD type I):

 

  • Deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Presents with severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly.
  • Glycogen structure is normal, unlike the abnormal short outer branches in Cori’s disease.

 

Option B. Pompe’s disease (GSD type II):

 

  • Deficiency: Lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase).
  • Presents with cardiomegaly, hypotonia, and muscle weakness.
  • Does not cause fasting hypoglycemia; glycogen accumulates in lysosomes, not as short-branched cytoplasmic glycogen.

 

Option D. McArdle’s disease (GSD type V):

 

  • Deficiency: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Presents with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after exertion.
  • Does not cause hepatomegaly or fasting hypoglycemia because the liver is unaffected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cori’s disease (GSD type III) results from debranching enzyme deficiency, leading to hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and accumulation of abnormally structured glycogen with short outer branches on liver biopsy.

questions.text: The inferior border of the external oblique aponeurosis thickens and folds backward on itself, forming an important anatomical landmark that extends from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle. Which of the following structures is formed by this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inguinal ligament

 

  • The inguinal ligament is formed when the inferior margin of the external oblique aponeurosis thickens and folds back on itself, running between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and the pubic tubercle. 
  • This structure forms the base of the inguinal canal and serves as an important landmark in hernia anatomy.
  • In this case, the reducible hernia lies above the inguinal ligament, consistent with an inguinal hernia. 

  • The surgeon’s description points directly to the anatomical formation of this ligament from the external oblique aponeurosis.

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectus sheath: Incorrect. This is a fibrous compartment containing the rectus abdominis and pyramidalis muscles. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the external oblique, internal oblique, and transversus abdominis but is not specifically created by folding back of the inferior margin of the external oblique aponeurosis.

 

Option C. Arcuate line: Incorrect. This marks the lower limit of the posterior layer of the rectus sheath, located around the lower abdomen. It is unrelated to the folding of the external oblique aponeurosis.

 

Option D. Deep inguinal ring: Incorrect. This is an opening in the transversalis fascia, not formed by the external oblique aponeurosis. It is the internal entrance to the inguinal canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inguinal ligament is created when the inferior margin of the external oblique aponeurosis thickens and folds back on itself, extending from the ASIS to the pubic tubercle and forming the lower boundary of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease underwent terminal ileal resection for the presence of a stricture. Several months later, he presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of his hands and the peripheral smear shows the presence of macrocytic anemia. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

  • The most likely cause of tingling sensation in the hands and macrocytic anemia following ileal resection is vitamin B12 deficiency. 
  • The terminal ileum is the site for vitamin B12 absorption. 
  • Resection of this part of the bowel can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, which may result in neurological symptoms like tingling and macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency: Can cause neurological and cardiac symptoms, but it is not typically associated with macrocytic anemia.

 

Option C. Folic acid deficiency: Can cause macrocytic anemia, it doesn't typically cause the neurological symptoms described and is more often linked to dietary deficiencies or malabsorption syndromes not specific to the terminal ileum.

 

Option D. Calcium deficiency: Can lead to neuromuscular irritability and osteoporosis but is not typically associated with macrocytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Following resection of the terminal ileum, a patient may develop vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of specific receptors located there, which can lead to macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms like paresthesias.

choices.text: They inhibit intestinal absorption of dietary cholesterol.
They prevent degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing hepatic clearance of LDL.
They inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, reducing endogenous cholesterol synthesis.
They increase bile acid excretion, lowering cholesterol reabsorption.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of hypercholesterolemia is not achieving adequate LDL cholesterol reduction despite high-intensity statin therapy. His physician considers adding a PCSK9 inhibitor. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of PCSK9 inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They prevent degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing hepatic clearance of LDL.

 

  • PCSK9 normally promotes degradation of LDL receptors. 
  • PCSK9 inhibitors (alirocumab, evolocumab) are monoclonal antibodies that block this action, leading to increased LDL receptor recycling and enhanced LDL clearance from the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They inhibit intestinal absorption of dietary cholesterol: This is the mechanism of ezetimibe, not PCSK9 inhibitors.

 

Option C. They inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, reducing endogenous cholesterol synthesis: This describes statins, not PCSK9 inhibitors.

 

Option D. They increase bile acid excretion, lowering cholesterol reabsorption: This is the mechanism of bile acid sequestrants like cholestyramine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCSK9 inhibitors lower LDL cholesterol by preventing LDL receptor degradation, increasing hepatic LDL clearance. 
  • They are used as adjuncts to statin therapy in high-risk patients or in those with familial hypercholesterolemia.

questions.text: A middle-aged man sustains a severe injury to his lower limb in a high-speed collision. On examination, he cannot perform plantar flexion, and his ankle jerk reflex is absent. Dorsiflexion remains intact, and sensory testing reveals complete loss of sensation over the sole of the foot. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tibial nerve

 

  • The tibial nerve supplies:
    • Motor: Posterior compartment of the leg, responsible for plantar flexion (gastrocnemius, soleus) and toe flexion.
    • Reflex: Mediates the ankle jerk (S1-S2).

    • Sensory: Sole of the foot via medial and lateral plantar branches.

       

Injury effects:

 

  • Loss of plantar flexion → due to paralysis of posterior leg muscles.
  • Absent ankle jerk → tibial nerve carries afferent and efferent limbs for S1 reflex.
  • Preserved dorsiflexion → anterior compartment (deep peroneal nerve) intact.
  • Sensory loss over sole → hallmark of tibial nerve injury.
  • These findings exactly match this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve: Provides cutaneous sensation to the posterolateral leg and lateral foot. Lesion does not cause motor loss or affect the ankle jerk.

 

Option B. Common peroneal nerve: Supplies muscles for dorsiflexion and eversion; injury would cause foot drop, not isolated plantar flexion loss.

 

Option D. Deep peroneal nerve: Innervates anterior compartment of the leg for dorsiflexion; injury results in foot drop and sensory loss in the first web space, not loss of plantar flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tibial nerve injury results in loss of plantar flexion, absent ankle jerk, and sensory loss over the sole, while dorsiflexion remains intact because the anterior compartment (deep peroneal nerve) is unaffected.

choices.text: Pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas

questions.text: What CT finding, if present in the setting of cecal volvulus, would indicate bowel ischemia or impending gangrene, requiring emergent surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas

 

  • In patients with cecal volvulus, timely diagnosis is critical to avoid bowel necrosis. 
  • The most ominous signs on CT that suggest ischemia or impending gangrene are:
    • Pneumatosis intestinalis: Air within the bowel wall due to ischemic mucosal injury
    • Portal venous gas: Air tracking into the portal system, secondary to transmural bowel infarction
  • Both are urgent red flags for emergency laparotomy, as endoscopic decompression is contraindicated when ischemia is present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated colon >6 cm: This may suggest high-risk volvulus, but in isolation, does not confirm ischemia. Many volvulus cases present with this finding without necrosis.

 

Option B. Air-fluid levels within the cecum: Common in obstructive bowel pathology, but nonspecific. Does not distinguish viable vs ischemic bowel.

 

Option D. Gasless abdomen: Seen in early postoperative ileus or poor imaging window; not diagnostic of ischemia or volvulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cecal volvulus, pneumatosis intestinalis and portal venous gas on CT are specific indicators of bowel wall ischemia or necrosis, mandating urgent surgical intervention. 
  • Early recognition improves outcomes by avoiding delay in definitive care.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman undergoes a total abdominal hysterectomy. In the immediate postoperative period, she reports moderate-to-severe pain. Her past medical history includes peptic ulcer disease and she developed gastric bleeding few years ago while taking NSAIDs for arthritis. The surgical team considers giving her an analgesic that:

 

  • Provides postoperative pain control
  • Is available as a parenteral formulation
  • Has a lower risk of gastrointestinal ulceration and bleeding 

 

Which of the following medications best fits this profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parecoxib

 

  • Parecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor used for short-term management of acute postoperative pain.
  • It is unique because it is given parenterally (IV/IM injection), unlike most other COX-2 inhibitors (celecoxib is oral).
  • Its COX-2 selectivity provides analgesia and anti-inflammatory effects with reduced gastrointestinal toxicity, making it suitable for patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease or GI bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketorolac: A potent parenteral NSAID, but it is non-selective COX inhibitor, associated with significant GI bleeding risk.

 

Option C. Indomethacin:  Another non-selective NSAID, commonly used in gout and PDA closure, but not preferred for postoperative pain in patients with GI bleeding risk.

 

Option D. Ibuprofen: Oral NSAID, non-selective COX inhibitor, not typically used parenterally for immediate postoperative pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parecoxib is the only parenteral selective COX-2 inhibitor, used for short-term postoperative pain management with reduced gastrointestinal side effects compared to traditional NSAIDs.

choices.text: Increased blood flow to the skin

questions.text: A 40-year-old man develops fever due to a bacterial infection. As his hypothalamic set point for temperature regulation is suddenly raised, his body temperature begins to rise from baseline to the new higher level. On the graph shown, this corresponds to the transition from stage V to stage W. Which of the following physiological responses is most likely to occur during stage W?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shivering

 

  • At stage W, the hypothalamus has reset the body’s thermostat to a higher set point. 
  • The body perceives itself as being colder than the new target and initiates heat-generating mechanisms such as shivering, vasoconstriction, and piloerection to increase temperature toward the new set point.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sweating: Incorrect. Sweating occurs later, at stage Y, when the set point returns to normal and the body attempts to lose excess heat.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin: Incorrect. Skin vasodilation occurs in stage Y to dissipate heat, not during stage W.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis: Incorrect. Heat production is stimulated in stage W, not suppressed. Inhibition of thermogenesis occurs during the cooling phase (stage Y).

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the rising phase of fever (stage W), shivering and other heat-generating mechanisms are activated to elevate body temperature toward the new hypothalamic set point.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia is being treated with rosuvastatin for cholesterol management. He develops a respiratory tract infection and requires antibiotic therapy. The physician is considering additional medications, but one of the following should be avoided due to the risk of serious drug interaction with his current statin therapy. Which of the following agents should not be prescribed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin

 

  • Rosuvastatin is a statin used to lower LDL cholesterol and reduce cardiovascular risk. 
  • Statins are metabolized via the CYP450 system (especially CYP3A4 for many, though rosuvastatin is less dependent compared to simvastatin or atorvastatin).
  • Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic and a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor. When combined with statins, it increases statin serum levels, significantly raising the risk of statin-induced myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.
  • Therefore, clarithromycin should not be co-administered with rosuvastatin.
  • Contraindicated/should be avoided. 
  • Clarithromycin is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor. 
  • While rosuvastatin is less dependent on CYP3A4 metabolism compared to simvastatin or atorvastatin, it still undergoes partial metabolism and transporter-mediated clearance (OATP1B1/1B3, BCRP). 
  • Clarithromycin can increase plasma concentrations of rosuvastatin, raising the risk of statin-induced myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. Hence, it should be avoided.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cefixime: Safe. A third-generation oral cephalosporin; it has no significant interaction with rosuvastatin.

 

Option C. Linezolid: Safe. An oxazolidinone antibiotic with MAO-inhibitor activity, but it does not interfere with statin metabolism. No significant interaction with rosuvastatin.

 

Option D. Faropenem: Safe. An oral carbapenem antibiotic; no cytochrome P450 interaction with statins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic and CYP3A4 inhibitor, should not be co-administered with statins such as rosuvastatin because of the increased risk of statin-induced myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.

choices.text: Send a fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption test (FTA-ABS)
Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM single dose

questions.text: A 26-year-old primi at her 8-week routine antenatal visit has a reactive VDRL on screening. She is asymptomatic. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Send a fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption test (FTA-ABS)

 

  • A reactive VDRL in an 8-week pregnant 26-year-old detected on routine antenatal screening requires confirmation because VDRL (a nontreponemal test) is not specific and can yield biologic false positives (including in pregnancy). 
  • The next best step in management is to send a treponemal-specific confirmatory test such as FTA-ABS (or TPHA). 
  • If the treponemal test is positive, treat during pregnancy with benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM (single dose for early syphilis). 
  • Immediate termination of pregnancy is not indicated because syphilis is treatable, and repeating VDRL only delays definitive care. 
  • Thus, the immediate action is confirmatory treponemal testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat VDRL after 2 weeks: Incorrect. While titers are later used for follow-up, repeating a nonspecific screen first delays care. After a reactive VDRL on routine antenatal testing in an asymptomatic patient, confirm immediately with a treponemal-specific assay (e.g., FTA-ABS) rather than waiting 2 weeks.

 

Option C. Termination of pregnancy: Incorrect. Termination is not indicated solely for a positive VDRL. Syphilis in pregnancy is treatable; proper confirmation and benzathine penicillin therapy markedly reduce the risk of congenital infection.

 

Option D. Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM single dose: Incorrect. This is the correct treatment for confirmed early syphilis, but therapy should follow a treponemal-specific confirmation (e.g., FTA-ABS). Empiric treatment prior to confirmation can lead to unnecessary antibiotic exposure and mislabeling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a reactive VDRL during pregnancy, the next best step is confirmation with a treponemal-specific test (FTA-ABS/TPHA); if confirmed, treat with benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM to prevent congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man sustains a penetrating head injury involving the structure pointed by arrow. Which artery is the primary source of blood supply to this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior cerebral artery

 

  • The region marked in the question corresponds to the medial aspect of the frontal lobe, making the ACA the primary artery responsible for its perfusion. 
  • The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is a branch of the internal carotid artery that supplies the medial and superior aspects of the frontal and parietal lobes, as well as the anterior four-fifths of the corpus callosum. 

  • Damage to this artery can result in contralateral lower limb weakness and sensory deficits due to involvement of the medial motor and sensory cortices.

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery: While the ACA originates from the internal carotid artery, the internal carotid itself is a proximal vessel that supplies several cerebral branches. It does not directly supply the specific medial frontal lobe territory marked in the image.

 

Option C. Vertebral artery: This artery supplies the posterior circulation of the brain, including the brainstem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes via the posterior cerebral arteries. It has no role in the vascularization of the medial frontal lobe.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery: The Middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surfaces of the cerebral hemispheres, including the primary motor and sensory cortices for the face and upper limb, but not the medial frontal lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes, including the paracentral lobule, which contains the motor and sensory representations of the contralateral lower limb.

choices.text: It requires routine monitoring with PT/INR levels
It is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits Factor Xa
It acts as a direct thrombin inhibitor when given orally
It is metabolized extensively in the liver before excretion

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about fondaparinux?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits Factor Xa

 

  • Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant that works as a synthetic pentasaccharide, binding antithrombin III and causing potent, selective inhibition of Factor Xa.
  • It is given subcutaneously and does not inhibit thrombin directly.
  • It has predictable pharmacokinetics, so routine laboratory monitoring (like APTT or PT/INR) is not required.
  • It is mainly excreted unchanged by the kidneys, not metabolized by the liver.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It requires routine monitoring with PT/INR levels: False. Fondaparinux does not require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable effect, unlike unfractionated heparin.

 

Option C. It acts as a direct thrombin inhibitor when given orally: False. Fondaparinux is not a thrombin inhibitor and it is not given orally; it is a parenteral Factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Option D. It is metabolized extensively in the liver before excretion: False. Fondaparinux is excreted renally without significant hepatic metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits Factor Xa via antithrombin III, has predictable pharmacokinetics, is excreted by the kidneys, and does not require routine coagulation monitoring.

questions.text: A pregnant woman (G3P2L0) presented at 9 weeks gestation. She has a history of conization 1 year ago for CIN3 and is currently on follow-up with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has a history of preterm births at 30 and 32 weeks during her last 2 pregnancies. What is your next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical length measurement on ultrasound

 

  • This patient has a history of conization (a procedure that can weaken the cervix) and preterm births, which raises concerns about cervical insufficiency. 
  • The next appropriate step in managing this patient is to perform a cervical length measurement on transvaginal ultrasound to assess the risk of preterm labor.
  • Cervical length measured via ultrasound is the best way to determine whether the cervix is shortening or opening prematurely, which could indicate the need for intervention to prevent preterm birth.
  • If the cervical length is found to be shortened (<25 mm) before 24 weeks gestation, then cervical cerclage may be indicated to mechanically support the cervix and prevent premature dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical cerclage: Cervical cerclage is a procedure used to reinforce the cervix in cases of cervical insufficiency. However, this is not the immediate next step. First, the cervical length should be assessed via ultrasound to determine whether cerclage is needed. Cerclage is recommended if cervical shortening is detected.

 

Option C. Complete bed rest: Bed rest is generally not recommended as the primary intervention for preventing preterm birth due to limited evidence of its effectiveness. The first step should be assessing cervical length.

 

Option D. Abdominal cerclage: Abdominal cerclage is typically reserved for cases of failed transvaginal cerclage or in patients with a very short or absent cervix, often detected in earlier pregnancies. It is not the first-line intervention at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with a history of cervical conization and preterm births, the next step in management is to measure the cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound. 
  • If the cervix is shortened, interventions like cervical cerclage may be considered to prevent preterm birth.

questions.text: A newborn is noted to have bilateral renal agenesis on prenatal ultrasound, and postnatal examination confirms the absence of internal genital structures. These abnormalities are most likely due to defective development of which embryologic tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intermediate mesoderm

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is the embryonic tissue that gives rise to the urogenital system, including the kidneys, ureters, and much of the internal genital tract. 
  • Failure of intermediate mesoderm development results in anomalies such as renal agenesis and absence of internal genital structures. 
  • This tissue develops along the dorsal body wall between the paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm.
  • Renal agenesis can lead to Potter sequence due to oligohydramnios, but in this case, the focus is on the embryologic origin of the involved structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral plate mesoderm: Forms structures such as the heart, blood vessels, spleen, and the lining of body cavities. It is not involved in kidney or internal genital formation, so defects here would not explain renal agenesis.

 

Option B. Paraxial mesoderm: Gives rise to somites, which differentiate into skeletal muscle, dermis, and axial skeleton. It is unrelated to the urinary or genital systems.

 

Option D. Surface ectoderm: Differentiates into epidermis, hair, nails, sweat glands, and mammary glands, as well as the lens of the eye. It plays no role in urinary tract or internal genital development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intermediate mesoderm forms the kidneys, ureters, and most internal genital structures. Defective development of this tissue can result in both renal agenesis and absence of internal genitalia.

choices.text: Lacks cytochrome oxidase system for electron transport
Possesses superoxide dismutase but lacks catalase
Utilizes nitrate as terminal electron acceptor
Contains flavoprotein oxidase for oxygen reduction

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with diabetes presents with a foul-smelling foot ulcer. Gram stain shows gram-positive cocci in chains. The organism grows equally well in anaerobic jar and candle jar but shows negative catalase test. Which metabolic characteristic distinguishes this organism from facultative anaerobes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Possesses superoxide dismutase but lacks catalase

 

  • The clinical presentation and microbiology suggest Enterococcus species or aerotolerant streptococci causing diabetic foot infection. 
  • Aerotolerant anaerobes are unique in that they can tolerate oxygen but cannot use it for respiration. 
  • They possess superoxide dismutase (SOD) which converts toxic superoxide radicals to hydrogen peroxide and oxygen, but lack catalase to break down hydrogen peroxide. 
  • This distinguishes them from facultative anaerobes which have both SOD and catalase, and from obligate anaerobes which typically lack both enzymes.
  • These organisms rely exclusively on fermentation for ATP production regardless of oxygen presence, explaining equal growth in both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lacks cytochrome oxidase system for electron transport: While aerotolerant anaerobes lack cytochrome oxidase, this alone doesn't distinguish them from obligate anaerobes

 

Option C. Utilizes nitrate as terminal electron acceptor: Nitrate respiration is characteristic of some facultative anaerobes, not aerotolerant anaerobes

 

Option D. Contains flavoprotein oxidase for oxygen reduction: Flavoprotein oxidases that use oxygen are found in some aerobic bacteria, not aerotolerant anaerobes

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aerotolerant anaerobes possess superoxide dismutase but lack catalase, allowing oxygen tolerance without oxygen utilization for energy metabolism.

questions.text: Match the following diuretics with their mechanisms of action:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

  • 1. Triamterene → D. Block epithelial sodium channels (ENaC): Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic acting in the collecting duct, where it blocks ENaC (epithelial sodium channels). This reduces Na⁺ reabsorption and limits K⁺ secretion, fitting the mechanism “Block epithelial sodium channels (collecting duct).”
  • 2. Brinzolamide → A. Inhibit carbonic anhydrase (proximal tubule): Brinzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, it decreases H⁺ formation and NaHCO₃ reabsorption, matching “Inhibit carbonic anhydrase (proximal tubule).”
  • 3. Metolazone → C. Inhibit Na⁺-Cl⁻ pump (distal convoluted tubule): Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic that blocks the Na⁺-Cl⁻ cotransporter (NCC) in the distal convoluted tubule, exactly the mechanism “Inhibit Na⁺-Cl⁻ pump (distal convoluted tubule).”
  • 4. Bumetanide → B. Inhibit Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ pump (thick ascending limb): Bumetanide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the NKCC2 cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, matching “Inhibit Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ pump (thick ascending limb).”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Triamterene → ENaC block (collecting duct, potassium-sparing)
  • Brinzolamide → carbonic anhydrase inhibition (proximal tubule)
  • Metolazone → Na⁺-Cl⁻ cotransporter inhibition (distal convoluted tubule)
  • Bumetanide → Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ cotransporter inhibition (thick ascending limb)

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding the sternal angle (angle of Louis): 

  1. It lies at the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae.
  2. It marks the level where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  3. It is flanked by the costal cartilages of the 3rd pair of ribs.
  4. It is crossed by the superior epigastric artery.
  5. It lies in the epigastric fossa.

Which of the above statements is/ are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2 only

 

The sternal angle (angle of Louis) is a palpable ridge at the junction between the manubrium and the body of the sternum.

 

Statement 1. It lies at the level of the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae: Correct. The sternal angle lies at the level of the intervertebral disc between T4 and T5 vertebrae. This level is a key anatomical landmark for various thoracic structures.

 

Statement 2. It marks the level where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi: Correct. It corresponds to the level where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi, an important reference point for airway anatomy.

 

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3. It is flanked by the costal cartilages of the 3rd pair of ribs: Incorrect. because the sternal angle is flanked by the costal cartilages of the 2nd pair of ribs, not the 3rd pair. This is an important surface landmark used for rib counting.

 

Statement 4. It is crossed by the superior epigastric artery: Incorrect. The superior epigastric artery passes through the rectus sheath to supply the anterior abdominal wall; it does not cross the sternal angle. The sternal angle is crossed by the internal mammillary artery.

 

Statement 5. It lies in the epigastric fossa: Incorrect. The sternal angle does not lie in the epigastric fossa; it is located in the anterior thoracic wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sternal angle is located at the level of the T4/T5 intervertebral disc and marks the site of tracheal bifurcation. 
  • It is flanked by the costal cartilages of the second ribs and serves as an essential landmark in thoracic anatomy and clinical examination.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is scheduled for open reduction and internal fixation of a distal radius fracture. Under ultrasound guidance, which nerve block is being performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supraclavicular brachial plexus block

 

  • The supraclavicular block targets the brachial plexus at the level of the trunks/divisions, seen as a “cluster of grapes” lateral and superior to the subclavian artery on ultrasound. 
  • It provides dense anesthesia of the entire upper limb distal to the shoulder and is often called the “spinal of the upper limb” due to its rapid, complete blockade.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interscalene brachial plexus block: The interscalene block is performed higher up in the neck, between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, targeting the roots of the brachial plexus. It is best suited for shoulder and upper arm surgeries but often spares the ulnar nerve distribution.

 

Option C. Infraclavicular brachial plexus block: This block targets the cords of the brachial plexus, located deeper beneath the clavicle around the axillary artery. On ultrasound, the artery is seen beneath the pectoral muscles, not in the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Option D. Axillary brachial plexus block: The axillary block is done distally in the axilla at the level of the terminal branches. On ultrasound, nerves appear around the axillary artery. It is used for hand and forearm surgery but does not reliably cover the musculocutaneous nerve unless separately targeted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supraclavicular brachial plexus block is performed under ultrasound guidance at the level of the trunks/divisions, visualized as a cluster lateral to the subclavian artery, and provides dense anesthesia for surgeries of the upper limb below the shoulder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, productive cough with greenish sputum, and pleuritic chest pain for 3 days. On examination, his temperature is 39.2°C, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, pulse 118/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles over the right lower lung field. Chest X-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation. Sputum Gram stain reveals Gram-negative rods, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection is strongly suspected. Which of the following antibiotics would not be appropriate for treating this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • Active only against Gram-positive organisms (MRSA, enterococci). 
  • It has no activity against Gram-negative bacteria including Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Appropriate. A third-generation cephalosporin with good antipseudomonal activity.

 

Option C. Cefoperazone: Appropriate. A third-generation cephalosporin with reliable antipseudomonal coverage.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Appropriate. An extended-spectrum ureidopenicillin highly active against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vancomycin, a glycopeptide is effective only against gram positive bacteria and lacks activity against gram negative bacteria like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 
  • In suspected Pseudomonas infections, appropriate choices include piperacillin, cefoperazone, and ceftazidime.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion
Assertion is true but Reason is false
Assertion is false but Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Mannose-binding lectin (MBL) deficiency increases susceptibility to recurrent bacterial infections in infancy but not in adulthood. 

 

Reason: The lectin pathway represents an innate immune response that becomes redundant once adaptive immunity through the classical pathway develops with age.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true but Reason is false 

 

  • The assertion is true. MBL deficiency significantly increases infection risk in infancy (especially 6 months to 2 years) when maternal antibodies wane but the child's adaptive immunity is immature. 
  • Adults with MBL deficiency rarely have increased infections unless immunocompromised. 
  • This age-dependent phenotype makes MBL deficiency one of the most common immunodeficiencies that often goes undiagnosed.
  • The reason is false because it contains a fundamental error. 
  • Both the lectin and alternative pathways are innate immune responses, while only the classical pathway participates in adaptive immunity (through antibodies). 
  • The lectin pathway doesn't become "redundant" - rather, the developing adaptive immune system (antibody production) provides alternative mechanisms for opsonization and complement activation through the classical pathway. 
  • Additionally, the alternative pathway amplification loop remains intact in MBL deficiency, providing backup complement activation. 
  • The reduced infection susceptibility with age reflects maturation of multiple immune mechanisms, not redundancy of the lectin pathway itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

MBL deficiency causes age-dependent immunodeficiency most severe in infancy because mature adaptive immunity compensates through antibody-mediated classical pathway activation, not because the lectin pathway becomes redundant.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with persistent hypercalcemia and low serum phosphate is suspected to have a parathyroid adenoma. Her Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is inconclusive. To aid in surgical planning, the physician wants to identify the exact anatomical location of the suspected lesion. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate for anatomical localization in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4D CT of the neck

 

  • While Tc-99m Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice (IOC) for parathyroid adenoma, it may be inconclusive in cases of:
    • Small adenomas
    • Ectopic or retrotracheal glands
    • Multiglandular disease
  • In such cases, a contrast-enhanced CT of the neck, especially 4D-CT, provides precise anatomical localization by assessing:
    • Perfusion patterns
    • Washout characteristics
    • Exact relationship to surrounding structures
  • This is particularly helpful in pre-operative planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neck ultrasound: Good for superficial parathyroid adenomas, but limited for deep/ectopic glands and operator-dependent.

 

Option B. Thyroid function test: Has no role in localization of parathyroid adenomas; used for thyroid disorders.

 

Option C. FDG-PET scan: Used for malignancy workup; not the standard modality for parathyroid adenoma detection due to low sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with inconclusive sestamibi scans, contrast-enhanced CT or 4D-CT neck provides the most accurate anatomical localization of parathyroid adenomas and is crucial for guiding surgery.

choices.text: Involvement of only the proximal interphalangeal joints of a digit

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 10-year history of psoriasis presents with dactylitis and tenderness in the sacroiliac joints. Which of the following findings suggest a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mouse ear sign on X-ray

 

  • The patient has psoriasis, dactylitis (sausage digits), and sacroiliac joint tenderness, which are consistent with psoriatic arthritis (PsA). 
  • PsA is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy often associated with psoriasis, presenting with asymmetrical oligoarthritis, dactylitis, enthesitis, and sometimes axial involvement (e.g., sacroiliitis). Radiographic findings are key to diagnosis.
  • The mouse ear sign on X-ray is a characteristic radiographic feature of PsA. It describes erosions with fluffy periostitis (new bone formation), resembling mouse ears, due to bone proliferation and enthesitis. This sign, along with the "ray sign" (involvement of all joints in one digit), supports the diagnosis in this patient with dactylitis and sacroiliac tenderness.
  • Supporting Features: PsA typically involves distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, is asymmetrical (except in ~15% of cases), and is seronegative (negative rheumatoid factor). Dactylitis and sacroiliitis further align with PsA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive rheumatoid factor: False. PsA is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, meaning rheumatoid factor (RF) is typically negative. A positive RF would suggest rheumatoid arthritis (RA) rather than PsA, making this finding inconsistent with the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Bilateral symmetric disease: False. While PsA can occasionally present with symmetric arthritis (in ~15% of cases), the most common presentation is asymmetrical oligoarthritis. Bilateral symmetric disease is more characteristic of RA, not PsA, and thus does not strongly suggest PsA in this context.

 

Option D. Involvement of only the proximal interphalangeal joints of a digit: False. PsA predominantly affects the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the hands and feet, often with dactylitis (sausage digits). Isolated involvement of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints is more typical of RA, not PsA, and contradicts the patient’s dactylitis presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mouse ear sign on X-ray, indicating erosions with periostitis, is a diagnostic feature of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Psoriatic arthritis is characterized by negative rheumatoid factor and predominantly asymmetrical joint involvement.
  • Dactylitis and sacroiliac tenderness support psoriatic arthritis, with DIP joint predominance over PIP joints.

choices.text: The proportion of true negatives correctly identified
The model’s accuracy in balanced datasets
The overall improvement in prediction over random chance

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with worsening fatigue and weight loss. Initial laboratory testing reveals normocytic anemia.
