Her physician suspects an underlying malignancy and orders a tumor marker panel, which includes a logistic regression–based risk model. The lab presents the results along with a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve comparing the model (orange curve) to a no-skill classifier (blue dashed line). Based on the ROC curve shown, what does the area between the model’s curve and the diagonal line most accurately represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The overall improvement in prediction over random chance

 

  • The ROC curve plots the true positive rate (sensitivity) against the false positive rate (1-specificity) for various threshold settings of a diagnostic test or predictive model.
  • The diagonal line (No Skill) represents a model with no discriminative ability—essentially, random guessing.
  • The area under the ROC curve (AUC) reflects the probability that a randomly chosen positive case will be ranked higher than a randomly chosen negative case.
  • Therefore, the area between the model’s curve and the diagonal line represents how much better the model performs than random chance.
  • In this image, the logistic regression model shows excellent discriminative performance with an AUC likely >0.9.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The proportion of true negatives correctly identified: This refers to specificity, which is only one point on the ROC curve, not the area under or between curves.

 

Option B. The prevalence of the disease: Prevalence impacts positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) but not the shape or interpretation of the ROC curve, which is prevalence-independent.

 

Option C. The model’s accuracy in balanced datasets: Accuracy considers both false positives and false negatives but is not directly represented by the ROC curve. Also, ROC does not require balanced datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The area between a predictive model’s ROC curve and the diagonal line (no-skill) reflects the model’s improvement over random guessing. 
  • The greater this area, the better the model’s discriminative ability.

choices.text: Culex larvae have evolved genetic resistance to Paris Green
Anopheles larvae are bottom feeders that ingest more poison
Paris Green is a surface-active contact insecticide
Anopheles larvae feed near the surface, increasing exposure to ingested toxin

questions.text: A public health team is conducting a vector control program in a malaria-endemic region. They decide to use Paris Green as a larvicide to control mosquito populations. After several days, the team notes significant reduction in Anopheles larvae but not much impact on Culex larvae. Which of the following best explains why Paris Green is more effective against Anopheles larvae than Culex larvae?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anopheles larvae feed near the surface, increasing exposure to ingested toxin

 

  • Paris Green is a stomach poison larvicide, most effective when ingested by mosquito larvae. 
  • Anopheles larvae typically feed at the surface of stagnant water, where Paris Green particles accumulate, leading to greater ingestion and mortality. 
  • This feeding behavior enhances the effectiveness of the larvicide specifically against Anopheles mosquitoes, which are vectors of malaria.
  • In contrast, Culex larvae are bottom feeders, making them less exposed to Paris Green unless a special granular formulation is used to target bottom dwellers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Culex larvae have evolved genetic resistance to Paris Green: Incorrect. The reduced efficacy of Paris Green against Culex is due to behavioral feeding differences, not resistance.

 

Option B. Anopheles larvae are bottom feeders that ingest more poison: Incorrect. This is the opposite of what is true. Anopheles larvae feed near the surface, not the bottom.

 

Option C. Paris Green is a surface-active contact insecticide: Incorrect. Paris Green acts as a stomach poison, not a contact insecticide. Its action depends on ingestion, not surface contact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paris Green is a stomach poison larvicide that is most effective against surface-feeding mosquito larvae, such as Anopheles, due to their feeding behavior at the water surface.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus, a BMI of 34 kg/m², presents with exercise intolerance.  On evaluation she is found to have heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Which of the following can be beneficial in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tirzepatide

 

  • The patient has type 2 diabetes (BMI 34 kg/m² indicates obesity), a known risk factor for HFpEF, which is characterized by left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) ≥50% with diastolic dysfunction. 
  • Tirzepatide, a dual GIP/GLP-1 receptor agonist, is approved for glycemic control and weight loss, with emerging evidence for cardiovascular benefits.
  • Tirzepatide can be beneficial. 
  • Clinical trials (e.g., SURPASS program, SURPASS-CVOT) demonstrate significant HbA1c reduction, weight loss (up to 15–20% of body weight), and cardiovascular risk reduction in type 2 diabetes. 
  • Subgroup analyses and ongoing studies (e.g., SUMMIT trial) suggest potential benefits in HFpEF by improving metabolic health, reducing inflammation, and alleviating volume overload, making it a promising option for this obese diabetic patient with HFpEF. 
  • Dosing starts at 2.5 mg weekly, titrated to 5–15 mg based on tolerance.
  • The patient’s obesity (BMI 34) and diabetes align with tirzepatide’s indications, and its cardiorenal protective effects are under investigation, supporting its use in HFpEF management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: Not optimal here. While metformin is a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes, it is less effective for weight loss (minimal effect, ~2–3 kg) and has no direct benefit in HFpEF. It is contraindicated in severe heart failure (NYHA IV) or unstable conditions due to lactic acidosis risk, though this patient’s stability is unspecified. Its benefit is limited compared to tirzepatide in this context.

 

Option C. Insulin glargine: Not optimal here. Insulin glargine controls hyperglycemia but often leads to weight gain (1–3 kg), which could worsen HFpEF in this obese patient. It lacks evidence for improving HFpEF outcomes and is less preferred when weight loss is a goal, unlike tirzepatide.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Not optimal here. Spironolactone, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, is beneficial in HFpEF (e.g., TOPCAT trial showed reduced hospitalizations), but it primarily manages fluid overload and has no direct effect on diabetes or weight. It complements but does not address the patient’s metabolic needs as effectively as tirzepatide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tirzepatide improves glycemic control and promotes weight loss (5–15 mg weekly), benefiting obese diabetic patients with HFpEF.
  • Metformin and insulin glargine address diabetes but lack weight loss benefits and HFpEF-specific effects.
  • Spironolactone reduces HFpEF hospitalizations but does not target diabetes or obesity.

choices.text: S. mansoni – Terminal-spined eggs in stool
S. japonicum – Acid-fast, lateral-spined eggs in urine
S. haematobium – Terminal-spined eggs in urine
S. mansoni – Rudimentary lateral spine and stool-negative

questions.text: Which of the following Schistosoma species is correctly paired with its diagnostic feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S. haematobium – Terminal-spined eggs in urine

 

  • Schistosoma haematobium is the only Schistosoma species that resides in the vesical venous plexus and sheds eggs with a terminal spine into the urine.
  • Its clinical manifestations include urinary schistosomiasis, hematuria, and increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Eggs are most accurately detected in urine around midday, and antigen tests (e.g., CCA detection) may support recent infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. mansoni – Terminal-spined eggs instool: Incorrect. This species produces lateral-spined eggs excreted in stool, not urine.

 

Option B. S. japonicum – Acid-fast, lateral-spined eggs in urine: Incorrect. Eggs are found in stool, have a rudimentary Knob, and are not acid-fast.

 

Option D. S. mansoni – Rudimentary lateral spine and stool-negative: Incorrect – Eggs of S. mansoni have a well-developed lateral spine, not rudimentary, and are stool-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Egg morphology and route of excretion (urine vs. stool) are key to differentiating Schistosoma species:
    • S. haematobium → Terminal spine, urine
    • S. mansoni → Lateral spine, stool
    • S. japonicum → Rudimentary knob, stool

choices.text: Epidemic curves always show multiple peaks per year
Endemic curves have a flat baseline when incidence is low
Endemic curves never touch zero, while epidemic curves may begin at or return to zero
Epidemic curves cannot display seasonal variation

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a feature that distinguishes an endemic curve from an epidemic curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endemic curves never touch zero, while epidemic curves may begin at or return to zero

 

  • An endemic disease is one that is constantly present within a given population or geographic area. 
  • As a result, the incidence line on a graph never touches zero, reflecting ongoing transmission at a stable baseline level.
  • In contrast, an epidemic refers to an unusual rise in the number of cases above the expected level. 
  • An epidemic curve typically begins at or near zero, shows a sharp rise, and then returns to zero or baseline once the outbreak is controlled.
  • This fundamental difference in baseline presence vs transient spike is a key graphical feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic curves always show multiple peaks per year: Incorrect. Epidemic curves can be single-peaked (point-source outbreaks) or multi-peaked (continuous or propagated outbreaks), but not always multiple peaks per year. The number of peaks is not a reliable distinguishing factor.

 

Option B. Endemic curves have a flat baseline when incidence is low: Incorrect. The baseline may fluctuate slightly due to seasonal variation, population dynamics, or surveillance sensitivity. "Flat" is not necessarily a distinguishing term. The key is consistency, not flatness.

 

Option D. Epidemic curves cannot display seasonal variation: Incorrect. Epidemics can certainly show seasonal patterns, such as flu outbreaks in winter. Seasonal epidemics still qualify as epidemics if they exceed the expected threshold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic diseases persist in a population at a stable rate with seasonal fluctuations but do not disappear. 
  • Holoendemic diseases primarily affect young children due to early-life exposure, whereas hyperendemic diseases affect all age groups at high prevalence. 
  • The product of R0 and the proportion susceptible (S) being equal to 1 defines a steady endemic state. 
  • Endemic curves fluctuate over time but never drop to zero.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents at 37 weeks in early labor. After a few hours, the patient complains of leaking per vaginum. The CTG shows a prolonged deceleration, and on vaginal examination, the cord is felt in the vagina. The cervix is 8 cm dilated. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lift the presenting part up

 

  • The patient is experiencing a cord prolapse, a true obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord descends into the vagina ahead of the presenting part of the fetus, leading to cord compression and fetal distress (as evidenced by the prolonged deceleration on CTG). 
  • Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve pressure on the cord and maintain fetal oxygenation until delivery.
  • The next best step is to lift the presenting part up manually, which will relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and restore blood flow. 
  • This is a temporary measure to prevent cord compression while preparing for immediate delivery, typically via emergency cesarean section.
  • Repositioning the presenting part should be done gently, and the patient should be placed in the knee-chest position or Trendelenburg position to use gravity to further relieve cord compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately reposit the cord: This is incorrect. Attempting to reposit the cord can cause further trauma to the cord and worsen the situation. The focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord.

 

Option C. Apply forceps: Forceps are used for assisted vaginal delivery but are not appropriate here, as the cervix is only 8 cm dilated. Additionally, an emergency cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery in the case of cord prolapse with fetal distress.

 

Option D. Cord blood sampling: This is not appropriate in the acute management of cord prolapse. The priority is to relieve the pressure on the cord and deliver the baby as soon as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of umbilical cord prolapse with fetal distress, the immediate priority is to lift the presenting part to relieve pressure on the cord and maintain blood flow. 
  • The patient should then be prepared for emergency cesarean section to expedite delivery and prevent fetal hypoxia.

questions.text:
A medical officer at a block PHC is instructed to enforce the following administrative measures:

 

  • Abolition of private practice among government-employed doctors
  • Ensuring equal pay for equal work among health personnel
  • Integration of medical and paramedical staff into a unified service structure

 

Which committee's recommendations are being implemented through these reforms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jungalwalla

 

  • The Jungalwalla Committee (1967) specifically focused on the integration of health services in India and made recommendations to:
    • Abolish private practice among government doctors
    • Implement equal pay for equal work
    • Create a unified cadre of health personnel under a single administrative structure
  • These structural reforms were aimed at streamlining public health delivery and reducing fragmentation across various vertical programs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shrivastava: Focused on creating a cadre of para-professionals and health volunteers at the village level and recommended the creation of health manpower planning and medical education reforms.

 

Option C. Kartar Singh: Known for introducing multipurpose health workers (MPWs) and establishing norms for subcenter staffing (1 male + 1 female MPW per 5,000 population).

 

Option D. Mudaliar: Primarily aimed at strengthening secondary-level health care (1 PHC for 40,000), AIHS (All India Health Services) and improving quality of services after the Bhore Committee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jungalwalla Committee (1967) is pivotal for:
    • Advocating equal pay,
    • Banning private practice in public health, and
    • Creating a unified health service.
  • It worked in conjunction with the Chadah and Kartar Singh Committees, which shaped staffing patterns and multipurpose worker deployment at PHC and sub-centre levels.

choices.text: Etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine (EMA-CO)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman undergoes exploratory laparotomy for a pelvic mass. Intraoperatively, she is found to have bilateral ovarian tumors with extensive omental involvement. Frozen section confirms advanced epithelial ovarian carcinoma. Following optimal cytoreductive surgery, she is scheduled to begin adjuvant chemotherapy. Which of the following regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboplatin, paclitaxel

 

  • Advanced epithelial ovarian cancer (stages II–IV), especially with extensive omental involvement as in this case, requires combined modality treatment:
    1. Primary cytoreductive surgery: Goal is to remove as much visible tumor as possible (optimal debulking).
    2. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Standard regimen is a platinum compound plus a taxane:
      • Carboplatin (preferred over cisplatin for less nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, and emetogenicity)
      • Paclitaxel (Taxol)
  • Multiple randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that carboplatin + paclitaxel improves progression-free survival and overall survival in women with epithelial ovarian carcinoma after optimal debulking. 
  • This combination is used as first-line adjuvant therapy for Stage IC and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine (EMA-CO): Incorrect. The combination of etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine is used for high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), not epithelial ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Bleomycin, etoposide, cisplatin (BEP): Incorrect. This regimen is the treatment of choice for malignant ovarian germ cell tumors (e.g., dysgerminoma, yolk sac tumor), not epithelial ovarian carcinoma.

 

Option D. Paclitaxel, doxorubicin, cisplatin (TAP): Incorrect. Although TAP has been studied for ovarian carcinoma, it is associated with higher toxicity and has not shown superiority over carboplatin + paclitaxel. Current guidelines recommend carboplatin + paclitaxel as the preferred first-line regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For advanced epithelial ovarian carcinoma after optimal cytoreductive surgery, the standard adjuvant chemotherapy is carboplatin plus paclitaxel, which has proven survival benefit and lower toxicity compared to older regimens.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with pulsatile proptosis, conjunctival chemosis, and an audible orbital bruit. His symptoms developed gradually after a history of head trauma 3 months ago. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF)

 

  • The clinical triad of:
    • Pulsatile proptosis
    • Chemosis
    • Orbital bruit
  • Combined with the DSA finding of early contrast opacification of the cavernous sinus with drainage into an enlarged superior ophthalmic vein (seen in the image) is diagnostic of carotid-cavernous fistula.
  • This condition typically occurs due to trauma, creating a direct high-flow communication between the intracavernous internal carotid artery and the venous cavernous sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Presents with fever, cranial nerve palsies, and painful ophthalmoplegia, but no pulsatile proptosis or bruit. Venous drainage is obstructed, not enhanced.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Causes painful eye movements, eyelid erythema, and fever; usually secondary to sinusitis. No vascular findings on DSA.

 

Option D. Internal carotid artery dissection: May present with headache and stroke symptoms. DSA would show a string sign or flap, not early venous filling or orbital drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is an abnormal high-flow communication between the intracavernous internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus, classically presenting with pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and orbital bruit. 
  • DSA shows early venous opacification and superior ophthalmic vein engorgement. 
  • Prompt diagnosis is essential to prevent vision loss.

choices.text: Cohort studies are the most reliable method to understand natural history, despite being resource-intensive
The clinical horizon represents the point where clinical signs first appear
Prepathogenesis phase includes the interaction of host and agent inside the human body
The concept of “interaction of host, agent, and environment” forms the basis of disease distribution

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the natural history of disease are correct, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prepathogenesis phase includes the interaction of host and agent inside the human body

 

  • The prepathogenesis phase refers to the stage before the disease enters the host’s body. 
  • At this stage, there may be interactions among the host, agent, and environment, but no pathologic or clinical changes have begun inside the body. 
  • The interaction is external, and this is the stage where primary prevention strategies (like vaccination or health education) are most effective.
  • In contrast, pathogenesis begins when the agent successfully invades the host, leading to subclinical and eventually clinical disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort studies are the most reliable method to understand natural history, despite being resource-intensive: Correct. Cohort studies allow for observation of disease progression over time, from exposure to outcome, and are ideal for studying natural history.

 

Option B. The clinical horizon represents the point where clinical signs first appear: Correct. The clinical horizon is the boundary between the subclinical and clinical phases of disease. Before this, the disease is asymptomatic.

 

Option D. The concept of “interaction of host, agent, and environment” forms the basis of disease distribution: Correct. This is the cornerstone of the epidemiologic triad and is fundamental in public health for understanding and preventing disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The prepathogenesis phase involves interaction between agent, host, and environment before disease enters the host's body. 
  • It does not include internal pathologic changes.

choices.text: A normal heart rate in anorexia nervosa may indicate heart failure.
Thiamine should be given before refeeding.
Start with 1400–1600 kcal/day, avoid rapid caloric increases, and monitor electrolytes.
Respiratory complications are the leading cause of mortality.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa (BMI 12.8 kg/m², 66% ideal body weight) is admitted for nutritional rehabilitation. On day 3, she develops dyspnea, and leg edema with jugular venous distension and bibasilar crackles. Which statement about the condition in this patient is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory complications are the leading cause of mortality.

 

  • The patient’s severe malnutrition (BMI 12.8 kg/m², <70% ideal body weight) indicate high refeeding syndrome risk. 
  • Day 3 symptoms (dyspnea, edema, jugular venous distension, crackles) suggest congestive heart failure from fluid overload and hypophosphatemia-induced myocardial dysfunction.
  • Cardiac complications (heart failure, arrhythmias) are the primary cause of mortality in refeeding syndrome due to hypophosphatemia and volume overload in a starved, atrophied heart. 
  • Respiratory complications (e.g., diaphragmatic weakness) are rare and usually secondary to heart failure; no primary respiratory failure is noted here.
  • Management includes reducing calories, administering IV furosemide for heart failure, and correcting phosphorus/potassium with close monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A normal heart rate in anorexia nervosa may indicate heart failure: True. Bradycardia is typical in anorexia nervosa (baseline 55/min); a rise to 80/min with edema and crackles signals heart failure from fluid overload or hypophosphatemia, a critical refeeding syndrome feature.

 

Option B. Thiamine should be given before refeeding: True. Thiamine (100–200 mg daily for 3–5 days) prevents Wernicke encephalopathy during refeeding, as carbohydrate metabolism increases thiamine demand. The patient received 100 mg IV appropriately, with no Wernicke symptoms (e.g., confusion, nystagmus).

 

Option C. Start with 1400–1600 kcal/day, avoid rapid caloric increases, and monitor electrolytes: True. Starting at 1400–1600 kcal/day is standard, though 1200 kcal/day is cautious for severe malnutrition. Avoiding rapid caloric increases and daily electrolyte monitoring (especially phosphorus) are critical to prevent shifts, given the low-normal baseline phosphorus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiac complications are the leading cause of mortality in refeeding syndrome in severely malnourished anorexia nervosa patients. 
  • Cautious refeeding (≤1400 kcal/day), pre-refeeding thiamine, and vigilant electrolyte monitoring is important to prevent life-threatening complications.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with multiple papules along the forearm and axillary lymphadenopathy 10 days after playing with neighborhood cats. Which of the following organisms can be transmitted through cat scratches or bites?

 

  1. Bartonella henselae
  2. Bartonella bacilliformis
  3. Pasteurella multocida
  4. Bartonella vinsonii
  5. Yersinia pestis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3 and 5 only

 

Cat bites and scratches can transmit specific pathogens from their oral flora or contaminated claws. 

 

Statement 1. Bartonella henselae: Is the causative agent of cat scratch disease, residing in cat erythrocytes and transmitted via scratches contaminated with infected flea feces. The organism causes regional lymphadenopathy with papules at inoculation sites. 

 

Statement 3. Pasteurella multocida: Is present in oral flora of 70-90% of cats and causes rapidly progressive cellulitis within 24 hours of bites or deep scratches. 

 

Statement 5. Yersinia pestis: Can be transmitted by cats that hunt plague-infected rodents, either through bites from infected cats or via their fleas, particularly in endemic areas of southwestern United States. Cats can develop pneumonic plague and transmit it through respiratory droplets or bites.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Bartonella bacilliformis: Causes Carrion's disease (Oroya fever and verruga peruana), transmitted exclusively by Lutzomyia sandflies in Andean regions of South America, not associated with cats

 

Statement 4. Bartonella vinsonii: Primarily a canine pathogen with subspecies berkhoffii affecting dogs; not transmitted by cats

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cat bites and scratches transmit Bartonella henselae (cat scratch disease), Pasteurella multocida (cellulitis), and potentially Yersinia pestis (plague in endemic areas).

choices.text: It is a blood-sucking bug using cyclo-propagative transmission
It is a reduviid bug using mechanical transmission
It is a reduviid bug using cyclo-developmental transmission
It is a sandfly using propagative transmission

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, periorbital edema, and signs of congestive heart failure. He is diagnosed with Chagas disease. If a researcher is studying the vector responsible for this disease, which of the following is most accurate regarding the vector’s classification and mode of transmission?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a reduviid bug using cyclo-developmental transmission

 

  • Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, and the vector responsible is the reduviid bug, also known as the "kissing bug" or Triatomine bug.
  • Vector Classification: Reduviid bug (Triatoma species)
    • Belongs to the family Reduviidae
    • Hematophagous (blood-sucking) insect
    • Nocturnal, bites typically near the lips and eyes
  • Transmission Type: Cyclo-developmental transmission
    • The parasite undergoes development but no multiplication in the vector.
    • Trypanosoma cruzi matures in the hindgut of the bug.
    • Transmission occurs via contamination of the bite wound with bug feces, not via saliva (unlike mosquitoes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a blood-sucking bug using cyclo-propagative transmission: Incorrect. This involves both development and multiplication, as seen in malaria (Plasmodium in Anopheles mosquito). Not applicable to T. cruzi.

 

Option B. It is a reduviid bug using mechanical transmission: Incorrect. Chagas disease is biologically transmitted, not mechanically. Mechanical transmission means no parasite development inside the vector (e.g., flies carrying bacteria).

 

Option D. It is a sandfly using propagative transmission: Incorrect. Sandflies are vectors of Leishmania, not T. cruzi. Propagative: multiplication without developmental changes (e.g., arboviruses in mosquitoes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reduviid bugs transmit Trypanosoma cruzi via cyclo-developmental transmission.

questions.text: A researcher is working on the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology. In the process, B cells are fused with immortal cell lines to generate hybrid cells that produce identical antibodies indefinitely. From which of the following are these monoclonal antibody-producing cells derived?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensitized B cells

 

  • Hybridoma technology is used to produce monoclonal antibodies (mAbs).
  • The process includes:
    • Immunizing a mouse with a specific antigen
    • Isolating sensitized (antigen-exposed) B lymphocytes from its spleen
    • Fusing these B cells with immortal myeloma cells (which lack antibody-producing ability)
    • Resulting in a hybridoma — a cell that combines:
      • The specific antibody-producing ability of B cells
      • The immortality of the myeloma cell line
      • This fusion enables continuous production of identical antibodies (monoclonal).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Sensitized T cells: T cells do not produce antibodies. Their role is in cell-mediated immunity, not humoral antibody production.

 

Option C. Myeloma cell lines: These provide the immortal property, but they do not produce antibodies on their own. They are fused with B cells to enable hybridoma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Monoclonal antibodies are generated by fusing sensitized B lymphocytes with immortal myeloma cells to form hybridomas. 
  • The B cells contribute antibody specificity, while myeloma cells contribute immortality.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is produced specifically from the oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propionyl CoA

 

  • During β-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, all but the final three-carbon fragment are broken down into acetyl-CoA units. 
  • The remaining three-carbon fragment is propionyl-CoA, a unique product not generated during even-chain fatty acid oxidation.
  • Metabolic fate of propionyl-CoA:
    1. Propionyl-CoA → (propionyl-CoA carboxylase, biotin-dependent) → methylmalonyl-CoA
    2. Methylmalonyl-CoA → (methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, vitamin B₁₂-dependent) → succinyl-CoA
    3. Succinyl-CoA enters the TCA cycle or can serve as a gluconeogenic precursor.

 

Key link:

 

  • "Produced as a result of oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids" → uniquely propionyl-CoA.
  • Even-chain fatty acids only yield acetyl-CoA and do not produce propionyl-CoA.
  • Propionyl-CoA metabolism requires biotin and vitamin B₁₂; deficiencies in these cofactors can cause methylmalonic acidemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fumaryl CoA: Incorrect. Not produced by fatty acid oxidation; it is an intermediate in tyrosine and phenylalanine catabolism.

 

Option B. Acetoacetyl CoA: Incorrect. Formed during ketone body synthesis and degradation of certain amino acids; not the unique final product of odd-chain fatty acid oxidation.

 

Option D. Malonyl CoA: Incorrect. Produced during fatty acid synthesis, not oxidation. It inhibits carnitine palmitoyltransferase I to prevent simultaneous fatty acid synthesis and breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Odd-chain fatty acid oxidation produces propionyl-CoA as the final three-carbon fragment, which is converted to succinyl-CoA via biotin- and vitamin B₁₂-dependent enzymes, enabling entry into the TCA cycle and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
Match the type of discharge/condition (A–D) with the appropriate color-coded NACO STI/RTI kit: 

 

  1. Urethral, anorectal, or cervical discharge
  2. Vaginal discharge (Vaginitis)
  3. Lower abdominal pain (Pelvic inflammatory disease)
  4. Inguinal bubo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A–1, B–2, C–3, D–4

 

A–1. Urethral, anorectal, or cervical discharge – Kit 1 (Grey): Contains Azithromycin 1 g and Cefixime 800 mg. Used for gonorrhea and chlamydia syndromes.

 

B–2. Vaginal discharge – Kit 2 (Green): Contains Secnidazole 2 g and Fluconazole 150 mg. Targets bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, and candidiasis.

 

C–3. Lower abdominal pain (PID) – Kit 6 (Yellow): Contains Cefixime 800 mg (single dose), Cap. Doxycycline 100 mg (28 capsules) as twice day dose for 14 days and Metronidazole 400 mg BD for 14 days. 

 

D–4. Inguinal bubo – Kit 7 (Black): Contains Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 21 days. Used for lymphogranuloma venereum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NACO color-coded STI kits provide syndromic management: Grey (discharge), Green (vaginitis), Yellow (PID), Black (inguinal bubo), ensuring standardized treatment at all levels of healthcare.

questions.text: A 4-week-old neonate presents with progressive jaundice, hepatomegaly, and pale stools. A liver biopsy demonstrates marked proliferation of bile ducts, portal tract edema and fibrosis, and extensive intrahepatic and canalicular bile stasis. Despite supportive care, the jaundice worsens, and the infant dies of liver failure at 9 months of age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary atresia

 

  • This 3-week-old neonate with progressive jaundice, hepatomegaly, and pale stools plus biopsy findings of marked bile duct proliferation, portal tract edema and fibrosis, and extensive intrahepatic/canalicular bile stasis is most consistent with biliary atresia.
  • Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts. 
  • It presents in early infancy with:
    • Persistent conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (cholestasis)
    • Pale (acholic) stools due to lack of bile pigment in stool
    • Dark urine due to increased conjugated bilirubin excretion
    • Hepatomegaly and progressive portal fibrosis → cirrhosis → liver failure
  • Death usually occurs within the first year of life if not surgically corrected (Kasai procedure or transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson disease: An autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism, presenting later in childhood/adolescence with neurologic dysfunction, hemolytic anemia, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. It does not present in early infancy with biliary obstruction findings.

 

Option C. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency: Can present in neonates with cholestasis and later in adults with panacinar emphysema and cirrhosis, but the classic histology shows PAS-positive, diastase-resistant globules in hepatocytes, not the bile duct proliferation and portal fibrosis seen here.

 

Option D. Neonatal hemochromatosis: A rare cause of neonatal liver failure due to iron overload, showing iron deposition in hepatocytes and extrahepatic tissues. It does not cause the ductal proliferation and fibrosis described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts in neonates, causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, pale stools, hepatomegaly, and ultimately liver failure within the first year of life.

questions.text: Genetic analysis reveals misincorporation of uracil into DNA in place of thymine. This defect results from impaired conversion of deoxyuridylate (dUMP) to thymidylate (dTMP) due to a deficiency in a vitamin. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B9

 

  • Uracil misincorporation occurs when thymidylate synthase activity is impaired. 
  • This enzyme requires methylene tetrahydrofolate as a methyl donor, derived from tetrahydrofolate (THF).
  • Vitamin B9 (folate) is essential for THF production.
  • Folate deficiency → ↓ methylene THF → dUMP cannot be methylated to dTMP → uracil replaces thymine in DNA.
  • This leads to defective DNA synthesis and megaloblastic changes in rapidly dividing cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin is a precursor of FAD and FMN, important in redox reactions, but not directly involved in thymidylate synthesis.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Thiamine is a cofactor in carbohydrate metabolism (pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, transketolase) and is unrelated to uracil incorporation.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, but uracil misincorporation is primarily due to folate-dependent thymidylate synthesis failure; B12 deficiency causes folate trapping indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency impairs the conversion of dUMP to dTMP by thymidylate synthase, leading to uracil incorporation into DNA and defective DNA synthesis.

choices.text: Open inguinal hernia repair: Clean wound
Incision and drainage of breast abscess: Clean-contaminated wound

questions.text: Identify the mismatched type of surgical wound.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage of breast abscess: Clean-contaminated wound

 

  • An abscess already contains pus, which means active infection is present.
  • By definition, wounds with existing clinical infection or gross contamination are Class IV (Dirty), not clean-contaminated.
  • Hence, this option is mismatched.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open inguinal hernia repair: Clean wound:

 

  • Hernia repair does not involve entry into the respiratory, alimentary, or genitourinary tract.
  • It is performed under sterile conditions without infection → Class I (Clean).
  • This is correctly matched.

 

Option C. Open cardiac massage: Contaminated wound:

 

  • This involves opening the chest in an emergency (often non-sterile circumstances).
  • Such emergency operations without sterile preparation are considered Class III (Contaminated).
  • This is correctly matched.

 

Option D. Diabetic wet gangrene: Dirty wound:

 

  • Presence of necrotic, devitalized tissue with infection is Class IV (Dirty).
  • This is correctly matched.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clean wounds have no infection or entry into viscera, clean-contaminated wounds involve controlled entry into viscera, contaminated wounds include fresh accidental or emergency surgeries with contamination, and dirty wounds involve existing infection or devitalized tissue.
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess is always a dirty wound, not clean-contaminated.

questions.text:
Which of the following mediators are primarily involved in the early phase of type I hypersensitivity reaction? 

 

  1. Mast cells
  2. Histamine
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Prostaglandins
  5. Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

  • The early phase of type I hypersensitivity (minutes after allergen exposure) is mediated by mast cell degranulation.
  • 1 and 2: Mast cells and Histamine: Mast cells release →  Histamine → causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and bronchoconstriction.
  • 4. Prostaglandins: Contribute to vasodilation and edema.
  • 5. Leukotrienes: Cause prolonged bronchoconstriction and vascular permeability.
  • These mediators explain acute allergic manifestations such as urticaria, bronchospasm, and angioedema.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

3. Neutrophils: Incorrect. Are not early mediators. Neutrophils participate in late phase reactions, several hours after allergen exposure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The early phase of type I hypersensitivity is mediated by mast cell degranulation releasing histamine, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes.
  • Neutrophils are not involved in the early phase but play a role in late-phase responses.

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer, without perineural invasion. What would be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) No further treatment

 

Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumour penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perform extended cholecystectomy: This is required for T1b (muscle invasive) Ca GB.

 

Option C. Adjuvant chemotherapy: This is required in T1b or higher stages of Ca GB.

 

Option D. Radiation: This is not usually needed in treatment of Ca Gb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Treatment options for carcinoma gall bladder found incidentally after cholecystectomy:
    • T1a with negative margins: Standard cholecystectomy
    • T1a with perineural/ lymphatic/ vascular invasion: Extended cholecystectomy Chemotherapy is not required in an early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.
    • T1b: Extended cholecystectomy, No need for port site excision.

choices.text: Microorganisms that commonly cause IE isolated from 2 or more separate blood culture sets
Microorganisms that occasionally or rarely cause IE, isolated from 3 or more separate blood culture sets
Positive PCR or other nucleic acid-based technique from blood for Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella spp, or Tropheryma whipplei
Abnormal metabolic activity detected by 18FDG PET/CT within 3 months of implantation of prosthetic valve

questions.text: A 32-year-old intravenous drug user presents with fever, weight loss, and a new systolic murmur. Echocardiography reveals a vegetation on the tricuspid valve, raising suspicion for infective endocarditis. Which of the following is not included in the major 2023 Duke-ISCVID IE Criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormal metabolic activity detected by 18FDG PET/CT within 3 months of implantation of prosthetic valve

 

  • The patient’s presentation (fever, weight loss, systolic murmur, tricuspid valve vegetation in an intravenous drug user) strongly suggests infective endocarditis (IE), commonly associated with Staphylococcus aureus in this population. 
  • The 2023 Duke-ISCVID Criteria for IE include major and minor criteria to guide diagnosis, with major criteria focusing on microbiologic evidence and imaging findings.
  • The 2023 Duke-ISCVID Criteria include [18F]-FDG PET/CT showing abnormal metabolic activity as a major criterion for prosthetic valve endocarditis or cardiac device-related IE, but only after 3 months post-implantation to avoid false positives from post-surgical inflammation. Abnormal activity within 3 months of implantation is not considered a major criterion, as it lacks specificity in this timeframe.
  • The major criteria include microbiologic evidence (options A, B, C) and specific imaging findings (e.g., echocardiography showing vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation), but option D’s timeframe makes it incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microorganisms that commonly cause IE isolated from 2 or more separate blood culture sets: Included. Common IE pathogens (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp., Enterococcus spp.) isolated from ≥2 separate blood cultures meet a major microbiologic criterion, reflecting definite evidence of bloodstream infection, as likely in this patient with IV drug use.

 

Option B. Microorganisms that occasionally or rarely cause IE, isolated from 3 or more separate blood culture sets: Included. For less common pathogens (e.g., HACEK group), ≥3 separate positive blood cultures are required to confirm their role in IE, ensuring specificity for less typical organisms, a major criterion in the 2023 update.

 

Option C. Positive PCR or other nucleic acid-based technique from blood for Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella spp, or Tropheryma whipplei: Included. Positive PCR for fastidious organisms like Coxiella burnetii (Q fever), Bartonella spp, or Tropheryma whipplei (Whipple’s disease) is a major microbiologic criterion, as these pathogens are difficult to culture and require molecular confirmation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isolation of common IE pathogens (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus) from ≥2 blood cultures is a major Duke-ISCVID criterion.
  • Positive PCR for Coxiella burnetii or Bartonella spp confirms IE as a major criterion for fastidious organisms.
  • [18F]-FDG PET/CT is a major criterion for prosthetic valve IE only after 3 months post-implantation.

choices.text: Sepsis with an increase of ≥2 points in the SOFA score
Requirement of vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg despite adequate fluid resuscitation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. He is diagnosed with urosepsis due to Escherichia coli bacteremia. Despite 30 mL/kg of intravenous fluids, his blood pressure remains low. Which of the following is not used to define septic shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heart rate >100 beats per minute

 

  • The patient’s presentation (fever, tachycardia, hypotension, E. coli bacteremia from urosepsis) and persistent low blood pressure despite adequate fluid resuscitation (30 mL/kg) suggest septic shock. 
  • Per the 2016 Sepsis-3 definitions, sepsis is life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection, defined by an increase of ≥2 points in the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score. 
  • Septic shock is a subset of sepsis with circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities, identified by: 
    1. Meeting sepsis criteria (SOFA score increase ≥2), 
    2. Need for vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥65 mmHg despite adequate fluid resuscitation, and
    3. Serum lactate >2 mmol/L.
  • Heart rate >100 beats per minute is part of the older systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria (pre-2016) but is not a specific component of the Sepsis-3 septic shock definition. 
  • While tachycardia is common in sepsis and septic shock, the Sepsis-3 criteria prioritize organ dysfunction (SOFA score), vasopressor need, and lactate levels for diagnosis.
  • Management includes broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone for E. coli urosepsis), vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine), source control, and ICU monitoring, but the question focuses on diagnostic criteria.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Sepsis with an increase of ≥2 points in the SOFA score: Used in definition. Septic shock requires meeting the criteria for sepsis, defined by a SOFA score increase of ≥2 points due to infection-induced organ dysfunction (e.g., hypotension, renal impairment). This criterion is foundational for diagnosing septic shock in this patient with urosepsis.

 

Option B. Requirement of vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg despite adequate fluid resuscitation: Used in definition. Persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg after adequate fluid resuscitation (30 mL/kg in this case) is a core criterion for septic shock, indicating circulatory failure, as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Serum lactate >2 mmol/L: Used in definition. A lactate level >2 mmol/L reflects cellular and metabolic dysfunction, a hallmark of septic shock, distinguishing it from sepsis alone and indicating higher mortality risk. This criterion applies to this patient’s severe presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sepsis with a SOFA score increase of ≥2 points is required to diagnose septic shock.
  • Vasopressor need to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg after fluid resuscitation is a key septic shock criterion.
  • Serum lactate >2 mmol/L defines metabolic dysfunction in septic shock, unlike heart rate.

choices.text: Primary dengue infection in early phase

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of prior dengue infection presents with symptoms of fever and rash. Serologic testing shows a 4-fold rise in IgG titers without significant IgM levels. What is the most likely interpretation of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary dengue infection

 

  • In secondary dengue infection, the immune system mounts a rapid and robust IgG response, due to prior sensitization to a dengue serotype. 
  • A fourfold rise in IgG titers without a corresponding IgM rise is diagnostic of a secondary infection.
  • This is due to anamnestic response (memory cell activation), where IgG rises rapidly within the first few days, often before IgM has a chance to become significantly detectable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary dengue infection in early phase:

 

  • Incorrect because in primary infection, IgM is the first antibody to appear, usually after day 5, followed by IgG after day 14–21.
  • A fourfold IgG rise early on without IgM is not characteristic of primary infection.

 

Option B. Cross-reactivity with other flaviviruses:

 

  • While flaviviruses share some antigenic components, cross-reactivity does not typically result in a significant (≥4-fold) rise in IgG titers.
  • Additionally, there's clinical context and past dengue history, making cross-reactivity unlikely here.

 

Option C. Past infection with unrelated flavivirus:

 

  • Past flavivirus infection (e.g., Zika or Yellow fever) would not show a fourfold rise in dengue-specific IgG titers.
  • Moreover, the patient is currently symptomatic, indicating an active infection, not a past one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fourfold rise in IgG titers without IgM strongly suggests a secondary dengue infection, particularly in patients with prior exposure to dengue virus.
  • This reflects immunological memory and is a key diagnostic clue in dengue-endemic regions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the last year. Echocardiography shows right ventricular hypertrophy and elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Right heart catheterization confirms pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). She has been started on therapy including endothelin receptor antagonists and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, but her symptoms persist. The physician now prescribes an oral agent that is a prostacyclin (IP) receptor agonist to reduce pulmonary vascular resistance and improve exercise capacity. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selexipag

 

  • Selexipag is an oral prostacyclin (IP) receptor agonist, approved for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
  • Prostacyclin analogues and receptor agonists cause vasodilation, inhibit smooth muscle proliferation, and reduce pulmonary vascular resistance, improving exercise tolerance and delaying disease progression.
  • It provides an oral alternative to intravenous or inhaled prostacyclin analogs like epoprostenol and iloprost.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bosentan: Endothelin receptor antagonist; used in PAH, but acts by blocking endothelin-1, not via prostacyclin receptor.

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor; increases cGMP and vasodilation, also used in PAH, but not a prostacyclin receptor agonist.

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Prostacyclin analogue; used in PAH but is given intravenously, not orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selexipag is an oral prostacyclin (IP) receptor agonist used in pulmonary arterial hypertension to reduce pulmonary vascular resistance, improve exercise capacity, and delay disease progression.

choices.text: It is a gonadotropin release hormone antagonist
It is approved for treatment of pain due to endometriosis
It can cause hot flashes as adverse effect

questions.text: Which of the following statements about elagolix is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is not effective orally

 

  • Elagolix is an orally active gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist. 
  • It is effective when taken by mouth, which makes it a convenient option for patients. 
  • This statement is false because elagolix is indeed effective when administered orally.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is a gonadotropin release hormone antagonist: This statement is true. Elagolix works as a GnRH antagonist, which means it inhibits the action of GnRH and reduces the production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH).

 

Option C. It is approved for treatment of pain due to endometriosis: This statement is true. Elagolix has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis.

 

Option D. It can cause hot flashes as adverse effect: This statement is true. One of the known adverse effects of elagolix is the occurrence of hot flashes, which is related to its mechanism of reducing estrogen levels in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elagolix is an orally active gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist approved for the treatment of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis. 
  • It effectively reduces the production of gonadotropins and estrogen, which can alleviate endometriosis-related pain. 
  • However, its estrogen-lowering effect can lead to side effects such as hot flashes. 
  • Understanding the pharmacokinetics, therapeutic indications, and potential adverse effects of elagolix is crucial for its appropriate use in clinical practice.

choices.text: Endometriosis ablation due to an increased rate of endometriosis
Gonadectomy because retained gonads with Y-chromosome material carry an increased risk of malignant transformation
Oophoropexy due to an increased rate of torsion

questions.text: A 20-year-old phenotypic female with gonadal dysgenesis is found on karyotyping to have 45X/46XY mosaicism. She is counseled regarding laparoscopy. The procedure is planned primarily for which reason?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gonadectomy because retained gonads with Y-chromosome material carry an increased risk of malignant transformation

 

  • In a 20-year-old with gonadal dysgenesis and 45X/46XY mosaicism, the presence of Y-chromosome material in retained gonads (streak/dysgenetic gonads or undescended testicular tissue) confers a substantial risk of malignant transformation (classically gonadoblastoma and dysgerminoma).
  • Therefore, the next step is laparoscopic bilateral gonadectomy to eliminate this increased risk. 
  • This is standard management once the diagnosis is established, particularly in a phenotypic female with 45X/46XY mosaicism, and addresses the precise indication: malignancy prevention in retained gonads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis ablation due to an increased rate of endometriosis: Incorrect. Gonadal dysgenesis with hypoestrogenism/amenorrhea does not confer an increased rate of endometriosis; ablation is not the primary reason for laparoscopy in this setting.

 

Option B. To rule out Müllerian agenesis: Incorrect. Müllerian agenesis (MRKH) is a different diagnosis (typically 46, XX with normal secondary sexual characteristics). In gonadal dysgenesis with 45X/46XY mosaicism, laparoscopy is not performed to “rule out Müllerian agenesis”; imaging (US/MRI) delineates Müllerian structures. The indication here is gonadectomy for malignancy risk, not ruling out agenesis.

 

Option D. Oophoropexy due to an increased rate of torsion: Incorrect. There is no recognized increased rate of torsion in streak/dysgenetic gonads that would justify oophoropexy. The urgent concern in 45X/46XY is malignant transformation, not torsion, making oophoropexy the wrong rationale for laparoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In gonadal dysgenesis with 45X/46XY mosaicism, the presence of Y-chromosome material in retained gonads markedly increases the risk of gonadal malignancy; thus, prophylactic laparoscopic gonadectomy is indicated.

choices.text: Conventional IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) using her own oocytes

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of infertility. She reports regular menstrual cycles but has not conceived despite timed intercourse. Laboratory evaluation reveals very low anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), elevated day-3 FSH, and low antral follicle count on transvaginal ultrasound, consistent with significantly diminished ovarian reserve. Her partner’s semen analysis is normal. Which of the following is the most effective treatment option to help her conceive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Donor egg in vitro fertilization (IVF)

 

  • This patient has significant decline in ovarian reserve—as indicated by low AMH, elevated FSH, and low antral follicle count—which reflects very poor quantity and likely reduced quality of her remaining oocytes.
  • In such cases, conventional ovulation induction or IVF using the patient’s own eggs is associated with extremely low success rates due to poor follicular recruitment and higher rates of aneuploidy.
  • Donor egg IVF bypasses the problem of diminished oocyte quantity and quality by using oocytes from a younger donor with normal ovarian reserve. 
  • These donor eggs are fertilized with sperm from the patient’s partner (or a donor), and the resulting embryos are transferred into the patient’s uterus.
  • This approach offers the highest chance of pregnancy for women with severely diminished ovarian reserve while still allowing them to carry the pregnancy and experience childbirth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadotropin ovulation induction: Incorrect. While high-dose gonadotropins can stimulate follicular development in women with mild to moderate decline in ovarian reserve, they are typically ineffective in cases of severe ovarian depletion where only a few follicles remain.

 

Option C. Clomiphene citrate ovulation induction: Incorrect. Clomiphene works by blocking estrogen receptors, increasing endogenous FSH secretion, and promoting follicular development. In women with very few responsive follicles, this strategy is unlikely to produce viable eggs and thus has poor pregnancy rates in this scenario. Clomiphene is given in patients with anovulation.

 

Option D. Conventional IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) using her own oocytes: Incorrect. While IVF with ICSI can overcome male factor infertility or fertilization issues, it does not address the severe oocyte quantity/quality deficit. Using the patient’s own oocytes in this setting is associated with very low live birth rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In women with severely diminished ovarian reserve, the most effective fertility treatment is donor egg IVF, which replaces the poor-quality, low-quantity oocytes with those from a younger donor, thereby maximizing pregnancy and live birth rates while allowing the patient to carry the pregnancy herself.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with a progressive history of shortness of breath over the past 18 months. Physical examination is unremarkable. Pulmonary function testing demonstrates normal FEV1 but reduced FVC. A chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial markings without evidence of masses or hilar lymphadenopathy. Laboratory testing for ANA and anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

 

  • This 57-year-old man has progressive dyspnea for 18 months, with pulmonary function tests showing normal FEV1 but diminished FVC — a restrictive pattern. 
  • The chest radiograph demonstrates diffuse interstitial disease without hilar adenopathy or masses, and autoimmune serologies (ANA, anti-DNA topoisomerase I) are negative.
  • This clinical picture is most consistent with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a chronic progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of older adults.
  • Key features include:
    • Gradual worsening of exertional dyspnea and dry cough
    • Restrictive physiology on PFTs
    • Interstitial markings on imaging without masses or nodal enlargement
    • Negative autoimmune testing (excludes scleroderma/other connective tissue disease)
  • Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse alveolar damage: Represents the acute phase of ARDS, with rapid respiratory failure due to causes such as sepsis or trauma. The chronic 18-month history excludes this.

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Can cause interstitial lung disease (restrictive lung disease), but is associated with positive ANA or anti-Scl-70 antibodies and systemic findings such as skin thickening, Raynaud phenomenon, which are absent here.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Classically shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, noncaseating granulomas, and systemic involvement (skin, eyes, joints). This patient’s imaging showed no hilar adenopathy, making sarcoidosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis presents in older adults with gradually progressive dyspnea, restrictive lung function, interstitial changes on imaging, and absence of autoimmune markers or hilar lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female falls at home and lands on her outstretched hand. She has wrist pain and swelling. Radiograph is shown below. What is this classic deformity associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colles' fracture

 

  • A Colles' fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with a characteristic dorsal displacement and angulation of the wrist fragment.
  • This creates a "dinner fork" deformity on physical examination.
  • The patient's age and mechanism of injury (fall onto an outstretched hand) are a classic match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galeazzi fracture: 

 

A Galeazzi fracture involves a fracture of the distal radius and a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). 

 

 

  • While it also involves a fall on an outstretched hand, the specific deformity of a Colles' fracture is not present.

 

Option B. Boxer's fracture:

 

  • A Boxer's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone in the hand. 

 

 

  • It is typically caused by punching an object with a closed fist.

 

Option D. Scaphoid fracture: 

 

  • A scaphoid fracture is a break in the scaphoid bone in the wrist, also caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. 

 

 

  • However, it does not typically present with the "dinner fork" deformity. 
  • Pain is localized to the anatomical snuffbox, and the fracture is often difficult to see on a plain radiograph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colles' fracture is a very common fracture of the distal radius, which occurs when a person falls onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents with recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and painful red eye for the past 6 months. He also reports joint pain and skin lesions on his legs. Regarding Behçet's disease, which of the following is true?

 

  1. Uveitis is bilateral, episodic, and may not resolve completely between episodes.
  2. Arthritis is usually asymmetric and non-erosive.
  3. Biopsy of the skin lesions can confirm the diagnosis.
  4. Apremilast can be tried for aphthous ulcers as an alternative to colchicine.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Uveitis is bilateral, episodic, and may not resolve completely between episodes: True. Uveitis in Behçet's disease is a common and serious manifestation, often involving the anterior, posterior, or panuveitis. It is typically bilateral (though not always simultaneously) and occurs in episodic flares. Unlike some other uveitic conditions, the inflammation in Behçet's disease often leaves residual damage (e.g., synechiae, cataracts), meaning it does not fully resolve between episodes, supporting this statement.

 

Statement 2. Arthritis is usually asymmetric and non-erosive: True. Arthritis in Behçet's disease affects approximately 50% of patients, typically involving large joints (e.g., knees, ankles) in an asymmetric pattern. It is generally non-erosive, distinguishing it from rheumatoid arthritis, and tends to be self-limiting, aligning with this statement.

 

Statement 4. Apremilast can be tried for aphthous ulcers as an alternative to colchicine: True. Aphthous ulcers are a hallmark of Behçet's disease, and colchicine is a first-line treatment to reduce their frequency and severity. Apremilast, a phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor, has emerged as an alternative therapy, showing efficacy in reducing oral ulcers in clinical trials (e.g., RELIEF study), making it a viable option when colchicine is ineffective or contraindicated.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Biopsy of the skin lesions can confirm the diagnosis: False. Skin lesions (e.g., erythema nodosum, papulopustular lesions) are a diagnostic criterion for Behçet's disease, but biopsy is not definitive for confirmation. Histopathology may show nonspecific inflammation (e.g., vasculitis, perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate), but the diagnosis relies on clinical criteria (e.g., International Criteria for Behçet's Disease [ICBD]) rather than biopsy alone, as findings are not specific enough to confirm the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uveitis in Behçet's disease is bilateral and episodic with incomplete resolution.
  • Arthritis presents as asymmetric and non-erosive, typical of the disease.
  • Apremilast serves as an effective alternative to colchicine for managing aphthous ulcers.

choices.text: Conidia arising only from the upper third of vesicle
Phialides arranged only in a single row
Conidia arising from entire vesicle; phialides in 1 or 2 rows

questions.text: Which of the following features best helps to distinguish Aspergillus flavus from Aspergillus fumigatus on LPCB microscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conidia arising from entire vesicle; phialides in 1 or 2 rows

 

  • Aspergillus flavus is characterized on LPCB microscopy by:
    • Globular vesicle
    • Conidia arising from the entire surface of the vesicle
    • Phialides arranged in one or two rows (uniseriate or biseriate)
    • Hyaline conidia
  • In contrast, Aspergillus fumigatus displays:
    • Conical vesicle
    • Phialides arranged in a single row (uniseriate)
    • Conidia arise only from the upper third of the vesicle
  • These morphological distinctions are key in differentiating species during laboratory identification, especially in clinical settings involving immunocompromised patients.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conidia arising only from the upper third of vesicle: This is a hallmark feature of Aspergillus fumigatus, not flavus. In flavus, conidia cover the entire vesicle.

 

Option B. Vesicle globular with black conidia: While flavus has a globular vesicle, its conidia are hyaline, not black. Black conidia are seen in Aspergillus niger.

 

Option C. Phialides arranged only in a single row:This is again a feature of Aspergillus fumigatus, not flavus, which shows phialides in one or two rows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus flavus shows conidia arising from the entire globular vesicle and phialides arranged in one or two rows (uniseriate or biseriate) on LPCB mount. 
  • This distinguishes it from Aspergillus fumigatus, which has a conical vesicle with uniseriate phialides restricted to the upper third.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman admitted with severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to COVID-19 develops ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) on day 6. Endotracheal aspirate grows Acinetobacter baumannii resistant to most antibiotics. Which of the following antibiotics is suitable for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefiderocol

 

  • The patient’s severe ARDS due to COVID-19 and development of VAP on day 6 with multidrug-resistant (MDR) Acinetobacter baumannii indicate a critical care scenario requiring targeted antibiotic therapy. 
  • Acinetobacter baumannii is a gram-negative, nosocomial pathogen notorious for extensive drug resistance, including to carbapenems, making treatment challenging.
  • Cefiderocol is a novel siderophore cephalosporin designed to combat MDR gram-negative bacteria, including carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii.
  • It binds to bacterial iron transport systems, facilitating entry into cells, and is effective against strains resistant to meropenem, imipenem, and ceftazidime-avibactam. 
  • Clinical trials (e.g., CREDIBLE-CR) support its use in VAP caused by MDR Acinetobacter, making it suitable for this patient, especially given the resistance profile.
  • Treatment of MDR Acinetobacter VAP often requires combination therapy (e.g., cefiderocol with colistin or tigecycline, guided by susceptibility testing) and supportive care in the ICU, with attention to source control and resistance patterns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meropenem: Inappropriate. Meropenem, a carbapenem, is commonly used for gram-negative infections, but MDR Acinetobacter baumannii is frequently resistant to carbapenems (including meropenem), as stated in the stem. Without susceptibility data confirming efficacy, meropenem is not suitable for this resistant strain.

 

Option C. Ceftazidime-avibactam: Inappropriate. Ceftazidime-avibactam is effective against some carbapenem-resistant gram-negative bacteria (e.g., those with specific beta-lactamases like KPC or OXA-48). However, Acinetobacter baumannii often produces metallo-beta-lactamases (e.g., NDM) or other mechanisms not inhibited by avibactam, rendering this combination ineffective for most MDR Acinetobacter strains.

 

Option D. Imipenem-cilastatin: Inappropriate. Like meropenem, imipenem-cilastatin is a carbapenem, and MDR Acinetobacter baumannii is typically resistant to it. The stem’s mention of resistance to most antibiotics strongly suggests carbapenem resistance, making imipenem-cilastatin unsuitable without confirmed susceptibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cefiderocol is effective for ventilator-associated pneumonia due to multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii.
  • Meropenem and imipenem-cilastatin are ineffective against carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter strains.
  • Ceftazidime-avibactam lacks activity against most MDR Acinetobacter due to specific resistance mechanisms.

questions.text:
Which of the following are functions of the cartridge case in ammunition? 

 

  1. Keeps components of cartridge together
  2. Allows backward escape of gases during firing
  3. Waterproofs gunpowder
  4. Aids in identification of gun type
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 4 only

 

The cartridge case is a vital component of ammunition that serves several key functions:

 

Statement 1. Keeps components of cartridge together: True. It holds the primer, propellant, and projectile (bullet or pellets) together in a single, compact unit—essential for consistent firing mechanics.

 

Statement 3. Waterproofs gunpowder: True. It provides a sealed environment, protecting the gunpowder from moisture, thereby ensuring reliable ignition and performance.

 

Statement 4. Aids in identification of gun type: True. The base configuration (rimmed, rimless, etc.) and firing pin impressions on the cartridge case can help identify the type of firearm used, which is crucial in forensic investigations.

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

Statement 2. Allows backward escape of gases during firing: False.The cartridge case is designed to prevent the backward escape of gases during firing by expanding and sealing the breech of the firearm. Allowing gas escape would be dangerous and reduce firing efficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cartridge cases seal, protect, and identify.
  • They do not allow gas to escape, but instead contain the explosive force and direct it forward.
  • Base designs and firing pin marks assist in ballistic forensics.

choices.text: Use of pencil point needles has a lesser incidence of PDPH.
Most techniques used to prevent PDPH are ineffective.
Optimal blood volume for epidural blood patch is around 50 mL.
PDPH is typically a positional headache that increases on upright posture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman underwent lumbar puncture for spinal anesthesia during cesarean section and presents 48 hours later with a severe headache. A diagnosis of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding PDPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Optimal blood volume for epidural blood patch is around 50 mL.

 

  • The patient’s presentation (severe headache worsened by upright posture, relieved by lying flat, onset 48 hours post-lumbar puncture for spinal anesthesia) is classic for post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), caused by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leakage through the dural puncture site, leading to intracranial hypotension.
  • The optimal blood volume for an epidural blood patch (EBP), the definitive treatment for PDPH, is typically 10–20 mL, not 50 mL. Studies suggest 10–15 mL is often sufficient to form a clot over the dural defect, sealing the CSF leak. Volumes >20 mL are rarely needed and may increase risks (e.g., back pain, nerve compression). 
  • A volume of 50 mL is excessive and not standard practice, making this statement false.
  • PDPH management includes conservative measures (bed rest, hydration, caffeine, analgesics) for 24-48 hours, but EBP is indicated for severe or persistent symptoms. 
  • The patient’s lack of neurologic deficits rules out complications like subdural hematoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of pencil point needles has a lesser incidence of PDPH: Correct. Pencil point needles (e.g., Whitacre, Sprotte) have a non-cutting, conical tip that separates dural fibers rather than cutting them, reducing CSF leakage compared to cutting needles (e.g., Quincke). Studies show a significantly lower PDPH incidence (2–5% vs. 10–30%) with pencil point needles, especially in high-risk procedures like spinal anesthesia.

 

Option B. Most techniques used to prevent PDPH are ineffective: Correct. Many preventive measures (e.g., bed rest, aggressive hydration, routine caffeine) lack strong evidence for reducing PDPH incidence. The most effective prevention strategies are using smaller-gauge (e.g., 25–27G) pencil point needles and minimizing puncture attempts, but other techniques (e.g., prophylactic EBP, prolonged supine positioning) are largely ineffective or impractical.

 

Option D. PDPH is typically a positional headache that increases on upright posture: Correct. PDPH is characterized by a positional headache due to CSF leakage causing intracranial hypotension, worsened by upright posture (sitting/standing) and relieved by lying flat. This is a hallmark feature, often accompanied by nausea, neck stiffness, or photophobia, as seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pencil point needles reduce PDPH incidence compared to cutting needles.
  • PDPH presents as a positional headache worsened by upright posture.
  • Epidural blood patch uses 10–20 mL of blood, not 50 mL, for optimal treatment

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about congenital (transplacental) CMV infection are true? 

 

  1. Mothers who transmit the virus are usually symptomatic
  2. It is the most common cause of non-syndromic hearing loss
  3. It is diagnosed by persistent presence of IgM antibody after 6 months of age
  4. All affected babies are symptomatic at birth
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 only

 

Statement 2. It is the most common cause of non-syndromic hearing loss: Congenital CMV infection is the leading cause of non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss in children worldwide. Even infants who are asymptomatic at birth can later develop progressive hearing loss, making this the most important long-term complication.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Mothers who transmit the virus are usually symptomatic: False. Most mothers who transmit CMV to the fetus are asymptomatic. Transmission usually occurs during a primary infection in pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, but maternal symptoms are rare.

 

Statement 3. It is diagnosed by persistent presence of IgM antibody after 6 months of age: False. IgM does not cross the placenta, so its presence in the neonate can indicate infection, but it is neither sensitive nor specific. Persistent IgM beyond 6 months is not the diagnostic standard. Diagnosis is made by PCR detection of CMV DNA or virus isolation from saliva or urine in the first 3 weeks of life.

 

Statement 4. All affected babies are symptomatic at birth: False. Only 10–15% of congenitally infected infants are symptomatic at birth. Most are asymptomatic but remain at risk for long-term sequelae like hearing loss and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital CMV is usually transmitted by asymptomatic mothers, presents with variable features, and is the most common cause of non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss; most affected infants are asymptomatic at birth.

choices.text: Recruitment of collapsed alveoli to improve oxygenation
Reduction of physiologic dead space to improve CO₂ clearance
Direct lowering of plateau pressure to reduce barotrauma
Increased cardiac preload to improve systemic perfusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with severe ARDS secondary to influenza pneumonia is on mechanical ventilation. He is sedated and paralyzed. Current ventilator settings: FiO₂ 0.8, tidal volume 6 mL/kg predicted body weight, respiratory rate 20/min, and PEEP 5 cm H₂O. His PaO₂ remains 48 mmHg, and plateau pressure is 26 cm H₂O. The team considers increasing PEEP. Which of the following is the primary physiological benefit of increasing PEEP in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Recruitment of collapsed alveoli to improve oxygenation

 

  • In ARDS, alveoli are prone to collapse at end-expiration due to low compliance and surfactant dysfunction. 
  • Increasing PEEP prevents alveolar collapse, recruits collapsed alveoli, and improves ventilation–perfusion matching, leading to better oxygenation.
  • This is the cornerstone of ARDS management when hypoxemia persists despite low tidal volume ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduction of physiologic dead space to improve CO₂ clearance: PEEP primarily improves oxygenation, not CO₂ clearance. Dead space ventilation is influenced more by tidal volume, respiratory rate, and pulmonary perfusion, not PEEP.

 

Option C. Direct lowering of plateau pressure to reduce barotrauma: Increasing PEEP does not reduce plateau pressure; in fact, plateau pressure often rises with higher PEEP. Protection against barotrauma is achieved by using low tidal volumes and keeping plateau pressure ≤30 cm H₂O, not by PEEP adjustments.

 

Option D. Increased cardiac preload to improve systemic perfusion: Higher PEEP actually reduces venous return by increasing intrathoracic pressure, which may lower cardiac output and systemic perfusion, especially in hypovolemic patients. It does not enhance preload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, PEEP improves oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse and recruiting collapsed alveoli, but excessive PEEP can impair hemodynamics and increase barotrauma risk.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is best represented by the lifecycle shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

  • The image illustrates the transmission cycle of Nipah virus, a zoonotic virus from the Paramyxoviridae family. 
  • Fruit bats (Pteropus species) are the natural reservoir. 
  • The virus spreads via:
    • Contaminated date palm sap (collected in open containers that bats lick or urinate into)
    • Infected fruits contaminated by bat saliva
    • Pig intermediates, where the virus can amplify (as seen in Malaysian outbreaks)
    • Direct human-to-human transmission, particularly in hospital or caregiving settings

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hendra virus: Also uses fruit bats as reservoirs but typically transmits to horses, not pigs or via date palm sap.
