Option C. Ebola virus: Involves bats but spreads primarily via bodily fluids; fruit or palm sap are not typical transmission modes.

 

Option D. Japanese Encephalitis virus: Spread via Culex mosquitoes from birds/pigs; bats or palm sap not involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus is transmitted from fruit bats to humans via contaminated palm sap, fruits, or pigs, and can also spread person-to-person, causing severe encephalitis outbreaks with high mortality.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lane's tissue holding forceps

 

  • Lane’s tissue holding forceps are stout with thick distal blades and oval fenestrae. It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part.
  • It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babcock's forceps: 

 

  • In Babcock’s forceps, the distal part of the blade is curved with a triangular fenestra, which allows soft tissues to bulge out. 
  • The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations. It has a lock in the proximal part.
  • It is used to hold tubular structures, such as parts of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, etc.

 

 

Option C. Kocher's clamp:

 

  • Kocher’s hemostatic forceps are identified by the opposing tooth on the tip and serrations in the distal blades.
  • It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It can also hold ribs during rib dissection and be used for blunt dissection or resected bowel.

 

 

Option D. Rampley’s sponge holder: Sponge holder shows a rounded, fenestrated, but blunt tip with serrations.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lane’s tissue holding forceps are stout with thick distal blades and oval fenestrae.
  • It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part.
  • It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

choices.text: Brought on by walking a certain distance
It is of a cramping type
Relieved on resting for a few minutes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of ischemic pain that is seen in peripheral arterial occlusive diseases (PVD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Relieved on limb elevation 

 

Ischemic pain (Rest pain) gets worse on limb elevation as blood flow reduces further.

 

Ischemic pain relief by hanging their leg side of bed 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brought on by walking a certain distance: Correct. Intermittent claudication is characterized by pain brought on by walking or exercise due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles.

 

Option B. It is of a cramping type: Correct. The pain of ischemia of muscle is cramping or spastic type in character.

 

Option C. Relieved on resting for few minutes: Correct. The pain of intermittent claudication is usually relieved by rest within a short duration, typically within a few minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

It is important to recognize the key features of intermittent claudication, including pain brought on by walking, relief with rest within a short duration, and a consistent claudication distance.

choices.text: PrPSc is anchored to the cell membrane while PrPC is cytoplasmic
PrPSc is protease-sensitive and has rapid turnover
PrPSc has increased beta-sheet content and is protease-resistant
PrPSc is encoded on a different chromosome than PrPC

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates the disease-causing prion protein (PrPSc) from its normal cellular isoform (PrPC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PrPSc has increased beta-sheet content and is protease-resistant

 

  • Prions are misfolded proteins, so deposited in different tissues. 
  • The key pathological feature of prion diseases lies in the conformational change of the normal prion protein (PrPC) into the abnormal form (PrPSc).
  • The normal PrPC is rich in alpha-helical structure, protease-sensitive, and has a short half-life. 
  • In contrast, PrPSc adopts a beta-sheet-rich conformation, making it resistant to protease digestion and capable of accumulating in the brain, where it forms amyloid-like plaques. 
  • These structural differences are critical in understanding the persistence and infectivity of PrPSc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PrPSc is anchored to the cell membrane while PrPC is cytoplasmic: Incorrect. The normal PrPC is anchored to the cell membrane, whereas the disease-associated PrPSc tends to accumulate in cytoplasmic vesicles.

 

Option B. PrPSc is protease-sensitive and has rapid turnover: Incorrect. This describes PrPC, not PrPSc. PrPSc is protease-resistant and has a much slower turnover, contributing to its accumulation.

 

Option D. PrPSc is encoded on a different chromosome than PrPC: Incorrect. Both forms are encoded by the same PRNP gene on chromosome. The difference arises post-translationally, due to abnormal folding—not due to different genetic encoding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pathological prion protein PrPSc differs from its normal isoform PrPC by having a beta-sheet-rich structure, protease resistance, and prolonged persistence. 
  • This conformational change underlies the pathogenesis of prion diseases.

questions.text: During the post-mortem examination of a 60-year-old man, blood is collected in a tube that contains heparin but no sodium fluoride. Which of the following analyses is most likely to yield an unreliable result because of this collection protocol?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol detection

 

  • Fluoride inhibits the glycolytic enzyme enolase and suppresses microbial fermentation, both of which can otherwise produce or consume ethanol after death and lead to false-positive or false-negative results.
  • Therefore, blood collected without sodium fluoride—regardless of which anticoagulant is used—should be considered unsuitable for forensic ethanol quantification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood glucose: Preservation of glucose requires inhibition of glycolysis. While sodium fluoride is preferred for accurate glucose levels, heparin does not majorly interfere with glucose assays in living patients, but it is not suitable for postmortem toxicology.

 

Option C. Complete blood count: Heparin is actually acceptable for CBC and does not interfere with cell counts or morphology significantly, though EDTA is the preferred anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin A1c estimation: EDTA-preserved blood is typically used, but heparinized samples may still be usable depending on the methodology. However, this is not the most compromised parameter in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Use sodium fluoride (10 mg/ml) with potassium oxalate (30 mg/10 ml) for alcohol and toxicology testing to prevent microbial ethanol formation and glycolysis. 
  • Avoid heparin and EDTA in this context due to interference with toxicological assays.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with facial and leg swelling, decreased urine output, and dark-colored urine. His parents report that he had a sore throat about 10 days ago. On examination, he has periorbital edema and elevated blood pressure. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum creatinine and red blood cell casts on urinalysis. A renal biopsy shows the histological findings displayed in the image provided. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

  • This 9-year-old boy presents with edema (face, legs, periorbital swelling), dark urine, decreased urine output, and hypertension following a recent sore throat.
  • Laboratory data show elevated creatinine and red blood cell casts, both classic for glomerulonephritis.
  • The timeline (latent period of ~10 days after infection), combined with pediatric age and preceding streptococcal pharyngitis, strongly suggests post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
  • Histology in PSGN typically demonstrates hypercellular glomeruli with granular immune complex deposition along the basement membrane and mesangium ("starry sky" or lumpy-bumpy appearance on immunofluorescence). 
  • This matches the provided biopsy image.
  • Thus, the most likely diagnosis is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: This condition may cause nephritic syndrome, but it usually presents with chronic infections (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C) rather than an acute sore throat followed by nephritic syndrome in a child. The biopsy appearance is different (tram-track splitting of GBM).

 

Option C. Acute tubular necrosis: ATN is usually due to ischemia or toxic injury and presents with muddy brown granular casts, not red blood cell casts. It does not follow a streptococcal throat infection and does not cause immune complex deposition.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: This is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, but it presents with massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and generalized edema. Hematuria and red blood cell casts are not typical, and it is not associated with a recent sore throat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis presents in children after a latent period following streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection, with hematuria, hypertension, edema, red blood cell casts, and granular immune complex deposition on biopsy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with severe headache and neck stiffness. A CT scan of the head is normal, but lumbar puncture reveals xanthochromia, confirming subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). His serum sodium is 125 mmol/L. Which of the following should be done to manage his hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3% NaCl

 

  • The patient’s presentation (severe headache, neck stiffness, xanthochromia on lumbar puncture) confirms subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), despite a normal CT scan, which can miss small bleeds (sensitivity ~95% in the first 24 hours). 
  • Serum sodium of 125 mmol/L indicates hyponatremia, commonly caused by the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) in SAH due to excessive ADH release from hypothalamic-pituitary stress or irritation.
  • 3% NaCl (hypertonic saline) is the appropriate treatment for symptomatic hyponatremia (sodium <130 mmol/L, especially with neurologic symptoms like headache) in SAH-related SIADH. 
  • Hypertonic saline corrects sodium levels rapidly (target increase 4–6 mmol/L in 24 hours) while avoiding cerebral edema, which is critical in SAH to prevent worsening intracranial pressure. 
  • Administration requires ICU monitoring to avoid overcorrection (>8–12 mmol/L/day, risking osmotic demyelination).
  • SAH management also includes nimodipine to prevent vasospasm, seizure prophylaxis, and neurosurgical evaluation for aneurysm clipping or coiling, but hyponatremia correction is urgent given the low sodium and neurologic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluid restriction: Inappropriate. Fluid restriction is a standard treatment for SIADH in non-emergent settings with mild hyponatremia (sodium >130 mmol/L or asymptomatic). In SAH, fluid restriction is contraindicated because it risks cerebral ischemia from vasospasm, which requires euvolemia or slight hypervolemia. The severe hyponatremia (125 mmol/L) and neurologic symptoms necessitate active correction with hypertonic saline.

 

Option C. Loop diuretics: Inappropriate. Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) are used in SIADH with fluid overload or in cerebral salt-wasting syndrome (CSWS), which is less common in SAH and presents with hypovolemia (not evident here). Diuretics alone do not correct severe hyponatremia rapidly and may exacerbate hypovolemia, risking SAH complications like vasospasm.

 

Option D. Normal saline: Inappropriate. Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) is ineffective for severe SIADH-related hyponatremia because it is isotonic and may worsen hyponatremia by increasing free water retention in the presence of excess ADH. Hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) is required to raise serum sodium effectively in this acute setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 3% NaCl is the treatment for severe hyponatremia (sodium <130 mmol/L) in SAH-related SIADH with neurologic symptoms.
  • Fluid restriction is contraindicated in SAH due to the need for euvolemia to prevent vasospasm.
  • Normal saline and loop diuretics are ineffective or harmful for severe SIADH-related hyponatremia in SAH.

choices.text: Male pattern hair growth on lower abdomen
Thickened dark skin on inner thighs
High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a long-standing history of irregular menstrual cycles and amenorrhea presents with the ultrasound image shown below. Which of the following finding is least likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High serum levels of high-density lipoproteins

 

  • The ultrasound image shows an ovary with multiple small peripheral cysts, which is highly suggestive of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). 
  • PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age, characterized by hormonal imbalances, irregular menstrual cycles, and often signs of hyperandrogenism (excess male hormones).
  • PCOS is associated with several metabolic and reproductive features, including:
    • Hirsutism (male-pattern hair growth) due to excess androgens.
    • Acanthosis nigricans (thickened, dark skin) often seen in insulin resistance, which commonly occurs in PCOS.
    • Abnormal glucose tolerance and insulin resistance, leading to a higher risk of type 2 diabetes.
  • High-density lipoproteins (HDL), the "good cholesterol," are often low in PCOS, rather than high. 
  • Therefore, high HDL levels are least likely to be seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male pattern hair growth on lower abdomen: This is a common feature of hyperandrogenism in PCOS.

 

Option B. Thickened dark skin on inner thighs: This describes acanthosis nigricans, a marker of insulin resistance, commonly seen in PCOS.

 

Option C. Abnormal glucose tolerance test results: Insulin resistance and impaired glucose tolerance are common in women with PCOS, putting them at risk for type 2 diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by irregular menstrual cycles, hyperandrogenism, and insulin resistance. 
  • It is typically associated with low HDL levels, which makes high HDL the least likely feature in patients with PCOS.

questions.text:
Regarding MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry for bacterial identification, which of the following statements are true?

 

  1. The technology primarily analyzes ribosomal proteins in the 2,000-20,000 Dalton range
  2. α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid matrix is required for ionization of bacterial proteins
  3. Protein fingerprinting can differentiate between methicillin-sensitive and methicillin-resistant S. aureus
  4. Multiple samples can be analyzed simultaneously on a single target plate
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only 

 

Statement 1. The technology primarily analyzes ribosomal proteins in the 2,000-20,000 Dalton range: True. MALDI-TOF predominantly detects ribosomal proteins, which comprise up to 20% of bacterial cellular proteins and are ideal identification markers due to their abundance and species-specific composition. The 2,000-20,000 Dalton range captures both 30S and 50S ribosomal subunit proteins, with most diagnostic peaks appearing between 4,000-12,000 Da. This mass range is optimal as it avoids small molecules below 2,000 Da and large proteins above 20,000 Da that ionize poorly. Each bacterial species produces a unique pattern of ribosomal protein masses in this range, creating a characteristic fingerprint for identification.

 

Statement 2. α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid matrix is required for ionization of bacterial proteins: True. HCCA matrix is essential for MALDI-TOF because proteins cannot be directly ionized by laser without fragmentation. The matrix co-crystallizes with bacterial proteins and absorbs laser energy at 337 nm, preventing protein damage while facilitating their ionization through proton transfer. HCCA enables "soft ionization" where matrix molecules carry intact proteins into gas phase as charged ions. This matrix is specifically optimal for bacterial ribosomal proteins, providing the best resolution and sensitivity for bacterial identification compared to other available matrices.

 

Statement 4. Multiple samples can be analyzed simultaneously on a single target plate: True. MALDI-TOF target plates contain 48-96 spots (some up to 384), each holding one sample. After loading all samples with matrix, the instrument automatically analyzes each spot sequentially, taking only 1-3 seconds per spot. A 96-sample plate completes analysis in under 10 minutes. This high-throughput capability allows batch processing, multiple technicians to work simultaneously, and inclusion of quality controls on the same plate, making MALDI-TOF highly efficient and cost-effective for clinical laboratories.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Protein fingerprinting can differentiate between methicillin-sensitive and methicillin-resistant S. aureus: This is false. MALDI-TOF cannot distinguish MSSA from MRSA because methicillin resistance is mediated by the mecA gene encoding PBP2a protein, which represents less than 0.1% of total cellular proteins. This minor addition doesn't alter the dominant ribosomal protein peaks that form the identification fingerprint. Both MSSA and MRSA produce identical ribosomal protein patterns, resulting in the same spectral profile. MALDI-TOF identifies organisms at species level based on conserved proteins, not resistance mechanisms, making separate antimicrobial susceptibility testing necessary.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

MALDI-TOF provides rapid bacterial identification through ribosomal protein analysis but cannot detect antibiotic resistance mechanisms, while offering high-throughput capability for multiple simultaneous samples.

choices.text: Internalin B binding to Met receptor

questions.text: A neonate develops early-onset sepsis with gram-positive rods showing tumbling motility at room temperature. The organism grows on PALCAM agar producing black colonies. Which virulence factor enables transplacental transmission of this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internalin A binding to E-cadherin

 

  • The description indicates Listeria monocytogenes (tumbling motility at 20-25°C, black colonies on PALCAM agar). 
  • Listeria monocytogens causes early-onset neonatal sepsis through transplacental transmission.
  • Internalin A (InlA) specifically binds to E-cadherin on the basolateral surface of syncytiotrophoblasts in placental tissue. 
  • This interaction is crucial for crossing the placental barrier. Notably, human E-cadherin has higher affinity for InlA compared to mouse E-cadherin, explaining why mice are relatively resistant to transplacental listeriosis. 
  • InlA-E-cadherin interaction triggers bacterial internalization into placental cells, enabling fetal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Internalin B binding to Met receptor: InlB binds Met receptor and aids invasion but is not specific for placental transmission

 

Option C. Listeriolysin O mediated membrane disruption: Listeriolysin O enables phagosomal escape after internalization, not initial placental invasion

 

Option D. ActA protein for actin polymerization: ActA mediates actin-based motility for cell-to-cell spread but doesn't initiate placental crossing

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Listeria monocytogenes crosses the placental barrier through Internalin A binding to E-cadherin on syncytiotrophoblasts, causing transplacental infection.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the correct Bayes’ theorem-based formula for Positive Predictive Value (PPV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

  • Bayes' theorem allows us to calculate the Positive Predictive Value (PPV), which is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease. 
  • The correct formula is:

 

 

  • This formula takes into account:
    • True Positives: Sensitivity × Prevalence
    • False Positives: (1 - Specificity) × (1 - Prevalence)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) reflects the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease.
  • It increases with higher prevalence and higher specificity, and is calculated using Bayes’ theorem:

 

 

Note – Prevalence is Pre-test probability and PPV is Post-test probability of a disease.

choices.text: Headache severity correlates with the size of the adenoma.
Single most important test to diagnose acromegaly is serum IGF-1.
ADH deficiency causing central diabetes insipidus indicates a pituitary lesion.
Most pituitary incidentalomas are likely to be functioning.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman underwent an MRI for persistent headaches, revealing an 8-mm mass near the sella turcica, suggestive of a pituitary adenoma. Which of the following statements is true regarding pituitary adenoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single most important test to diagnose acromegaly is serum IGF-1.

 

  • The patient’s presentation (20-year-old woman with headaches and an 8-mm sellar mass on MRI) suggests a pituitary adenoma, likely an incidentaloma (asymptomatic mass found during imaging for unrelated symptoms). 
  • Pituitary adenomas are classified as microadenomas (<10 mm) or macroadenomas (≥10 mm) and can be functioning (hormone-secreting) or non-functioning.
  • The single most important test to diagnose acromegaly is serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). 
  • Acromegaly, caused by a growth hormone (GH)-secreting pituitary adenoma, leads to elevated IGF-1 levels, which reflect integrated GH secretion over time. 
  • Elevated age- and sex-adjusted IGF-1 is highly sensitive and specific for acromegaly, with confirmation via oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) showing failure of GH suppression (<1 ng/mL). 
  • In this patient, while acromegaly is not clinically evident, IGF-1 is the key diagnostic test for suspected GH-secreting adenomas.
  • Evaluation of an incidental pituitary adenoma includes hormonal workup (e.g., IGF-1, prolactin, ACTH, TSH) and visual field testing (less critical for microadenomas). 
  • Management depends on whether the adenoma is functioning or causing mass effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Headache severity correlates with the size of the adenoma: False. Headaches in pituitary adenomas are common but do not consistently correlate with adenoma size. Microadenomas (<10 mm, as in this case) can cause headaches due to dural stretch or hormonal effects, while macroadenomas may cause headaches via mass effect (e.g., optic chiasm compression). Severity varies individually and is not a reliable indicator of size.

 

Option C. ADH deficiency causing central diabetes insipidus indicates a pituitary lesion: False. Central diabetes insipidus (DI) due to antidiuretic hormone (ADH, vasopressin) deficiency typically results from lesions affecting the posterior pituitary or hypothalamus (e.g., craniopharyngioma, trauma, or infiltrative diseases like sarcoidosis). Most pituitary adenomas (anterior pituitary) do not cause ADH deficiency, as ADH is produced by the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary. DI is rare in pituitary adenomas unless there is significant stalk or hypothalamic involvement.

 

Option D. Most pituitary incidentalomas are likely to be functioning: False. Most pituitary incidentalomas are non-functioning adenomas (60–70%), not secreting hormones. Functioning adenomas (e.g., prolactinomas, GH-secreting, ACTH-secreting) are less common, with prolactinomas being the most frequent among functioning types. Hormonal workup (e.g., prolactin, IGF-1) is needed to determine functionality, but the majority of incidentalomas are non-functioning microadenomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum IGF-1 is the primary test for diagnosing acromegaly due to a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma.
  • Most pituitary incidentalomas are non-functioning microadenomas, not hormone-secreting.
  • Central diabetes insipidus is typically caused by hypothalamic or posterior pituitary lesions, not anterior pituitary adenomas.

questions.text:
Match the following. 

 

List I (Breathing Patterns): 

  1. Cheyne–Stokes respiration
  2. Kussmaul breathing
  3. Biot’s breathing 
  4. Apneustic breathing

 

List II (Causes/Associations):

  1. Damage to the pons, causing prolonged inspiratory pauses
  2. Severe metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis, renal failure)
  3. Increased intracranial pressure, meningitis, or medullary damage → irregular breathing with abrupt apneas
  4. Congestive heart failure or delayed central CO₂ detection → cyclic hyperventilation followed by apnea
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

  • 1. Cheyne–Stokes respiration (d): Seen in heart failure and CNS lesions. Caused by delayed detection of CO₂ by central chemoreceptors, leading to waxing and waning breathing.
  • 2. Kussmaul breathing (b): Deep, rapid breathing to blow off CO₂ in severe metabolic acidosis such as diabetic ketoacidosis or chronic renal failure.
  • 3. Biot’s breathing (c): Irregular breathing with abrupt apneas, caused by medullary damage, meningitis, or increased intracranial pressure.
  • 4. Apneustic breathing (a): Prolonged inspiratory pauses due to pons (lower pontine) damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abnormal breathing patterns help localize pathology: 

 

  • Cheyne–Stokes → heart failure/CO₂ delay, 
  • Kussmaul → metabolic acidosis, 
  • Biot’s → medullary lesions/ICP, 
  • Apneustic → pontine lesions.

choices.text: The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death.
The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.
The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology expert who testifies that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents. The defence argues that the expert’s testimony should be inadmissible as toxicology expert neither examined the victim while he was alive, nor he conducted the autopsy himself. Which of the below is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

 

  • Expert testimony can be based on facts or data that the expert has knowledge of, even if they weren't directly involved in gathering those facts.
  • In this case, the toxicologist analyzed the victim's stomach contents and can provide an expert opinion about the presence of a toxic substance.
  • The fact that the expert didn't examine the victim while alive or perform the autopsy does not necessarily make the testimony inadmissible. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death: Toxicologist doesn't need first-hand knowledge of the victim's condition at the time of death. The testimony is based on their expertise in analyzing evidence.

 

Option C. The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition: Expert testimony does not require corroboration from a common witness with first-hand knowledge of the victim's condition. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A toxicology expert’s opinion is valid and admissible in court as long as it is scientifically grounded and within their area of expertise, regardless of whether they directly examined the victim or performed the autopsy.

questions.text:
Which of the following surgical procedures are used as palliative operations in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)? 

 

  1. Modified Blalock-Taussig shunt
  2. Waterston-Cooley shunt
  3. Potts shunt
  4. Aortoplasty
  5. Cutting and end-to-end anastomosis of the aorta
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Statement 1. Modified Blalock-Taussig shunt: Most widely used palliative shunt for TOF, connects the subclavian artery to the pulmonary artery using a graft.

 

Statement 2. Waterston-Cooley shunt: Historical procedure connecting the ascending aorta to the right pulmonary artery, used in TOF before definitive repair techniques improved.

 

Statement 3. Potts shunt: Historical shunt connecting the descending aorta to the left pulmonary artery; increased pulmonary blood flow but is no longer commonly used.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 4. Aortoplasty: Indicated in coarctation of the aorta, not TOF.

 

Statement 5. Cutting and end-to-end anastomosis of the aorta: Also a surgery for coarctation of the aorta, with no role in TOF management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palliative shunt surgeries for TOF include the modified Blalock-Taussig, Waterston, and Potts shunts, whereas aortoplasty and end-to-end anastomosis are exclusively for coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, 10 weeks pregnant, presents with fever, chills, and altered sensorium, diagnosed with severe falciparum malaria confirmed by peripheral smear. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for her treatment?

 

  1. Quinine
  2. Doxycycline
  3. Artesunate
  4. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 4

 

  • The patient, at 10 weeks gestation (first trimester), has severe falciparum malaria, a life-threatening condition requiring urgent treatment. 
  • Severe malaria in pregnancy necessitates parenteral antimalarials initially, followed by oral therapy, with careful consideration of drug safety due to fetal risks.
  • Treatment approach: Severe falciparum malaria in the first trimester is treated with parenteral artesunate (first-line) or quinine (alternative if artesunate is unavailable), followed by oral artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) or quinine plus clindamycin. 
  • Local measures (e.g., supportive care, monitoring) are critical, but drug safety is paramount.

 

Correct Options:

 

2. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, due to risks of fetal bone and dental developmental abnormalities (e.g., tooth discoloration, impaired bone growth). It is a tetracycline antibiotic not recommended for malaria treatment in pregnant women.

 

4. Primaquine: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of hemolytic anemia in the fetus, particularly if G6PD status is unknown. It is used for radical cure of Plasmodium vivax or ovale, not falciparum malaria, and is avoided in pregnancy across all trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parenteral artesunate is the first-line treatment for severe malaria in all trimesters of pregnancy.
  • Quinine is a safe alternative for severe malaria in the first trimester when artesunate is unavailable.
  • Doxycycline and primaquine are contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal risks of developmental abnormalities and hemolysis, respectively.

choices.text: Herald patch precedes eruptions by 1–2 weeks

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with multiple oval, scaly plaques on her trunk, distributed along the lines of cleavage in a classic “Christmas tree” arrangement. Which of the following statements about pityriasis rosea is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Has a very chronic course

 

  • Pityriasis rosea does not have a very chronic course; rather, it is an acute and self-limiting dermatosis. 
  • It usually resolves within 6–12 weeks without scarring. Thus, describing it as having a “very chronic course” is not true, which makes this the correct Ans. to the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herald patch precedes eruptions by 1–2 weeks: This statement is true. In pityriasis rosea, a single larger lesion known as the herald patch typically appears before the eruption of generalized lesions. The interval is usually 1–2 weeks, and this feature is considered classical.

 

Option B. Caused by HHV 7 & 6: This is also true. Although the exact cause of pityriasis rosea is not fully understood, human herpesvirus types 6 and 7 (HHV-6 and HHV-7) are most commonly implicated in its pathogenesis. Therefore, attributing it to these viruses is correct.

 

Option C. Can be drug induced: This is true as well. Pityriasis rosea–like eruptions can occur secondary to certain medications. Drugs such as ACE inhibitors, metronidazole, gold, and others have been reported to trigger PR-like presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is an acute, self-limiting dermatosis characterized by a herald patch, “Christmas tree” distribution, possible drug-induced variants, and an association with HHV-6/7. 
  • It resolves spontaneously in 6–12 weeks, and it does not have a chronic course.

choices.text: Plan delivery at 37 weeks with maternal monitoring (including BP) and fetal surveillance
Weekly liver function tests with plan for delivery at 34 weeks

questions.text: A 27-year-old G2P1L1 at 33 weeks presents with nocturnal pruritus predominantly on the palms, a history of similar symptoms in her first pregnancy, mild icterus, and normal blood pressure (130/84 mmHg). On abdominal exam, the uterus measures about 32 weeks, and fetal heart rate is 140 bpm. Labs show SGOT 112 IU/L, SGPT 124 IU/L, and serum bilirubin 2 mg%. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plan delivery at 37 weeks with maternal monitoring (including BP) and fetal surveillance

 

  • This clinical picture—27-year-old, G2P1L1, 33 weeks, itching worse at night on the palms, mild icterus, elevated transaminases (SGOT 112 IU/L, SGPT 124 IU/L), and serum bilirubin 2 mg%, with BP 130/84 mmHg and FHR 140 bpm—is classic for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). 
  • The next best step is expectant management with close maternal–fetal monitoring and planned delivery at 37 weeks. 
  • This balances the risk of stillbirth associated with ICP against prematurity; standard practice is to plan delivery at 36–37 weeks, commonly 37 weeks when the patient is stable, as here. 
  • Monitoring includes maternal status (including BP, even though it’s normal at 130/84 mmHg), serial LFTs, pruritus control (e.g., ursodeoxycholic acid), and fetal surveillance (e.g., NST/BPP). 
  • The uterus measuring ~32 weeks at 33 weeks and FHR 140 bpm (normal baseline) support stability and allow planned timing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate induction of labor: Incorrect. At 33 weeks, immediate delivery is not indicated in a stable ICP patient with FHR 140 bpm, BP 130/84 mm Hg, mild icterus, SGOT 112, SGPT 124, and bilirubin 2 mg%. Early induction would increase prematurity risk without urgent maternal/fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Emergency cesarean delivery: Incorrect. There is no obstetric emergency. ICP with no fetal distress (FHR normal at 140 bpm) and stable maternal vitals (130/84 mm Hg) is managed expectantly; mode of delivery is based on usual obstetric indications, not ICP alone.

 

Option D. Weekly liver function tests with plan for delivery at 34 weeks:
Weekly LFTs are part of monitoring, but delivery at 34 weeks is not routinely indicated unless LFTs worsen severely or other complications arise. Delivery at 37 weeks is standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy—characterized by pruritus (often nocturnal, palms/soles), elevated LFTs, and possible mild jaundice—the next best step in a stable patient at ~33 weeks is expectant management with surveillance and planned delivery at 37 weeks to mitigate stillbirth risk while minimizing prematurity.

choices.text: It requires a mandatory test dose before administration
It is administered by intravenous route
It has a high risk of causing hypophosphatemia compared to ferric carboxymaltose
It is contraindicated in patients receiving erythropoietin therapy

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with chronic kidney disease on erythropoietin therapy develops severe iron-deficiency anemia. His nephrologist decides to start intravenous iron therapy. Which of the following statements about iron isomaltoside is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is administered by intravenous route

 

  • The drug is given intravenously (bolus or infusion). 
  • Its main advantage is that a large single dose (up to 1000 mg) can be given safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It requires a mandatory test dose before administration: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has a low risk of hypersensitivity, unlike high-molecular weight iron dextran. No test dose is required.

 

Option C. It has a high risk of causing hypophosphatemia compared to ferric carboxymaltose: Incorrect. This is actually a feature of ferric carboxymaltose, not iron isomaltoside. Iron isomaltoside has much lower risk of causing hypophosphatemia.

 

Option D. It is contraindicated in patients receiving erythropoietin therapy: Incorrect. In fact, IV iron (including isomaltoside) is often used together with ESAs in CKD to optimize hemoglobin response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron formulation with lower immunogenicity than iron dextran, does not require a test dose, does not cause hypophosphatemia and can be co-administered with erythropoietin in anemia of chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man presents with painless hematuria persisting for a month. He has a long history of smoking and exposure to industrial chemicals. Urinalysis shows red blood cells, and cystoscopy reveals a suspicious bladder lesion. Which of the following immunohistochemical profiles is most consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CK7+ and CK20+

 

  • This 59-year-old man with painless hematuria, along with risk factors of smoking and industrial chemical exposure (e.g., benzidine, aniline dyes), has classic features of urothelial carcinoma (bladder cancer). 
  • The suspicious lesion seen on cystoscopy supports this diagnosis.
  • On immunohistochemistry, urothelial carcinoma typically shows positivity for both CK7 and CK20 (i.e., CK7+ and CK20+). 
  • Cytokeratins are structural proteins of epithelial cells, and this dual positivity helps identify primary bladder cancer and distinguish it from other malignancies.
  • Therefore, the most likely immunohistochemical result is CK7+ and CK20+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CK5/6+ and p63+: This immunoprofile is associated with squamous cell carcinoma, particularly of the lung or cervix, not with urothelial carcinoma.

 

Option B. TTF-1 positive: Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) positivity is characteristic of lung adenocarcinoma and thyroid neoplasms, not bladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. CK7– and CK20–: This negative profile can be seen in renal cell carcinoma or hepatocellular carcinoma, but not in urothelial carcinoma, which typically expresses both CK7 and CK20.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder urothelial carcinoma, strongly associated with smoking and aromatic amine exposure, presents with painless hematuria and shows CK7+ and CK20+ immunohistochemical expression.

 

Note: Approach to Cytokeratin in Adenocarcinoma of Unknown primary (CK7; CK20):

questions.text: In a population, the mean systolic blood pressure is 120 mmHg with a standard deviation (SD) of 10 mmHg. What range of values would include approximately 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 100–140 mmHg

 

  • This is based on the Empirical Rule (also known as the 68-95-99.7 rule) for normal (Gaussian) distribution:
    • 68% of data lie within ±1 SD from the mean
    • 95% lie within ±2 SD
    • 99.7% lie within ±3 SD

 

 

Given:

 

  • Mean = 120 mmHg
  • SD = 10 mmHg
  • ±2 SD = 120 ± (2 × 10) = 100 to 140 mmHg
  • So, approximately 95% of the population would have systolic BP in the range 100–140 mmHg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a normally distributed population, 95% of values lie within two standard deviations (±2 SD) of the mean. 
  • This principle is crucial for estimating confidence intervals and evaluating population variability in clinical and research settings.

choices.text: Pleural fluid to serum glucose ratio of 0.2

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a 14-year history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with methotrexate presents with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain for several weeks. Chest X-ray reveals a unilateral pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed to analyze the pleural fluid. Which of the following findings is not consistent with a rheumatoid pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) White blood cell count >25,000/mm³

 

  • The patient’s long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and unilateral pleural effusion on chest X-ray suggest a rheumatoid pleural effusion, a known extra-articular manifestation of RA, particularly in men with chronic disease. 
  • Rheumatoid effusions are typically exudative and have specific pleural fluid characteristics: low pH (<7.3), low glucose (<50 mg/dL or pleural fluid:serum glucose ratio <0.5), high lactate dehydrogenase (LDH, often >700 IU/L or fluid:serum LDH >0.6), and a serum:pleural albumin gradient <1.2 g/dL (indicating exudate per Light’s criteria).
  • A white blood cell (WBC) count >25,000/mm³ in pleural fluid is suggestive of an empyema or parapneumonic effusion, not a rheumatoid effusion.
  • Rheumatoid pleural effusions typically have a WBC count of 1,000 - 5,000/mm³, predominantly lymphocytes or monocytes, reflecting chronic inflammation rather than acute purulent infection. 
  • A count >25,000/mm³ would raise suspicion for infection, which is not typical for RA-related effusions unless complicated by secondary infection.
  • Thoracentesis analysis is critical to differentiate rheumatoid effusions from other causes (e.g., infection, malignancy). 
  • Management includes optimizing RA treatment (e.g., methotrexate continuation, possible steroids) and, in severe cases, drainage or pleurodesis, but infection must be ruled out.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Pleural fluid to serum glucose ratio of 0.2: Consistent. Rheumatoid pleural effusions characteristically have very low glucose levels (<50 mg/dL) and a pleural fluid:serum glucose ratio <0.5 (e.g., 0.2), due to glucose consumption by inflamed pleura and impaired transport across the pleural membrane, a hallmark feature of RA effusions.

 

Option C. Serum:pleural albumin gradient <1.2 g/dL: Consistent. This indicates an exudative effusion per Light’s criteria (serum albumin minus pleural fluid albumin <1.2 g/dL). Rheumatoid effusions are exudative due to chronic inflammation, with high protein content, making this finding typical.

 

Option D. Pleural fluid LDH:serum LDH >0.6: Consistent. Rheumatoid effusions are exudative, with elevated LDH levels (often >700 IU/L) and a pleural fluid:serum LDH ratio >0.6, another Light’s criterion for exudates, reflecting active pleural inflammation in RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pleural fluid:serum glucose ratio <0.5 is characteristic of rheumatoid pleural effusions.
  • Serum:pleural albumin gradient <1.2 g/dL and pleural fluid:serum LDH >0.6 confirm exudative nature in RA effusions.
  • WBC count >25,000/mm³ suggests empyema, not typical rheumatoid effusion.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is evaluated for progressive vision loss, including night blindness and loss of peripheral vision. He also has myopia. Fundoscopic examination reveals gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina. The patient has a family history of a similar disorder, and genetic testing confirms an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. This condition is most likely due to the deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ornithine-δ-aminotransferase

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms of gyrate atrophy, an autosomal recessive condition caused by a deficiency of ornithine-δ-aminotransferase.
  • This enzyme is responsible for converting ornithine into pyrroline-5-carboxylate in the mitochondria. 
  • A deficiency in this enzyme leads to elevated levels of ornithine, which is toxic to the retina and choroid, resulting in the characteristic vision problems, including night blindness and loss of peripheral vision. 
  • The condition also causes progressive degeneration of the retina, which is visible as gyrate atrophy on fundoscopic examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Argininosuccinate lyase: This enzyme is involved in the urea cycle, and its deficiency leads to argininosuccinic aciduria, a metabolic disorder that causes hyperammonemia. It is not associated with gyrate atrophy or the retinal findings described in this patient.

 

Option C. Tyrosine hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme can lead to tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency, which primarily affects dopamine synthesis, leading to movement disorders and developmental delays, but it does not cause gyrate atrophy or night blindness.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency in this enzyme results in phenylketonuria (PKU), a condition marked by intellectual disability and musty body odor due to the inability to metabolize phenylalanine. It is not associated with vision problems or gyrate atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a deficiency of ornithine-δ-aminotransferase, leading to progressive vision loss, including night blindness and peripheral vision deficits.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to a tertiary care hospital because his parents noticed a red, exposed mass in the lower abdomen since birth. Which of the following is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypospadiasis

 

Ectopia vesicae is usually associated with epispadiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diastasis of pubis: Children with bladder exstrophy have a wide separation of the pubic bones due to failure of midline closure during development. This results in an abnormal pelvic anatomy and contributes to genital malformations.

 

Option B. Vesico-ureteric reflux: Because of abnormal anatomy of the bladder neck and vesicoureteric junction, vesico-ureteric reflux is a common association. This predisposes the child to recurrent urinary tract infections and potential renal damage.

 

Option C. Inguinal hernia: Up to 70-80% of patients with bladder exstrophy have inguinal hernias, often bilateral, due to weakness in the inguinal canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is associated with pubic diastasis, vesico-ureteric reflux, and genital malformations, but it predisposes to adenocarcinoma of the bladder—not squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a long-standing history of major depressive disorder has been stable on an SSRI for several months. Two weeks ago, he developed a complicated skin and soft tissue infection and was prescribed linezolid. He now presents with acute onset agitation, tremors, involuntary jerks of the extremities, diaphoresis, and hyperreflexia. On examination, he is restless, his temperature is mildly elevated, and he demonstrates myoclonus with inducible clonus at the ankle. Laboratory studies are unremarkable. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for treating this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyproheptadine

 

  • This patient developed serotonin syndrome after starting linezolid while already on an SSRI for major depression. 
  • Linezolid has monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) activity, and when combined with serotonergic drugs (SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, MAOIs, certain opioids), it can result in excess serotonergic activity.
  • Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include:
    • Neuromuscular hyperactivity → myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremor, clonus
    • Autonomic instability → diaphoresis, hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia
    • Altered mental status → agitation, confusion
  • Cyproheptadine is a serotonin receptor antagonist (5-HT2A blocker) and is the drug of choice for moderate to severe serotonin syndrome.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Sertraline: An SSRI; giving another serotonergic drug would worsen serotonin syndrome.

 

Option B. Vilazodone: An SSRI and partial 5-HT1A agonist; it also increases serotonergic activity, so it would exacerbate the syndrome.

 

Option D. Fluoxetine: Another SSRI; like the others, it would further increase serotonin and worsen symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serotonin syndrome results from excess serotonergic activity, often due to drug interactions such as SSRIs with linezolid. 
  • Clinical features include agitation, hyperreflexia, clonus, and myoclonus. 
  • The specific antidote is cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

choices.text: I – g, II – b, III – e, IV – a
I – g, II – b, III – c, IV – f
I – a, II – b, III – c, IV – f
I – a, II – g, III – e, IV – f

questions.text: Match the following systemic conditions to the ocular findings they are most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) I – a, II – b, III – c, IV – f

 

  • I. Hypertensive retinopathy → a. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE can cause secondary hypertension, and hypertensive retinopathy can occur due to renal involvement and systemic vascular inflammation. Retinal changes in SLE often resemble hypertensive or vasculitic retinopathy.
  • II. Granulomatous uveitis → b. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that commonly presents with granulomatous uveitis, characterized by mutton-fat keratic precipitates and iris nodules.
  • III. Necrotizing chorioretinitis → c. CMV retinitis: CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) presents with necrotizing chorioretinitis, typically described as "pizza-pie" or "cottage cheese and ketchup" appearance on fundus.
  • IV. Nuclear pearly cataract → f. Congenital rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome classically includes nuclear cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and cardiac defects. The cataract may have a pearly appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Systemic diseases often present with specific ocular findings that aid diagnosis. 
  • Examples include:
    • SLE with hypertensive-like retinopathy
    • Sarcoidosis with granulomatous uveitis
    • CMV infection with necrotizing chorioretinitis
    • Congenital rubella with nuclear cataract

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of ischemic stroke receives intravenous alteplase (tPA) for acute thrombolysis. Two hours later, he develops severe oropharyngeal bleeding and a rapidly expanding neck hematoma. The infusion is immediately stopped. Which of the following agents is the most appropriate antidote for reversing the effect of fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epsilon aminocaproic acid

 

  • Fibrinolytics (e.g., alteplase, reteplase, streptokinase, tenecteplase) work by converting plasminogen → plasmin, leading to degradation of fibrin clots.
  • A dangerous adverse effect of fibrinolytics is severe bleeding.
  • Epsilon aminocaproic acid is a synthetic lysine analogue that inhibits plasminogen activation, thereby blocking fibrinolysis.
  • It is the specific antidote used to reverse fibrinolytic-induced bleeding.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Protamine sulfate: Antidote for heparin toxicity, not for fibrinolytics.

 

Option B. Idarucizumab: It is an antidote of dabigatran and not an anti-fibrinolytic.

 

Option D. Andexanet alfa: A recombinant modified factor Xa decoy protein used as an antidote for direct factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., rivaroxaban, apixaban). It does not work for fibrinolytics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The antidote for fibrinolytic-induced bleeding is epsilon aminocaproic acid, which inhibits plasminogen activation and prevents fibrin degradation.

questions.text: A young male presents with pain in his thigh. The pain is worse at night and is partially relieved by salicylates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • It's a benign bone tumor that typically affects young males. 
  • The pain is caused by the high concentration of prostaglandins produced by the tumor's nidus (the core). 
  • This makes the pain highly responsive to NSAIDs, which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis. 
  • The radiographic image would typically show a small, lucent nidus surrounded by a dense, reactive bone sclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma:

 

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that usually presents with pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever and an elevated white blood cell count. 
  • Radiographically, it often appears as an "onion skin" periosteal reaction and a large destructive mass. 
  • The pain is generally not reliably relieved by NSAIDs.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: 

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and young adults. 
  • It presents with progressive, localized pain and swelling. 
  • The pain is typically severe and constant, not specifically worse at night or relieved by NSAIDs in the classic manner of osteoid osteoma. 
  • Radiographs show a destructive lesion with characteristic "sunburst" or "Codman's triangle" patterns.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: 

 

  • Osteochondroma is the most common benign bone tumor. 
  • It presents as a painless, bony projection near a joint, covered by a cartilage cap. 
  • While it can cause pain due to mass effect on a nerve or tendon, the pain is not typically worse at night or relieved by NSAIDs in the classic fashion seen with osteoid osteoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's clinical presentation—a painful bone mass with pain that is worse at night and is classically relieved by NSAIDs—is a hallmark feature of this benign bone tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the kidney functions as the countercurrent exchanger, helping maintain the osmotic gradient necessary for urine concentration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vasa recta

 

  • The vasa recta are straight capillaries in the renal medulla that run parallel to the loop of Henle. 
  • They act as countercurrent exchangers, allowing slow blood flow in opposite direction to tubular filtrate, which preserves the medullary osmotic gradient. 
  • This mechanism is crucial for water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritubular capillaries: Incorrect. These surround proximal and distal tubules and participate in solute and water reabsorption, but they are not countercurrent exchangers.

 

Option B. Loop of Henle: Incorrect.The loop of Henle acts as the countercurrent multiplier, generating the osmotic gradient. It does not function as the exchanger.

 

Option D. Juxtaglomerular apparatus: Incorrect. This regulates blood pressure and glomerular filtration via renin release. It does not contribute to the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vasa recta serve as the kidney’s countercurrent exchangers, maintaining the medullary osmotic gradient required for water reabsorption and concentrated urine formation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of substernal chest pain that occur at rest, particularly in the early morning hours. The pain is occasionally associated with mild diaphoresis but not exertion. An ECG obtained during one of these episodes reveals transient ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, which resolves spontaneously within minutes. Which of the following medications would most likely exacerbate his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metoprolol

 

  • Prinzmetal (variant) angina is caused by transient coronary artery vasospasm, producing rest pain with temporary ST-segment elevation that resolves after vasodilation.
  • First-line therapy: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem) and nitrates (e.g., isosorbide mononitrate) because they reduce vasospasm by promoting smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
  • Beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are contraindicated because they block β₂-mediated vasodilation, leaving unopposed α-adrenergic vasoconstriction, which can worsen coronary vasospasm.
  • Thus, the drug most likely to exacerbate the condition is Metoprolol.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Isosorbide mononitrate: Long-acting nitrate; causes vasodilation and relieves coronary vasospasm. Helpful, not harmful.

 

Option B. Diltiazem: Calcium channel blocker; prevents coronary vasospasm and improves symptoms. Beneficial.

 

Option D. Ranolazine: A late sodium current inhibitor used in refractory chronic stable angina; while not first-line for Prinzmetal angina, it does not exacerbate vasospasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In vasospastic (Prinzmetal) angina, beta-blockers such as metoprolol are contraindicated because they worsen vasospasm via unopposed alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction. 
  • Calcium channel blockers and nitrates are preferred therapies.

choices.text: ATP is required for the reaction in which argininosuccinate is cleaved to form arginine
Urea is produced directly by the hydrolysis of ornithine
The two nitrogen atoms incorporated into urea enter the cycle as ammonia and alanine
Urinary urea is increased by a diet rich in protein

questions.text: Regarding the urea cycle, which statement is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urinary urea is increased by a diet rich in protein

 

  • A diet rich in protein increases amino acid catabolism, generating more ammonia (NH₃/NH₄⁺) that must be detoxified via the urea cycle. 
  • The liver converts nitrogen to urea, which is then eliminated as urinary urea; therefore, protein loading raises both blood urea nitrogen and urinary excretion—making the statement “Urinary urea is increased by a diet rich in protein” correct and the best description of a correct aspect of the urea cycle.
  • Key mechanistic context to cover all original phrases:
    • “Two nitrogen atoms that are incorporated into urea”: One nitrogen enters the cycle as free ammonia (via carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, mitochondrial), and the second enters as aspartate, not alanine. Thus, “ammonia and alanine” is incorrect; alanine transports nitrogen to the liver (via the glucose–alanine cycle), but the actual urea nitrogen donors are ammonia and aspartate.
    • “Urea is produced directly by the hydrolysis of ornithine” is incorrect because arginase hydrolyzes arginine to urea and ornithine; ornithine is not hydrolyzed to form urea. Ornithine re-enters the cycle by accepting carbamoyl phosphate to form citrulline.
    • “ATP is required for the reaction in which argininosuccinate is cleaved to form arginine” is incorrect. Argininosuccinate lyase cleaves argininosuccinate → arginine + fumarate without ATP. ATP is consumed earlier: carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I uses 2 ATP, and argininosuccinate synthetase uses ATP → AMP + PPi (equivalent to two high-energy bonds).
  • Because protein intake increases nitrogen disposal through the urea cycle, urinary urea appropriately rises—exactly matching choice D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP is required for the reaction in which argininosuccinate is cleaved to form arginine: Incorrect. The reaction in which argininosuccinate is cleaved to form arginine is catalyzed by argininosuccinate lyase and does not require ATP. Although the urea cycle does use ATP (e.g., CPS I; argininosuccinate synthetase), ATP is not used at the lyase step. Therefore, this statement does not describe a correct aspect of the cycle.

 

Option B. Urea is produced directly by the hydrolysis of ornithine: Incorrect. Urea is produced by hydrolysis of arginine, not ornithine. Arginase converts arginine → urea + ornithine. The produced ornithine re-enters the urea cycle (accepts carbamoyl phosphate to form citrulline) but is not directly hydrolyzed to generate urea. Hence, this statement is not correct.

 

Option C. The two nitrogen atoms that are incorporated into urea enter the cycle as ammonia and alanine: Incorrect. While ammonia is indeed one nitrogen source, the other nitrogen comes from aspartate, not alanine. Alanine carries nitrogen from muscle to liver but does not directly serve as the second nitrogen donor incorporated into urea. Thus, the phrase “ammonia and alanine” is not a correct description of nitrogen entry into the urea cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A diet rich in protein increases nitrogen disposal via the urea cycle, leading to increased urinary urea.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with a history of poorly controlled asthma despite maximal inhaled corticosteroid and long-acting β₂-agonist therapy presents with recurrent hospitalizations for exacerbations. Peripheral blood studies show an eosinophil count of 1,200/µL (normal <500/µL). Pulmonary function testing demonstrates a reduced FEV₁ with partial reversibility after bronchodilator use. Given her severe eosinophilic asthma, she is started on a monoclonal antibody that binds to the IL-5 receptor α chain. Which of the following biologic agents best fits this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Benralizumab

 

  • Benralizumab is a monoclonal antibody against the IL-5 receptor α chain on eosinophils and basophils.
  • It triggers antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC), leading to rapid and nearly complete eosinophil depletion.
  • It is FDA-approved as an add-on therapy for severe eosinophilic asthma, especially in patients who remain symptomatic despite high-dose inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting β₂-agonists.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Omalizumab: Anti-IgE monoclonal antibody used in moderate to severe allergic asthma with elevated serum IgE. It does not target IL-5.

 

Option B. Dupilumab: Anti-IL-4 receptor α monoclonal antibody that blocks IL-4 and IL-13 signaling. It is used for moderate-to-severe asthma, atopic dermatitis, and chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab: Anti-her-2/neu monoclonal antibody that is used for treatment of breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benralizumab is an IL-5 receptor α monoclonal antibody that induces eosinophil apoptosis via antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, and is used as add-on therapy for severe eosinophilic asthma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was taken to a trauma centre after suffering an accident. An X-ray of her pelvis was taken, and the image below demonstrates an intracapsular fracture NOF. In this instance, what is the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed Reduction Internal Fixation

 

  • This procedure involves realigning the bone fragments without an open incision (closed reduction) and then stabilizing them with screws or pins (internal fixation).
  • This is the preferred treatment for an intracapsular NOF fracture in a young adult because it aims to preserve the native hip joint.
  • A successful reduction and fixation provides the best chance for the fracture to heal, restoring the original anatomy and function of the hip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiarthroplasty:

 

  • While hemiarthroplasty (replacement of only the femoral head component of the hip joint) is a common treatment option for older patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, it might not be the best choice for a younger patient with the potential for long-term joint function. 
  • Hemiarthroplasty is considered a salvage procedure for joints with severe degenerative arthritis or avascular necrosis. 

 

Option C. Closed Reduction:

 

  • This procedure involves manipulating the bone fragments back into position without surgery. 
  • However, it is less likely to be successful with a displaced intracapsular fracture, especially in a younger patient. 
  • Closed reduction may be considered for nondisplaced fractures or as an initial attempt before resorting to ORIF. 

 

Option D. Open + Closed Reduction:

 

  • This option combines open surgical exposure with closed manipulation of the fracture fragments. 
  • While technically possible, it is generally not preferred over a standard ORIF due to the increased complexity and potential for complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At age 45, preserving the natural hip joint is the priority. CRIF allows for this, while a hemiarthroplasty would require subsequent revision surgeries due to the patient's greater life expectancy and activity level.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of progressive hearing difficulty in her right ear. She denies vertigo but reports occasional tinnitus. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Pure tone audiometry shows an air-bone gap of 25 dB at low frequencies with normal bone conduction thresholds. Tympanometry demonstrates a Type As curve with reduced compliance but normal middle ear pressure. Acoustic reflex is absent on the affected side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

 

  • Otosclerosis is a hereditary disorder characterized by abnormal bony remodeling at the stapes footplate, leading to conductive hearing loss.
  • Audiometry shows an air-bone gap (conductive pattern), tympanometry shows a Type As curve (stiff system with reduced compliance), and absent acoustic reflexes further confirm stapes fixation. 
  • The normal tympanic membrane rules out middle ear effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secretory otitis media: This condition produces a conductive hearing loss, but tympanometry usually shows a Type B curve (flat, indicating fluid in the middle ear). Additionally, the tympanic membrane often appears dull or retracted, which was not observed in this patient.

 

Option C. Acute otitis media: Acute infection of the middle ear typically presents with fever, ear pain, and a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. Audiometry would show conductive loss, but tympanometry would more likely show a Type C curve if negative pressure is present or Type B if effusion has developed. The chronic, painless course in this patient does not fit.

 

Option D. Eustachian tube dysfunction: This often produces a Type C tympanogram (negative middle ear pressure) due to poor aeration of the middle ear. Patients usually report ear fullness or popping sensations, not progressive conductive hearing loss with normal tympanic membrane and absent stapedial reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In audiology, otosclerosis is characterized by a conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap, Type As tympanogram, and absent acoustic reflexes, distinguishing it from otitis media and eustachian tube dysfunction.

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4–5 days to allow spontaneous healing
Do an MRI to localize the leak and repair endoscopically
Insert a lumbar (dural) catheter to control CSF leak
Perform transcranial repair of the frontobasal defect

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He is conscious and oriented but complains of watery discharge from his right nostril. NCCT head reveals a inoperable frontobasal skull fracture. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wait and watch for 4–5 days to allow spontaneous healing

 

  • The majority of cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea close spontaneously within a few days.
  • Conservative management includes bed rest, head elevation, avoidance of coughing/sneezing, and prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis.
  • Immediate surgical intervention is not required unless the leak persists beyond 7–10 days or complications (like meningitis) arise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Do an MRI to localize the leak and repair endoscopically: Endoscopic repair is considered for persistent or recurrent leaks that do not close with conservative management. It is not the first-line approach in an acute setting where healing can occur spontaneously.

 

Option C. Insert a lumbar (dural) catheter to control CSF leak: Lumbar drains may be used as a supportive measure in persistent leaks to reduce intracranial pressure and facilitate healing, but they are not indicated in the initial conservative phase.

 

Option D. Perform transcranial repair of the frontobasal defect: This is reserved for complex, persistent, or recurrent leaks that cannot be managed endoscopically. It carries higher morbidity and is not appropriate for an initial non-surgical case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea resolve spontaneously; hence, the initial management is conservative observation for 4–5 days, reserving surgical repair for persistent or complicated leaks.

choices.text: Larvae migrate and encyst in skeletal muscles
Coproantigen ELISA can confirm active intestinal infection
Adult worms are isolated from CSF during early infection
Muscle biopsy near tendon is a reliable diagnostic method

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Trichinella spiralis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult worms are isolated from CSF during early infection

 

  • Adult worms are isolated from CSF during early infection is incorrect, because Trichinella spiralis adult worms are not found in the CSF. 
  • After ingestion of first-stage larvae (L1) from undercooked pork, the parasite matures into adults in the intestinal mucosa, not in the central nervous system.
  • The larvae migrate via the bloodstream to striated muscle, not the CSF, where they encyst.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larvae migrate and encyst in skeletal muscles: True. This is a classic feature of T. spiralis. Preferred sites include extraocular muscles, jaw, neck, diaphragm, and deltoid.

 

Option B. Coproantigen ELISA can confirm active intestinal infection: True. The double sandwich ELISA targeting larval somatic antigens in stool helps confirm intestinal phase of the infection.

 

Option D. Muscle biopsy near tendon is a reliable diagnostic method: True. Muscle biopsy from areas near tendons (e.g., deltoid insertion) is diagnostic and can reveal encysted larvae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichinella spiralis is transmitted via ingestion of L1 larvae in undercooked pork. Larvae encyst in skeletal muscle, not CSF. 
  • Diagnosis can include muscle biopsy, coproantigen detection, and serology, but adult worms are confined to the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic concerned about the absence of her menstrual periods for the past 9 months. Her symptoms began after she underwent a dilation and curettage procedure following a missed abortion. Laboratory results show serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy

 

  • This 28-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea lasting 9 months following a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure after a missed abortion. 
  • The normal serum FSH and LH levels indicate intact hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis function, ruling out central causes of amenorrhea. 
  • Given the temporal relationship between the D&C procedure and the onset of amenorrhea, the most likely diagnosis is Asherman's syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or synechiae). 
  • Hysteroscopy is the gold standard diagnostic tool for directly visualizing the uterine cavity and identifying intrauterine adhesions. 
  • It allows for both diagnosis and potential therapeutic intervention during the same procedure, making it the most appropriate next investigation in this clinical scenario.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography: Although this imaging study can identify uterine cavity abnormalities and tubal patency, it is less sensitive than hysteroscopy for detecting intrauterine adhesions. It also involves radiation exposure and cannot provide therapeutic intervention if adhesions are found.

 

Option B. Serum prolactin level: While elevated prolactin can cause amenorrhea, the normal FSH and LH levels make a prolactin-related cause less likely. Additionally, the clear temporal relationship with the D&C procedure points toward a structural uterine cause rather than a hormonal one.

 

Option D. Progesterone challenge test: This test evaluates estrogen levels and endometrial responsiveness but would not be the next best step when structural uterine pathology is suspected. With normal FSH and LH levels, hormonal causes are less likely, and the progesterone challenge would not identify intrauterine adhesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following dilation and curettage procedures, patients who develop secondary amenorrhea with normal FSH and LH levels should be evaluated for Asherman's syndrome using hysteroscopy as the diagnostic method of choice.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1–b, 2–c, 3–a, 4–d

 

  • 1. Amitriptyline → b. Acute angle-closure glaucoma:
    • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) with potent anticholinergic effects.
    • These effects can lead to mydriasis (pupil dilation), which may precipitate acute angle-closure glaucoma, especially in predisposed individuals with shallow anterior chambers.
  • 2. SSRIs (e.g., Fluoxetine) → c. Sexual dysfunction:
    • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) commonly cause sexual side effects, including delayed ejaculation, decreased libido, and anorgasmia.
    • This is one of the most frequent causes of SSRI discontinuation.
  • 3. Trazodone → a. Priapism: Trazodone, an antidepressant with serotonergic and alpha-1 adrenergic blocking properties, is notorious for causing priapism (prolonged, painful erection) as a rare but serious side effect.
  • 4. Bupropion → d. Seizure threshold lowering:
    • Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI).
    • It is contraindicated in patients with seizure disorders, as it lowers the seizure threshold, especially at high doses or in predisposed individuals (e.g., bulimia, anorexia nervosa).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of commonly used antidepressants:

 

  • Amitriptyline (TCA) can trigger acute angle-closure glaucoma due to anticholinergic action.
  • SSRIs often cause sexual dysfunction, the most common reason for discontinuation.
  • Trazodone is uniquely associated with priapism, a rare urologic emergency.
  • Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and must be avoided in predisposed individuals

choices.text: Recommend lifestyle modifications and repeat BP in 3 months
Order an echocardiogram to assess for target organ damage
Refer to a cardiologist for further evaluation

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with no cardiovascular risk factors presents for a routine check-up. His office BP readings over three visits in the past month are consistently 132/84 mmHg, 135/86 mmHg, and 134/85 mmHg. He is asymptomatic with a normal physical examination. What should be the next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recommend lifestyle modifications and repeat BP in 3 months

 

  • The patient’s office BP (130–139/80–89 mmHg) falls into the elevated BP category per the ESC 2024 guidelines, which define this range as a continuum of cardiovascular risk without meeting the hypertension threshold (≥140/90 mmHg). 
  • The absence of CV risk factors and symptoms suggests a low immediate risk, guiding a conservative approach.
  • The ESC 2024 guidelines recommend lifestyle modifications (e.g., sodium reduction <5 g/day, 150–300 min/week moderate exercise, weight loss if BMI >25 kg/m²) for elevated BP, especially in the absence of CV risk factors.
  • Repeat BP measurement in 3 months allows assessment of progression or stability, aligning with the guideline’s emphasis on monitoring before initiating pharmacotherapy in low-risk cases.
  • Rationale: The patient’s consistent readings and lack of risk factors indicate a need for non-pharmacologic intervention first, with follow-up to determine if hypertension develops (≥140/90 mmHg), as per the risk-based strategy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiate antihypertensive medication immediately: Incorrect. Immediate medication is not indicated for elevated BP (130–139/80–89 mmHg) without CV risk factors or target organ damage, per ESC 2024. Pharmacotherapy is reserved for hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) or high-risk patients, avoiding unnecessary treatment in this low-risk case.

 

Option C. Order an echocardiogram to assess for target organ damage: Incorrect. Echocardiography is not routinely recommended for elevated BP without symptoms, signs of left ventricular hypertrophy, or other CV risk factors. The ESC 2024 guidelines suggest imaging only as an optional step to assess HMOD, not a mandate. 

 

Option D. Refer to a cardiologist for further evaluation: Incorrect. Referral is unwarranted for elevated BP without risk factors or abnormal findings. The ESC guidelines advocate primary care management with lifestyle changes and follow-up, reserving specialist referral for resistant hypertension or secondary cause suspicion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elevated BP (130–139/80–89 mmHg) without CV risk factors warrants lifestyle modifications (e.g., sodium <5 g/day, exercise) and BP recheck in 3 months.
  • Immediate antihypertensive therapy is not indicated unless BP reaches ≥140/90 mmHg or risk factors are present.
  • Routine echocardiography or cardiology referral is unnecessary without evidence of target organ damage or complications.
